number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 10, 2013
												Edit: Updated for the newest patch.Shadowrun returns tries *really hard* to be a great game. It's got a great history in tabletop roleplay, and the super nintendo shadowrun might be the most overlooked RPG of all time. The framework is definitely laid to make this one of the best retro gaming experiences of the last few years. Sadly, a lack of attention to detail often holds it back. Simple things, like healing kits in the store before the last fight, have been flat out overlooked or left out. It may be intentional, however there are enough times that it happens that it really feels like the game was slightly rushed. Another great example of this is the decking system. Decking itself is fun, if a bit tedious at times. However, there are 3 missions in the entire game that actually allow you to deck. And the times there are decking quests? One requires you to take an npc along as a sidekick (not bad, all things considered). The next decking mission? The npc *has to* do it, you don't even help. I realize there may be plot reasons, but where it ends up is that there's an entire skill tree that they literally only let you use twice. My first run was a decker, and I got through 3/4ths of the game before I got to actually use the skills I built for. Frustrating doesn't describe it. Another issue is how healing magic only heals the last attack to hit you. Mobs love throwing a big hit, then pinging you for 1 damage. This wouldn't even be an issue, except for the fact that you have limited medkits, and can't force your helpers to pick em up on the fly. Either you get them, or they go to your stash. This isn't an issue in combat mode, but you can't toggle combat mode manually, so if you're out of a fight? Hope you're the medic, because you're the one getting the health packs. Movement can be equally tricky, especially when it starts getting crowded. Misclicks, clicks in wrong places, moving instead of attacking (the worst of the bunch, as it's pretty easy to die if you're not behind cover) are commonplace if you're not careful. Add the ability to manually enter combat mode at any time (so npcs can pick stuff up), or inventory management on the fly, mixed with a bit of an easier way to move to a specific location in a crowd? A lot of my problems would immediately go away.Shadowrun combat is fun and engaging. There's a deep variety of skills and abilities that all influence the battle field in different ways. Mage-based spellcasting feels powerful, especially if you beef yourself up to be able to take a hit (you'll have to) and stand on a ley line. Rigging is a *blast*, if a bit frustrating as they only allow one of each drone type per tier. This means, if you want 2 attack drones? One's gonna suck a bit. Summoning, similarly, is a ton of fun and feels really powerful. They put quite a few free summoning points in the game, it's one of the few ways you can use the environment against your enemy. As for Adepts? They are a bit under-utilized, IMO. Right now they're heavily melee focused, and take a lot of finesse to get full use out of, because you're so skill-thin. Body for HP, Quickness because Dodge, Strength for melee attacks and the attack focus skill, Will for Chi Casting. Late bloomer doesn't describe them, even the supposedly super-awesome npc you pick up near the end isn't all that impressive. And, without spoilers, he's one of the strongest characters in the entire Shadowrun canon.The campaign's difficulty is incredibly well balanced. I was thrilled when even my biggest indestructible troll still had to take cover from time to time, because becoming fully immortal is impossible when your enemies have fully automatic machine guns. Some of the UGC (actually, most of it I've played to this point) doesn't have the same light touch, though, making swapping from the official campaign a pretty steep learning curve. The only real issue with the main campaign is length. It's incredibly short, especially for this style of game. Lots of people lament the fact that it's a fairly linear experience, but I personally enjoyed that. Not every game needs to be a sandbox, and Shadowrun Returns has a very distinct story to tell. Some may feel shoehorned, but I just enjoyed going along for the ride. The writing in the main campaign is *fantastic* and easily the strongest thing about it. They paid a lot of attention to detail, and really worked a lot of the flavor of the shadowrun world into their story. I *love* the big bad, as well. They definitely swung for the fences with the nemesis in dead man's switch. This is a great touch, since I know a lot of us pnp shadowrun players have fond memories of them. As well, major and well known players in the shadowrun universe make cameos, and some may even join your team. There's a great early nod to the snes shadowrun game that really set a great tone. This game pays obvious respect to what came before it. The fact that Jordan Weisman was responsible for this is very apparent in the plot and tone. Also, for those wanting a sandbox style adventure? Dragonfall is very much along those lines.The graphics, as well, are spot on. The game feels fun, and cartoony, and really captures the essence of the shadowrun universe. Hyperkinetic neon and chrome, with a touch of Tolkien fantasy, blend together oddly well. None of it feels out of place. My only qualms about the background art boil down to there not being enough of them, which becomes a problem with UGC as it all starts to look exactly the same. The sprites are also well designed, if a bit generic at times (I'm looking at you, every troll in the game), and the game wouldn't hurt for the option of using different faces/body types. The sound? Meh. The soundtrack is fun at first, but quickly gets repetitive. I tend to turn off the music and put on some industrial while I play, or other music suitable for shadowrun. After the first playthrough, or even the first few hours? You probably will too. UGC... It's the elephant in the room. UGC is a great idea in theory, and supposedly a high selling point for the game. The ability to create your own worlds, and play the worlds other people create, is *fantastic* on paper. And sometimes, it even works in execution. This is seeming to be the exception to the rule. UGC suffers from the same thing it does in most other games that feature it. It's uneven, balance is often lacking, the plots are frequently very weak, and... Well... It was made by the community, with all of the lack of polish that entails. There are a few *strong* exceptions to this rule, but it seems overall like the ones with the great plot lack any semblance of combat balance. As well, and as mentioned, the art assets get rather repetitive. A lot of the UGC just looks cut-and-paste, which is probably because they are. On the upside, sourcebooks from the original pen and paper game being fully converted into the game, and heavily fine tuned. Some of the creators have done a lot of work adding even more customization options, which is *amazing*. The major downfall to UGC is already becoming apparent post-Dragonfall, however. A few of the people responsible for large conversion kits or well known adventures have walked away, because the expansion completely broke their work. It's the same problem the UGC community of the first Neverwinter Nights faced, with every new expansion comes 10-20 hours of work to put your mods back together again.Overall, this game is fantastic. It's got some quirks, but Dragonfall cleaned up a lot of bugs or issues that were once holding it back. This is solid retro gaming. 8/10

content:
Posted: February 27, 2014
												I'll get straight to the point:The Good: It's official campaign Dead Man's Switch is pretty good so to speak. The story it has justifies the linearity of the game's design as it's pretty much like reading an interactive book (like some of the older RPGs of the 90s). The game is practically friendly to almost any PC considering that it relies on the cyberpunk aesthetics to make the game look pretty. In terms of combat, it's basically a simplified version of Xcom: Enemy Unknown and if you like that game, you are going to be fairly familiar with how the game works. And even if you are done with the main campaign, there's still more to offer from the community itself through UGCs which can be downloaded through Steam directly or through the Shadowrun Nexus (especially if you own the DRM-free version on GOG) And by the time of this review (which is the same time as when the DLC Dragonfall first came out) you can actually save without relying on the autosave feature. The Bad: Due to the fact that the replayability of this game past Dead Man's Switch (and Dragonfall) is dependent on the UGC of the community, you will probably have to take your time to look for custom campaigns that are actually complete, let alone any good. Most of the complete ones are usually the shortest or the simplest of campaigns. In addition, the Dead Man's Switch campaign doesn't seem to give much options to have a players who want to play a Face or a Decker as they are either very few instances to begin with or doesn't truly payoff. I don't like the fact that I have to actually rely on hiring more runners for a particular mission and they feel restrictive in which you cannot give them suitable gear or even have them hold on to an medkit if your inventory is full. Also, there are certain dialog choices that are greyed out if you don't meet the required stats to qualify. I'd rather have them hidden to keep me surprised. On top of that, I know that the idea behind this game is to make the player the main protagonist, but the problem with that is that this is Shadowrun, and the reason you have a variety of runner archetypes in a team is because you can take advantage of what they are capable of inside and outside of combat. Instead, that variety is only restricted to combat and combat alone save of you being able to appoint a hired/companion decker to hack into the Matrix for you in case you are incapable of such a task.Overall: Shadowrun Returns has it's flaws but I like what Harebrained as treated it so far. It's not an amazing game and it's hardly going to be the "best RPG EVAR!!!11!" but if you appreciate a good cyberpunk story with a touch of magic with a potential for more to come whether by the devs themselves through DLC or by the Shadowrun community, then I'd say this is a very safe purchase.

content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												As a gamer constantly looking for as immersive as possible and varying different experiences, it felt as if I found a gold mine just for myself after 1 hour within Shadowrun Returns. The game runs as half tactic combat, half story. Both are very well made and entertaining, but where the game truly excells is the story. At first I was put off by the lack of voice in the game. Why are the pretty and detailed avatars with excessive and rich language representing the dialogue, entirely silent? I dig around options looking for volume slider, but there was none. Some minutes of gaming later I realized the person who wrote the story, descriptions, and dialogue lines is a pure genious. Reading your way into the world of Shadowrun is like reading a truly well written novel. I really really hope the person behind these texts continues the work in the next Shadowrun game. Thus, the game world is immersive, colourful, rich. There is zero point in spoiling the story, but it should suffice to say that it is very good and that♥♥♥♥♥♥goes down in unexpected extremely well written ways. The world of the game is not so big, but the way it is presented and through the richness of details you get a sense that it is huge, living, and real, and that there are so many more interesting "♥♥♥♥♥♥going down" kind of things going on besides your own story. Sahdowrun's RPG elements are not very deep but fun and engaging enough to encourage even several playthroughs. I would suggest Shadowrun Returns to anyone interested in a truly good story or immersive world, or those who like tactical combat. The game is truly bad♥♥♥♥♥

number of helpful: 6 of 10 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 9, 2014
												I managed to pick this up on a steam sale a while back. My friend suggested I just pirate it because the game wouldn't be worth 15 euro. How wrong he was! I've just come off finishing this entire game in one sitting, and the reason for that is because the game is that good.The game comes with one campaign which is called 'dead man's switch'. This is the campaign the developpers made and is a very good showcase of what you can do in Shadowrun returns. The story sucks you in and the entire realistic atmosphere gives off a gritty blade runner feeling. You actually feel the grime that exists in the world and the parallels to our world are scarily frequent.The gameplay itself is a blast, you play the game using a self constructed avatar which you assign a 'class'. Which can be broken down into a fighter, monk, mage, summoner, hacker and trapper. The game then divides the points into the needed categories and from there you are free to specialise your character how you see fit. This gives you an insane amount of customisation as far as your character is concerned. Besides yourself you can hire help to go along on the runs (missions), you can preview their stats and items before picking them and during the mission you are free to control them as you see fit.The game also contains a lot of dialogue which helps to flesh out the living and breathing world. You sometimes get choices which you feel will have some impact later on along the line, sadly you generally don't see any effect from your choices besides alternate ways of attack something or something being worth more or being more expensive.I suggest anyone to atleast give shadowrun a try, the game is really fun, able to pull you into it's world and the challenge it provides is just right in my opinion. Despite in the last mission the two 'superior' characters being weaker then my own dwarf. "Reality can be found in the shadows"

												You don't see these kind of games that often now a days. The old school classic feel you get with the isometric tactical RPG's from back in the days. Shadowrun Returns brings this back in full force. Great looking artistic graphics, very well written story and game play that is enjoyable. For me this is one of the best games i played all year. 												Some folks have noted that the core module "Dead Man's Switch" is short and the gameplay is limited. Those are both fair points, but when thought of as a weekend romp through a cyberpunk landscape, Shadowrun Returns is perfect. You're not bogged down learning in-depth combat systems or slogging through tutorials. The game gets off to a snappy start and doesn't stop. The writing is easily the best part in setting the tone even if the graphics won't blow you away. I wouldn't say the story is short so much as not cluttered with filler. Every step is meaningful and that's downright refreshing in an RPG nowdays despite shaving hours off of the game.

												I was proud to back this game on Kickstarter, and the final result is no disappointment. The tactical combat is very satisfying, and the writing and atmosphere are great. The end of the main story is just where the experience begins, though, because the community has already started creating some incredible content. This is to Shadowrun what Neverwinter Nights was to D&D, with new community modules cropping up everywhere to make the game much bigger than any single company could make. It'll just keep getting better as time goes on.This is a worthy Shadowrun game, recommended for everyone who loves party-based RPGs with turn-based tactical combat.

content:
Posted: December 19, 2013
												Let me start out by saying that this is the first Shadowrun game that I have ever actually played. Yes I have tried the 1993 Shadowrun for the Super Nintendo but I could never get into it due to it's... Interesting controls (read point and click with a controller). But the game concept and the universe intrigued me, Over the years I forgot the name of it several times but would bring it up every few years and try to find the name of it and feel that they should remake it for the pc where it ultimately belonged. Well a few months ago was one such time that It popped into my head, I did a quick search for it and what did I find but a new Shadowrun being made for its proper platform (psst its the PC). I instantly fell in love with the style and everything I say was just the best thing I have ever seen.Flash forward to now where I have been given the ability to write this review and I am just stoked to be able to finally play a Shadowrun game without being hindered by a D-pad. Well I wasn't home when I got the Beta code but I had a 2 hour drive till I got home and then I had to download it and set it up. This just ate at me up inside but I managed to do it and when I first started it up I felt a chill as the dark and music (composed by Marshall Parker and Sam Powell from the 1993 SNES Shadowrun) started to play and the menu appeared.When you start a new game your greeted with a fairly standard character creation menu. You can select your gender, race and choose between several preconfigured or a custom skill sets for your character as well as select from one of several portraits and player models. The models look nice but are lacking the level of detail that you see with other games though this low detail level just feels right in the world, fitting in with the 2D environments. Each race has specific traits that are more prominent then others, these usually have higher starting values and higher max values. After choosing a character model and skill set you get to pick traits and spend your skill points on your starting stats. As soon as you are done creating your character you start in a modest apartment. After looking around the apartment for a while you get a call from an old friend and are sent into a flashback where you learn more about yourself and your friend but more importantly you get to experience the combat system for the first time.Shadowrun Returns is broken up into missions and uses an auto save feature that saves at the beginning of a mission. It uses a tactical combat system where you have your squad and each member has action points. Each action your characters take use action points and once they're gone then that character can't do anything till the next turn.This is customary for tactical games like this and even new people to this style of play should get used to it rather quickly. The combat system uses cover and line of site as a tactic and shows you how good the cover is and to what side you have cover on. This system isn't perfect as it doesn't always show that you're in cover and at times it's hard to tell if your line of site is broken simply due to the layout of the room and the camera angle.Shadowrun Returns comes with a full scenario editor that allows users to create whole new missions and stories and share them with the community. The editor has been out for many of the kickstarter backers for a while now so there is going to be plenty of user made content available. Someone is currently working on recreating the old SNES Shadowrun into Shadowrun Returns using the editor available here http://www.obsidianportal.com/campaigns/snes-shadowrun/mapsOverall I feel that the 2D backgrounds and the 3D character models mesh very well together and unlike in some games they feel right together. The story is excellent and you don't feel like it's being force fed down your gullet so you can play the game for the story or the game play or both. The main story is quite linier and it tends to feel like there's some handholding going on but you can choose to help someone or leave them to their own devices and save your own skin. I am not a master of table top RPG's but this feels like how I would imagine a table top RPG should be on a PC.Check out my video review on YouTube @ 


YouTube™ Video: Shadowrun Returns - Ultimate Gaming Realm 

			Views: 89		

			Shadowrun Returns is a Shadowrun game based off of a pen and paper RPG books that really made a true comeback into the world of gaming through a successful Kickstarter campaign from 19 year gap since...

Posted: November 13, 2015
												While I like this game a lot, others may not, depending on what they're expecting.If you are expecting any edition of the tabletop role-playing game, or the Genesis or SNES console games, you will be disappointed.  Shadowrun: Returns plays something like a simplified version of tabletop rules that never actually existed.I liked the plot, combat, and music.Opinions on the plot vary widely.  If you have an aversion to reading, this game is not for you.  Almost all of the plot is delivered via screens of text upon entering an area, or text dialogs.  There is no voiceover.  Some people complain of purple prose, or that it seems to have been written by someone that is immature, but the writing is superior to that in most video games, including most other RPGs.  I personally do not perceive any of these problems, and have never seen examples cited.Screenshots do not do the combat system justice.  Some of the interface is only displayed when it is relevant.  For example, the action point cost of movement, and the effectiveness of cover, only appear when you prepare to move, and when cover exists in the area you mouseover.  The combat system is relatively simple (which is reflected in the user interface), but like Chess, can be quite difficult.  The difficulty is selectable at character creation, so if you find the game too easy or hard you can adjust it.  Since almost all RPGs are combat-heavy, it's important that it not be mindless and repetitive.The music is hard to describe.  It is not ambient.  You will notice it.  I especially like the theme on the title screen.I didn't like some things about Shadowrun: Returns.It is very linear, and most decisions will not affect the ending.The gameplay in the matrix is very similar to meatspace.  It's not so much that the gameplay in the matrix is bad as it doesn't feel different enough.The game only saves on area transition.  If you have to stop playing, or die, unexpectedly, you can lose quite a bit of progress.

Posted: November 23, 2015
												This is a fine piece of a turn-based RPG. I defnitely enjoyed this great, albeit short,  game and would recommend it to anyone who enjoys turn-based rpgs, x-com enemy unknown/within, urban-science-fantasy settings and fantasy races. A surprisingly good mixture of sci-fi stuff with near-like contemporary settings filled with elves, orcs, trolls and dwarves.

Posted: February 18, 2014
												Excellent! Loved it!There is no free roaming - this game is on rails.  It's more like an interactive William Gibson novel than Fallout Tactics.But it's the writing that really stands out,  that and the the RPG setting.  After playing this, I think if i ever did pen and paper again I'd like to try Shadowrun.  It reminds me a lot of Traveller (all-time favorite pen and paper RPG) in some respects.The music is good and fits the game well.The art is unique - be sure to zoom in occasionally to check out the details.In some of the levels, you will have a character jacked into the matrix and running alone,  while the rest of the team defends the access point (and the helpless cybernaut).  The game does a good job of creating a genuine feeling of urgency in these situations.Save points:  the game saves for you.  if you screw up a level you have to play it over again.  Did not care for this.I did not find it possible while on a mission to drop out of combat (when no enemies were visible) to move easier -  either i just never figured out how,  or it's not possible.  It should be automatic.  Did not care for this.I found the early game fights weak & easy.  Later scenarios were more difficult.Many reviews I have read lamented that the game is too short.  If you were expecting an open world roamer,  it is -  but if you are expecting a good novel,  it's not.   And ultimately, i think that's what this game is - a good novel.Speaking of good novel,  i found after playing  - being curious about some of the characters -  that i had met a very famous (in the milleu) dragon,  and an immortal - both subtly and (believe it or not) *realistically* portrayed.  another example of good writing.More side quests and missions would have been nice -  but it would have detracted from coherence.If you like cyberpunk novels, or gritty film noir,    you'll probably like this game.   I picked it up on sale for ~7.00$  and it's Definitely worth that.

												For a  turn based, and thus slow paced, game this is a pretty solid buy (especially on sale). The original mission is kind of short but the Dragonfall DLC is longer and more enjoyable. Also, the DLCs which I am just starting to get into are prety solid. I'm a big fan of ond SNES style RPGs which is why I wanted to try this game, and I wasn't dissapointed.ONLY COMPLAINTThere isn't a lot of replay value in the main mission, and there are not a lot of weapons/spells/equipment choices to keep you coming back and trying new thins with the same character class. Posted: July 9, 2014
												Overview:Pros:-	2D environments and portraits-	Interesting characters-	great writing-	refreshing setting-	diverse skill systemCons:-	3D effects-	linear story-	story goes a little off the rail in the final act-	endgame fights (enemies appear out of nowhere, required party members)RPGs are my favorite genre. Nevertheless I didn’t enjoy recent RPGs like I used to. Yes, they might have great graphics, good gameplay mechanics or a well-crafted skill system, but the one aspect I find them lacking is the storytelling. Shadowrun Returns is an exception.Before I start getting into the details, I have to say I watched several gameplay and review videos before I picked it up. To be honest – I wasn’t impressed. Even though the hand-crafted 2D environments are gorgeous and vivid, the character models as well as the visual effects are far from impressive. Nevertheless, I gave it a shot and I wasn’t disappointed.The Shadowrun universe combines Cyberpunk aspects with the return of magic and metahumans in a futuristic world. The player slips into the role of a shadowrunner, an operative who will steal, infiltrate, hack and kidnap for the right price. The protagonist has to deal with powerful corporations, corruption, mythical creatures and fellow shadowrunners to survive.When it comes to creating a character that is your own, Shadowrun excels. You can choose between five races you might find in a fantasy RPG (human, elf, dwarf, ork, troll), which feel quite fresh in this unfamiliar setting. Your character can choose from six pre-made classes:-	Street Samurai: become a gun-wielding or close-range killing machine-	Mage: Fireballs, buffs and Debuffs. The familiar choice.-	Decker: jack into the Matrix to fight security systems with your programs-	Rigger: use small drones to support your team or deal damage-	Shaman: use totems or summon spirits to defeat your enemies-	Adept: use magic to enhance your own abilities, making yourself a weaponFurthermore you can also start from scratch and spend Karma points and create your own experience. Technoshaman? Combat Decker? Everything is possible, as long as you don’t spread the Karma points too thin. Skill checks are quite common in dialogue options and spending some points in Charisma or Intelligence can be worthwhile.The inventory system is quite rudimentary. Characters wear an outfit and can carry up to three weapons. Everyone can carry up to six consumables and Magic users as well as Deckers have a spellbook with up to six slots. To further improve skills or stats, cyberware can be implanted. However this results in increased cooldowns for spells.The gameplay revolves around a team of up to 4 shadowrunners. During the majority of the game you can hire a team and choose them depending on your group dynamics. Or your cash on hand, since shadowrunners don’t work for free. The combat system is round-based and reminds of Fallout 1 & 2. Action points have to be spend wisely to move, attack or use consumables like medkits and grenades.You have to read! Where many games try to tell their stories with cutscenes and voice acting, Shadowrun Returns presents the story with superb writing. Whenever you travel to a new location or meet a character the situation is beautifully described before you have to worry about combat or dialogue choices. Combined with vibrant character portraits, the characters you encounter feel alive.The different races and classes offer replayability. My first playthrough (normal, Human Decker) took 9+ hours. Due to the familiarity with enemy placement and linear storyline, my second run (very hard, Dwarf Mage) took a little over five hours. I can see myself coming back to try out different classes, however for now I’m enjoying the Dragonfall DLC (very hard, Troll Adept).I would highly recommend this game to players who enjoy round-based RPGs, which concentrate on storytelling.

												A quick note - I've only played Dragonfall, and have not yet touched the original campaign.This was a really well-done narrative game, with a surprisingly fun tactical component, reminiscent of x-com (and the upcoming Wasteland 2).  While linear, the game did a stellar job of making it not feel linear.  The narrative was rather strong, and kept me interested the entirety of the way through.  The author's of the game clearly knew the setting well (as one would hope with the creator of the setting being on the team), and knew what elements worked well and wouldn't work well in the world.There are some caveots: there were some bugs which cropped up periodically, that if I hadn't been regularly saving would have forced me to restart the mission.  (On the other hand, at least this game would let you restart the mission without too much fuss).  There were some instances of some items dissapearing permanently if I didn't pick them up.  Another big issue is the lack of ability to change my party member's gear, or to even control them outside of combat.Overall, this is one of the strongest narrative games I have played in a long while.  Even some annoyances (and the inability to give weapons I find to party members is a big one for me) were unable to dissuade me from finishing the game.  I can't stop talking about this game to my friends, and perhaps you won't be able to either.

												At the time of this writing, Hairbrained Studios have only released "Dead Man's Switch" and "Dragonfall", with the latter a significantly stronger module than the former. Both are heavily combat-based, and while careful positioning and action choices can tilt battles in your favor, the RNG can make sure that even if you do everything right, your team can still be wiped in a couple rounds due to keyboard-smashing bad luck (in this respect, the combat is very similar to X-COM: Enemy Unknown). But if you're getting an RPG like this, you're hopefully getting it knowing that luck is part of the game.It's all very good fun, particularly on harder difficulties. Agonizing over how to build your character, whom to take on a mission, and how to position them each round should please old-school turn-based RPG purists. The story arcs and character depth are not really fantastic, but the game is built on going out and completing runs (usually by shooting/stabbing/blowing things up, with only occassional decking responsibilities).Definite recommend, particularly if you've played the pencil-and-paper version.

Posted: March 24, 2014
												Shadowrun: Returns and its Expansion/DLC Shadowrun: Dragonfall is a turn-based tactical RPG game created by a studio called Harebrained Schemes out of Seattle, WA. The base game Shadowrun: Returns was released on Steam on July 25th, 2013, and the DLC Shadowrun: Dragonfall was released on February 27th, 2014.For those not familiar with the Shadowrun universe, it is based on a cyber-punk futuristic planet Earth. It is the 2050’s. The world is run by enormous, greedy corporations who will stop at nothing to acquire power. The twist is that a few decades earlier (around our current modern-day) magic returned to our world. With it came elves, dwarves, trolls, ogres, and other magical creatures.Shadowrunners are for-hire mercenaries who will do just about any job as long as there is money to be made. Whether it is stealing secrets from a corporate rival, working as security to protect those secrets, or taking out individuals that stand in their way of power, they are hired by big corporations to do their “dirty work”. They work in the seedy underbelly of this corporate society and live and survive in the shadows.I discovered Shadowrun when I was browsing around Steam looking for something new to play. Dragonfall was pretty highly recommended, and after reading up a bit on it I thought it sounded like something I would enjoy. I started it up and decided to start from the beginning and play through the original campaign. I was immediately sucked in to the story. I just had to keep playing, if for no reason other than to find out how the story turned out!The story for each of the campaigns is probably the best feature of the game. I don’t think I’ve been this captivated by a video game’s story since Final Fantasy VII! Even though there are no video cut scenes and no voice overs, the story is told VERY well.The story is progressed by speaking with various NPCs in the game world. When you speak to them you are given a number of choices as to how you want to respond in the conversation. There are a few places in the game where the dialogue options you choose will change the sequence of events to complete the mission. There isn’t a LOT of these places, but they are there. Also some dialogue options may not be available to you because of certain conditions. For example, if your Strength stat is high you may be able to bully that gang leader into giving you the key you need to progress. But, if you lack strength and are more intelligent, you may have to use brains over brawn to get what you need. There is also a feature called “Etiquette”. The game describes etiquette as “knowing how to behave in various social situations”. In-game this means you will get certain dialogue options based on what etiquette you choose when you create your character. In the example above, if my character has the “Gang” etiquette I may have a dialogue option when talking to the gang leader that will open up different options for completing the mission.Character progression is pretty straight-forward. When you create your character there are a few class archetypes that you can choose from. This gives you a basic set of skills to start from. As you progress you will acquire more skill points that you can spend on any skill you want. If you want to spend your skill points to be a shotgun-wielding mage you can, or if you want to specialize in being an uber “Decker” (Shadowrun’s version of a computer hacker) you can do that too. While skill points come pretty easy, it’s still a good idea to specialize in one or two areas. The campaign isn’t long enough for you to get enough skill points to max out everything.The skills were all pretty well explained right in game. All of your teammates and other Shadowrunners that you can hire all have their own set of skills and abilities. So if you are a shotgun-wielding mage you can hire a teammate that has the hacking skills you need for a mission. I kind of like this system. It lets you build your character however you like and then you can complement your skills with those of the shadowrunners you run with.From the very beginning I felt like the game environment and the atmosphere were very well done. I felt like I was running around in the movie Blade Runner! Everything was futuristic, yet familiar. The characters I interacted with and their portraits definitely captured the cyberpunk feel. Each character you encounter has their own personality and they are very unique. I thought the music was great too, even if there wasn’t a lot of variety. I thought it fit well with the theme of the game.The tactical combat style is what attracted me to the game in the first place. I found the combat to be a lot of fun, and in some places it was VERY challenging. For most missions you have your player character and three other Shadowrunners to make up your team.When you are walking around the map everything is in real time. But, as soon as combat starts, it switches to turn-based tactical mode. Every member of your team has a set number of “Action Points” (AP) that you can spend each turn. Firing your weapon or using a special ability may cost an AP point. Moving to a different location with better cover may cost another. Casting that healing spell or reloading your rifle will cost another. This is where the tactical part comes in. You have to decide what you want each member of your team to do each round. Do you want to focus fire and finish off one enemy at a time, or do you spread out and burn them all down at once? You also have to be careful that you don’t leave yourself pinned down somewhere without enough AP to use that medkit to keep you alive in the fight. Once you spend all your AP for that turn, the computer will play the turn of your enemies. Once they are done it is your turn to spend your AP again. Add in that each weapon type has a different range and friendly-fire can be hazardous to your teammates, it makes combat VERY interesting.The Good, The Bad, and the UglyAs a whole I very much enjoyed Shadworun: Returns and Shadowrun: Dragonfall. The story lines for BOTH campaigns are among the best I’ve ever seen in a video game. The first campaign is a BIT slow to start but it’s only so at the beginning. Combat is a lot of fun and can be pretty challenging at times. There were a few missions I had to play through a couple of different times with different strategies before I was victorious.I really enjoyed the skill system as well. It was easy to understand and easy to use. I didn’t feel like I needed to go online and read hundreds of forum posts to learn what the best build for my character would be. I could just pick a couple of skills I wanted to learn that were fun for me and go with it and be successful.The only bad worth mentioning is the length of the campaigns. My total play time on Steam is 48 hours, and that was running all the way through both campaigns. I’m sure I’m a lot slower that a lot of other people. However, considering the inexpensive price of the game and the fact that there is a lot of player generated content on the Steam Workshop, there is a lot of replayability here. Hopefully they will also be releasing more DLC in the future.About the only “ugly” I can say about the game is a couple of buggy missions I encountered. In one mission there was an event that didn’t trigger properly and I was unable to continue because a door would not unlock. I had to replay that mission one or two times before it finally triggered properly and I could advance.Also, some earlier reviews criticized Shadowrun: Returns’ save system. At release you could only save at certain checkpoints. This is no longer the case. I’m not sure if it was with the release of Dragonfall or if it was before that, but they changed the game so you can now save anywhere.See my original review at http://www.mistervertigo.net

Posted: March 22, 2014
												Simply a-freaking-mazing.Shadowrun Returns is my first venture into this universe, and after a ten hour campaign, I'm completely obsessed. If you are also new, but a little wary about dropping the money for this title, allow me to explain a little about the game...SR is an isometric-style Rpg, set in a future-fantasy universe, where elves and dwarves wield shotguns and cast spells. Starting up the default campaign, Dead Man Switch, you create a character. Race, class and appearance are all up to you. Then, the developer, Harebrained Schemes drops you into a well-written and thoughtfully crafted story, presented in a text-based format - no voice acting here, and I think it's better for it, but that's personal preference. Dialog options are different depending on how you build your character and elicit different responses from NPCs, with charisma allowing you to sweet-talk, and etiquettes let you rub elbows with the many groups that populate Seattle.You play a Shadowrunner, a type of mercenary, doing the dirty-work of multi-billion dollar corporations and aristocrats for cash. Gameplay is very reminiscent of the recent Xcom: Enemy Unknown. If you didn't like that, chances are you won't like this. Every turn, each combatant is given a certain number of moves, from moving to shooting and using items. It's very tactical and you could wind up dead if you don't think before you click. Several jobs you undertake have you bringing other Runners on to watch your back and take a cut of the pay, so you're almost never alone.I found no hick-ups in the gameplay during my play-through. The specials and items are balanced well, meaning death is often the fault of the player's ill preparation. The game is fair, which is about all a gamer could ask for. Also available are game editors, allowing anyone to write their own stories and scenarios for others to enjoy. I haven't been able to try any out because there currently seems to be a bug that causes the ugc to be downloaded to the wrong files, making them difficult to locate.Shadowrun Returns is a gem that I'm glad was funded. It's not for everyone, but if it sounds like it's up your alley, I urge you to pick it up.

Posted: March 22, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is a game for those who enjoy old-school RPG's. Dragonfall DLC is a must have.The games strengths are in good writing, rich world history and all in all beautiful artwork.The world is beautifully detailed whether you're in the streets of Redmond Barrens, a luxurious corporate headquarter or busy market hub in Germany. I might not be the biggest fan of the "cartoony" style the designers went ahead with but all in all it works. The portrait artwork is also beautifully done.Dialogue and text is descriptive and good all through the games, lack of voice is the proper way to do an rpg when you have good writers.While there are many things in the game that could have been done better, far better even, I cannot think of any major  flaws or issues in design. Base game delivers an okay story and gameplay although it's lacking in many ways I still managed to get some 12 hours of gameplay from it and did not feel bad about getting the game but I did feel like it could have been done better and certainly it could have been bigger.Dragonfall DLC is a whole different story however. In fact, I would say that Dragonfall is -the- reason to buy Shadowrun Returns. Dragonfall provides you with a more classic Shadowrun feel, the storyline is excellent, the permanent companions have personalities and plenty of dialogue in and out of missions and even the local npc's are always worth talking to. Dragonfall features more of the actual Shadowrun gigs, the game is full of choices to make, plot twists to uncover and provides far richer experience for all types of characters as all types of skills have more uses.The Dragonfall DLC provided me with additional 18-20 hours of gameplay, far more than the base game does.Shadowrun Returns and Dragonfall dlc's only major problem is that it leaves me wanting for more. So much more.. I want a bigger game with more content!Harebrained Schemes has a great basis set up, hopefully they will continue in the path of Dragonfall as it is obviously doing so many things right.

Posted: March 4, 2014
												I never played Shadowrun when it was on the NES or whatever else it was on. I joined the world with Shadowrun Returns and I have to say its a good place to start. It opens up a lot of doors, and even some windows, to a whole new world of science and magic. The controls feel clunky sometimes, but its by no means game breaking. Its turn table based combat, good guys go first more often then not, and then the bad guys. You get to make your own character from various races and classes. You don't have to stick to class you pick at creation though. You can be a mage with some intense decking skills, or a rigger who knows some summoning. They don't force you to stick to a class. Just be careful, as the game often hints 'A Jack of all trades is a master of none.'You play as a Shadowrunner, a gun for hire in the streets. You've fallen on some hard times and seem to be thinking more about your future then your past, till you get a call from a old contact. A guy you used to run with, Sam. He's been killed recently and set up a 'dead mans switch' in his brain to send you a message when he finally kicks the bucket. Well, someone kicked his bucket for him and you need to travel to Seattle and find out who did it. There are some serious twists and turns as you dig deeper into this world, trying to uncover who did it.Dragonfall is leap and bounds ahead of Dead mans Switch. The graphics feel tighter, but there is no real change. Some of the sounds and combat has been tweaked a bit and the save anywhere anytime button is a lifesaver. The supporting characters feel a lot more real, and can be interacted with anytime. They have backgrounds and lives, and aren't afarid to give you a piece of their minds if they think your doing something wrong.In the newest 'dlc' you get a whole new campgain, set up for a new character but thanks to some dedicated players you can import your character over to this save file to run the DLC. Your out on a run with long time friend Monica and her crew in Berlin. Its a simple job, a smash and grab type. However things aren't always as they seem... Monica ends up dead and you and the crew end up fleeing for your lives. With Monica dead there is a seat to be filled in the community where she lived, and her crew wants revenge. Will you be the vengeful angel and the savior all in one package?

Posted: July 9, 2014
												Overview:Pros:-	2D environments and portraits-	Interesting characters-	great writing-	refreshing setting-	diverse skill systemCons:-	3D effects-	linear story-	story goes a little off the rail in the final act-	endgame fights (enemies appear out of nowhere, required party members)RPGs are my favorite genre. Nevertheless I didn’t enjoy recent RPGs like I used to. Yes, they might have great graphics, good gameplay mechanics or a well-crafted skill system, but the one aspect I find them lacking is the storytelling. Shadowrun Returns is an exception.Before I start getting into the details, I have to say I watched several gameplay and review videos before I picked it up. To be honest – I wasn’t impressed. Even though the hand-crafted 2D environments are gorgeous and vivid, the character models as well as the visual effects are far from impressive. Nevertheless, I gave it a shot and I wasn’t disappointed.The Shadowrun universe combines Cyberpunk aspects with the return of magic and metahumans in a futuristic world. The player slips into the role of a shadowrunner, an operative who will steal, infiltrate, hack and kidnap for the right price. The protagonist has to deal with powerful corporations, corruption, mythical creatures and fellow shadowrunners to survive.When it comes to creating a character that is your own, Shadowrun excels. You can choose between five races you might find in a fantasy RPG (human, elf, dwarf, ork, troll), which feel quite fresh in this unfamiliar setting. Your character can choose from six pre-made classes:-	Street Samurai: become a gun-wielding or close-range killing machine-	Mage: Fireballs, buffs and Debuffs. The familiar choice.-	Decker: jack into the Matrix to fight security systems with your programs-	Rigger: use small drones to support your team or deal damage-	Shaman: use totems or summon spirits to defeat your enemies-	Adept: use magic to enhance your own abilities, making yourself a weaponFurthermore you can also start from scratch and spend Karma points and create your own experience. Technoshaman? Combat Decker? Everything is possible, as long as you don’t spread the Karma points too thin. Skill checks are quite common in dialogue options and spending some points in Charisma or Intelligence can be worthwhile.The inventory system is quite rudimentary. Characters wear an outfit and can carry up to three weapons. Everyone can carry up to six consumables and Magic users as well as Deckers have a spellbook with up to six slots. To further improve skills or stats, cyberware can be implanted. However this results in increased cooldowns for spells.The gameplay revolves around a team of up to 4 shadowrunners. During the majority of the game you can hire a team and choose them depending on your group dynamics. Or your cash on hand, since shadowrunners don’t work for free. The combat system is round-based and reminds of Fallout 1 & 2. Action points have to be spend wisely to move, attack or use consumables like medkits and grenades.You have to read! Where many games try to tell their stories with cutscenes and voice acting, Shadowrun Returns presents the story with superb writing. Whenever you travel to a new location or meet a character the situation is beautifully described before you have to worry about combat or dialogue choices. Combined with vibrant character portraits, the characters you encounter feel alive.The different races and classes offer replayability. My first playthrough (normal, Human Decker) took 9+ hours. Due to the familiarity with enemy placement and linear storyline, my second run (very hard, Dwarf Mage) took a little over five hours. I can see myself coming back to try out different classes, however for now I’m enjoying the Dragonfall DLC (very hard, Troll Adept).I would highly recommend this game to players who enjoy round-based RPGs, which concentrate on storytelling.

Posted: August 29, 2015
												A tale of two halves.The first half is a basic-yet-intriguing cyberpunk XCOM-lite game. The second is a tedious, monotonous, dragged-out affair that completely spoils everything and made me very glad it was only $2.50 when I picked it up.PROS-Crisp art style that lends itself fairly well to the setting-Some interesting characters (kind of)-The music is decent the first time around-Neat outfits-It's less than ten hours....CONS-Environments/levels are 99% static and lifeless-The dialogue/script is wildly inconsistent in terms of style, going from grandiose to vernacular at will. It's like two or three different guys were writing without consulting the design document. Then at the end they were just like "♥♥♥♥ it, too hard to redo all this work"-After a couple hours, the music grates-Combat is far too simple to be enjoyable for long-Lack of cool loot/drops-Exceedingly linear-Most characters are neat at first but then it becomes obvious there's no depth-The narrative takes a wild shift in the second half, and it's not for the betterment of the game-The second half is only more difficult because gobs of enemies are thrown at you, rather than anything clever or original-Puzzles can all be solved by holding down Alt to see what few things are interactive-Terrible ending that made me uninstall immediately after closing the game-Along with the tonal shifts, most of the scant humor isn't funny, and the cyberpunk/Shadowrun terms were used in a tryharding manner rather than making sense or adding atmosphere-Lots of typos and generally-lazy writing-Decking is uselessly dullOverall it's a game that starts out strong and finishes way after boredom sets in. The combat is stale with little-to-no tactical depth, and level design is so narrow-sighted and basic that I can't help but think these guys are out of their league. And this is from someone who views cyberpunk as the best genre in all of media.

Posted: May 4, 2014
												I cannot put into words how much I love this game. There really are not enough good RPGs out there nowadays, this is an example, something to measure any RPGs by. Shadowrun is unique in many ways, most good. But before I start my big parade on how amazing this game is, let's look at the negatives. There is no adjustable difficulty setting, which I think is a plus but most look at as a bad. It can be repetitive, and sometimes a little bit clunky and unresponsive, but this factors don't occur often, I mean it is and RPG so you will be doing somethings more than you'd like to. And now the positives, there's a lot. This game is old school, in difficulty, its isometric layout and dialogue etc. The game has no speaking, so there is a bit of reading. Characters are memorable, and the fight system is superb. Choosing your crew is essential to living long enough to get paid, and you really feel like the little things you do actually will matter at some later point, and they mostly do. I love it so much, and I think it has set a new standard for its genre.

Posted: April 3, 2014
												ahhhhhh, sitting back with a glass of 15 year glenlivet and a pipe in your man chair. It's hard to find a more refreshing and manlier past time....oh wait, what is this? Cyberpunk infused with a refreshing take on fantasy? In an Isometric rpg using hand crafted maps with a unique art style? I have a game to play, enough of this manly lounging about!tl;dr;  Overall 7/10. Worth the cash if your gaming plate is empty and, you want a fun rpg with decent story telling and stunning, unique, art direction and  visuals to sit back and relax with.-hardcore rpgs fans will find the Dev's campaigns lacking rpg-ness in areas-those who want the best parts of the campign will have to pay $30 for the toolset and dragonfall -it missed its calling -> it needs networking/co-op support so it can be used as a pnp campaign tool for shadowrunners. In my opinion, with these expansions added on this tool would be hands down the best way to run a pnp shadowrun campaign with friends.Shadowrun plays as a mix between old school isometric rpgs such as baldurs gate and uses a combat system similar to the new Xcom by Firaxis. Unfortunatey though the first campagin is...lacking. While a fun play through and introduction to the universe, it is necessary to buy the dragonfall campaign to truly see what this framework is capable of. However, hardcore Isometric rpg fans will find this game lacking. Side quests are few and far between, you have no control over how your npc companions (depending upon the campaign by harebrained) level up, and a general lack of freedom in what should be a more open world experience. However, the game is primarily designed for being a tool that players use to build their own campaigns. Sadly though, this shouldn't have to be a substitute for harebrain's lack of campaign building talent. The game also needs co-op, just hear me out. This is turn based game, based upon a pen a paper rpg, with focus on building a single character for a player with full stats/"classes", with tools to build your own campaigns and maps. While entertaining to experience in single player, and as cool as the build your own rpg framework is, it missed its calling. This is a tool that could be expanded to actually run a pen and paper campaigns! There are things like roll20.net but lets be honest, the visual tools and dice support are lacking for odd ball rpgs like Shadowrun (huge lack of cyberpunk visuals like tiles/characters/creatures and a lot of custom equation building required to get it running properly). Adding networking/co-op would allow a savvy dm to build their own maps/campaigns and run a pnp rpg with visual support and a set rule framework for combat! (seriously, the art direction is gorgeous and no need to worry about that "one player" cheating their stats or rule loop holes).Overall, for the price ($30 if you buy all the dev built campaigns) it's worth the money. The 2 campaign  stories are fun, the lenghts of the stories are good, the changes in Dragonfall are proof that harebrained is listening to the community to improve upon their stories, tool upgrades, and improving rpg elements in their own work. There are a few bugs/optimizations that need to be sorted out but, I also need to upgrade my pc (really badly) so I'd like to hear how those with beefier rigs hold up. (I'm pretty sure the issues I ran into were due to the HD graphics straining my rig at high resolutions).

Posted: May 9, 2014
												This game, this game is one of the few titles I can name that truly inspires my mind to delve depths unimaginable the setting is superb, the lore rich and thick and let's not forget the beautiful controls and gameplay all in all I would say this title is one of my absolute favorites, but let's talk about why.First off the setting is one of the, if not the most beautifully crafted settings to grace the games industry the world feels alive and full of character and emotion as though it is dripping pure atmosphere and spawning true intrigue this is because it is built off of an amazing title already being part of the deep and wonderful world of Shadowrun making it one of the best modern iterations of a classic game series I have ever had the pleasure to step into.Now let's saunter on over to the lore of the game, which is built upon the original Pen and Paper title and the superb yet confusing NES and Genesis title, not to spoil anything too major but the entire world has been changed massively by an event called the awakening and yea, you know what just go read up on everything else.The gameplay is another area I want to cover as the game plays like an Turn Based Roleplaying Game, now the game comes with one preinstalled mission which is actually quite huge but there are a lot of player made missions on sites like NexusMods and even on the workshop itself add on the beautiful levelling system which stops you becoming extremely over powered early and you have fantastic gameplay.But I don't think the game is one hundred percent perfect, the preinstalled story called Dead Mans Switch, unfortunately feels undercooked and doesn't pull off the gritty superb story I expected in short your friend is killed and he hires you post death to find and kill the drek that killed him, I'm not gonna spoil anything but I thought the end villain was weak and uninteresting when they could've done something great with an established character from the beginning.I also shouldn't forget the DLC Dragonfall which in and of itself adds much more to the world and is it's own excellent piece of content adding new characters and more awesome story development.to test my new scoring system I give this 4 stars or a That's Grand LadLook forward to more reviews that hopefully don't sound too pretentious or crap

Posted: July 5, 2014
												Almost a perfect title.First off, the focus on the editor and the "module" approach to the campaign made me think of neverwinter nights (the first one). The fact that the game focused on being highly expandable and customizable made me more forgiving of the campaign's shortcomings.That being said, the game's pretty good, but still lacking. Some of it in terms of interface, some in terms of design (gameplay). Please note, I played on normal difficulty. The storyline is quaint, the visuals are detailed, and flow overall is smooth and enjoyable.1) With all the awesome artwork, the protagonist visuals were extremely boring, whatever look I had in mind for my hero was nowhere to be found in the portrait collection. I just gave up in the end and went with a whatever-approach.2) The chapter oriented campaign moves the story along nicely, but the linearity(sp?) of the game was disappointing, if you didn't manage your resources well, it's gone. This includes karma (xp).3) Moving around when there's no (immediate) combat in combat mode is a chore.4) Too many illusionary dialogue choices. Great, but acknowledging it was also an acknowledgement of it's extremely linear gameplay design (like combat, progression, resource allocation and game balance).Ultimately, I think if they fixed a few things, this title would have a been a true A+, and fans would be clamoring for a sequel like crazy. Unfortunately, in it's current state, it's a great experiment to the throwback that is the shadowrun RPG, but that's all.Maybe some mods would've helped, but the online presence for the game wasn't really there like other games neither. Hopefully they'll come out with some improvements in due time, if not a sequel.

Posted: July 27, 2014
												Stephenson meets Tolkien in the world of Shadowrun, and it works surprisingly well. I wasn't massively familiar with the PnP RPG roots of Shadowrun before I bought the game, but having completed the Dead Man's Switch campaign, I'd definitely like to know a lot more about it. Cyberpunk dwarves and elves might not be everyone's cup of tea, but if you can buy into the principle, there's a lot of depth to be found in the game lore and the mechanics of the game. The character classes are distinct enough to make the game replayable (though making sure you have three levels put into Rifle is pretty much compulsory if you want to get the best out of the combat) and the setting is well realised and nicely polished. One thing it's not is a cyberpunk Baldur's Gate, as the story does run on rails (and is easily dispensed with in around 10-12 hours), so there's no sense that you can just make your way in the world on your own and just discover what there is out there, but that said, the characters are nicely written (I especially like Coyote, Cherry Bomb, Harlequin and Dresden) and easy to invest emotionally in. Definitely worth picking up if you fancy a little old school isometric RPG action, and the mod scene should keep the game fresh for a long time to come.

Posted: August 3, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns (7/10)Just played through the main campaign (Dead man's Switch). Never got into the whole P&P shadowrun thing before, but snapped this and the DLC up during the Steam summer sale, and have to say overall I'm rather impressed, albeit I wasn't expecting much. Although it heavily treads the usual Cyberpunk tropes, the mix of races adds something to matters and although I generally relied on hacking and hardware to push through the storyline the magical aspects enhanced the experience to some degree. Play wise it's not long. I took a fancy to playing it yesterday early afternoon and wrapped it up earlier this morning, with a good nights sleep in between (10 hours tops by my reckoning). My main criticism of the principal campaign would really be the near linearity of it. You're basically pushed from pillar to post with very little in the way of deviation or side quests and that pacing felt off given in large part that the beginning of the campaign is an investigation. I wanted to be able to explore Seattle, but the opportunity never really arises versus being pulled by the main narrative.The game also suffers a bit when it comes to equipment. The upgrade path essentially consists of buying a better X versus any degree of customization and although there are various chem tonics you can take to temporarily boost a characters abilities I never felt the need to sacrifice an equipment slot for one, versus using it to carry a med pack instead. The combat is very much in the mould of X-Com, but for reasons unexplained even when all the enemies in a level have been defeated you're often seemingly forced to continue to use the point system to get around, which can get rather tedious at times, though thankfully the levels aren't generally too sprawling. In large part I didn't find the combat too troubling on normal, though towards the end the enemy difficulty does ramp up (a resultant of the narrative) and a bit more thought is required in order to effectively combat some of the threats. Where the game shines most is in the writing, which manages to give you some flexibility in terms of how you 'play' your character tonally. Although I suspect your choices likely don't have any impact in terms of options, it's nice to have that flexibility.

Posted: August 13, 2013
												Great game for fans of old school RPG at a great price. If you've read Neuromancer; and loved it, if you've spent countless hours playing Baldur's Gate or older Fallout titles; and couldn't tear yourself away from them, this is a game for you.And once you're done with original campaign, quality user generated content awaits you on Steam Workshop and 3rd party sites like Shadowrun Nexus. Modders are so ambitious that they are recreating whole Shadowrun sourcebooks. So, come on, join us in the shadows, chummer.Shadowrun Dragonfall: I know they are marketing this as merely DLC, but DLC this is not. It is a full blown, old fashioned expansion pack. Dragonfall packs a bigger campaign, set in the anarchy ridden Berlin of 2054, otherwise known as the Flux State.HBS has listened to fans and addressed all the major issues from the original game. Saving your game anywhere? Check! More interesting companions with actual personalities and backstory? Yes, sir! Side missions? Of course! This time around you are not led by the hand. You get a hub, certain Berlin neighborhood, where you can choose your missions, even reject them if Mr. Johnson offering it isn't on the level. You can chat with the (meta)humans living there. Solve their problems. Learn of their past, and they all have some very shady skeletons in the closet. Let's face it, only people running from something come to the F-State...and corporations. But the latter are a different story altogether. Runs themselves have been improved considerably. There are multiple solutions to every problem and some tough choices to be made in practically every one. Enemy encounters have been improved. Combat is more enjoyable, overall. Non-combat skills feature more prominently. Skills and etiquette checks are very frequent. You can go in guns, fists, blades and magic blazing. But you can also do things covertly. It's all up to you.Writing in this game is great. Story takes hold of you, is full of twist and turns, and won't let you go 'till the end. By that time, you'll crave more. Speaking of length, you'll get at least twenty hours out of the game. Even more, if you play on harder difficulties, want to speak to everyone and see everything.Dragonfall is the definitive reason to pick up the original game. If you're into old school RPGs, cyberpunk, and value a good story, you won't be disappointed with this game.

Posted: September 4, 2015
Dead Man's SwitchShadowrun Returns. Indeed it has... this intriguing isometric RPG is a great combat system wrapped in a rollicking mystery that although has a few stumbling points, it is very much worth your time. Returns comes with a built-in campaign that will last you 10-12 hours if you take your time, and with plenty of mods in the community to keep it fresh. GameplayShadowrun Returns has a basic isometric movement system, just click where you want to go/interact with. It's when you get into the easy-to-learn combat system that the game really opens up. You can create your Runner to be a Sorcerer, a Drone-using mastermind, or just a guy with a shotgun that shoots people in the face. The RPG system is good, not overly complicated, and has good conversation trees that can be affected with different levels of Charisma. You can even role-play what type of things your character is knowledgable in. Overall, the gameplay of Shadowrun Returns is slick and stellar. StoryShadowrun Returns has a story that doesn't quite work on the empathy stakes... there's no reason really to care for any of the characters you meet, and some of the Runners you can hire are simply generic. If they die, it's just a *shrug* and leave them behind. However, the actual mystery behind the game and what's going on I found to be motivating enough... although it starts off slow, you want to meet the 'Ripper' until you actually stop playing the game- though after you've met him, things really start to get interesting... Graphics, Atmosphere, and SoundThe graphics of Shadowrun are servicable; sure, they won't dazzle you, but they aren't bad either. It has a nice art-style to make the world come to life, and the character portraits help give you first impressions of the characters, as well as the information that comes through text-wise.The atmosphere is great, with dank hotels and rain-drenched streets beckoning your Runner on. The characters are as fleshed out as you can get in a 'short' campaign as the Dead Man's Switch, but personally, I won't miss any of them. The music quality in this game is impeccable. If you are a fan of electronic music, you won't regret listening to the tracks that are on offer here. 'Double Cross' is my personal favorite track. The additional sounds of guns and sorcery that permeate the air whilst fighting adds to the atmosphere. ConclusionShadowrun Returns, A Dead Man's Switch, is a joy to play, and although the story has a few hiccups and the companion system leaves a lot to be desired, the game is overall a solid reccomendation. Worth your time indeed. Ready to deck into the system?

Posted: July 28, 2013
												This game is absolutely great from top to bottom. The main game is a well written and well paced piece of murder mystery cyberpunk action, made with great writing and interesting characters. The writing is so good, in fact, that even characters that show up just once or twice feel really memorable. The graphic style and musical design are top notch and really help make the experience into a cohesive whole. The gameplay is a solid tactical RPG experience that's fun to play, if a bit on the easy side more often than not. The few downsides to the game start with the lack of manual saving. The game automatically saves at checkpoints (probably to prevent save scumming like some other tactical games) which can sometimes be frustrating. The locked angle camera usually is okay, but there are times where it's a problem. Some people will call a 12 hour, very linear main campaign a problem too, but I personally think that it's better to have 12 high-quality hours than 20-25 with lots of filler. So it's not perfect, but it's damned well done. And the inclusion of an editor means that in the end we'll hopefully see a lot more great content from the community.

Posted: November 13, 2015
												While I like this game a lot, others may not, depending on what they're expecting.If you are expecting any edition of the tabletop role-playing game, or the Genesis or SNES console games, you will be disappointed.  Shadowrun: Returns plays something like a simplified version of tabletop rules that never actually existed.I liked the plot, combat, and music.Opinions on the plot vary widely.  If you have an aversion to reading, this game is not for you.  Almost all of the plot is delivered via screens of text upon entering an area, or text dialogs.  There is no voiceover.  Some people complain of purple prose, or that it seems to have been written by someone that is immature, but the writing is superior to that in most video games, including most other RPGs.  I personally do not perceive any of these problems, and have never seen examples cited.Screenshots do not do the combat system justice.  Some of the interface is only displayed when it is relevant.  For example, the action point cost of movement, and the effectiveness of cover, only appear when you prepare to move, and when cover exists in the area you mouseover.  The combat system is relatively simple (which is reflected in the user interface), but like Chess, can be quite difficult.  The difficulty is selectable at character creation, so if you find the game too easy or hard you can adjust it.  Since almost all RPGs are combat-heavy, it's important that it not be mindless and repetitive.The music is hard to describe.  It is not ambient.  You will notice it.  I especially like the theme on the title screen.I didn't like some things about Shadowrun: Returns.It is very linear, and most decisions will not affect the ending.The gameplay in the matrix is very similar to meatspace.  It's not so much that the gameplay in the matrix is bad as it doesn't feel different enough.The game only saves on area transition.  If you have to stop playing, or die, unexpectedly, you can lose quite a bit of progress.

Posted: October 17, 2015
												As someone who's never played Shadowrun previously, I'm pretty happy with the system mechanics and how the story folds out. I played it on Very Hard difficulty, which didn't actually seem all too difficult (if anything, I felt like my team missed their attacks more often than they should have). This is also based on the Dead Man's Switch campaign, which comes with the game.I customized my character originally as a Rigger, focusing on Drone Control, with a few levels in Pistols. I later added Decking to my skills, keeping its levels even with my Drones, and it seemed to work out very successfully, in that I never felt that my character was over-reliant on my companions other than for additional damage output.The game does have a couple of bugs in some places: the first major one I noticed was when I bought level 2 Decker abilities, where they did not show up in my inventory/stash at all after I bought them. I had to trust the game actually did register that I possessed them, as they were also absent from the store (which is normal if you already had it), and later on in the game, when level 3 Decker abilities were made available, the behavior seemed to correct itself.The other major bug I found was in the room for the final battle (I'll try not to be spoilery). There are pieces in the room which are either active or inactive, and to keep the battle more manageable, you want to keep all of them inactive as much as possible. However, there were a few instances where I couldn't actually target an active piece (quicksave/loading fixed this), and a few times where a piece appeared inactive, but I knew based on enemy behavior in the battle that it was actually active.

Posted: March 16, 2014
												Shadowrun. I picked up the Pen and Paper RPG when I was younger. Sadly it took years before finding a group to play it. Luckly around my University years I found a decent group of people and we are gaming since than. I am an hardcore fan so probably my Review could be a bit biased. Frist of all I strongly suggest to read a bit before gaming. Just the "Primer" which is a small guide\introduction to the World of Shadowrun available from the site Shadowrun Universe (official site for all things related to Shadowrun). Once you have the Primer you can have a good idea of what to expect from the Setting. I know that at a frist glance it looks strange maybe even too much but trust me it is awesome. The more you will dig the better it will get, specially if you start to read the various RPG manuals and novels. If you liked the setting buy this game. The basic Campaign included in Shadowrun Returns is a classic. If you never rped or played Shadowrun (I am mostly referring to SNES and GENESIS Games) this is a wonderfull start. The narration is set in 2050s which is a very cool period for Shadowrun (keep in mind that in the current RP Setting the time is around 2075) and it is based on some of the hottest plots of that period. The game is a basic Turn Based Combat with RP elements in the form of dialogues where the various options depends on which skill you have. Back when it was just published the Game lacked few things like save anywhere option. Luckly this was fixed up in the 1st DLC Dragonfall. Dragonfall is even better than the basic game. The Devs listened to us Players and fixed few things and I dare to say even took inspiration from some of UGC - User generated Content (More of this later). Dragonfall can look a bit boring at the start with the logic of "Do a Run, get back and run again" (Run is a work, a mission in Shadowrun) but the Narration, the Plot goes always up till its end. In Dragonfall I was not impressed by the first Runs but nearby the end I could not stop to see how this Story was going to end. The only negative side of both Shadowrun Returns and Dragonfall is that you can not manage your NPCs. You can select who can help you in a Run but you do not have any kind of control on their Skills and how they improve. Probably this will be fixed in future DLCs. If the basic game and the DLC are not enough there are UGCs. Shadowrun Community is very active and Devs select from time to time some UCG to play just to show up how much it is good. There are a lot of good Artist out there who are working on big UCG like remakes of SNES and Genesis Shadowrun Games. I strongly suggest to take a loot at "Shadowrun Unlimited". I hope all of this makes sense. In any case, if you start to play and dig into the Shadows of Shadowrun remember: "Shoot straight, conserve your ammo and never make a deal with a Dragon".

Posted: July 2, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is an adaptation of the classic cyberpunk tabletop pen and paper RPG. Set in an alternative history future where magic has returned to the world, elves, dwarves, trolls, and orks live side by side with humans in dense urban cities, and corporations are a law unto themselves; the game centers around the segment of humanity who makes their living in the shadows, the runners. Hacker, mercenary, detective, sorcerer, where there is a job that needs doing, there will be someone willing to get paid to do it.The game itself is a single player, turn-based strategy RPG, utilizing 3/4 isometric perspective with 3D character models set against sprite based backgrounds. The sprite backgrounds are static and well done, while the character designs are somewhat poorly textured with resolution below that which the majority of modern systems could easily handle; belying the limited budget the company had to work with. Gameplay takes the form of point and click interaction with the world map and carries over directly into combat, utilizing the same environments. Combat is somewhat klunky, as there are problems with the interaction of the courser and corners of the movement field.The game itself is, however, merely a platform. It is in reality intended for players to build and share their own Shadowrun campaigns, and the full game editor comes included with the base game as well as a professionally developed campaign. Thanks to Steam Works, player campaigns are free, though professionally developed campaigns will be sold as DLC as they become available. Sadly there is no multiplayer option what-so-ever, crippling one of the intregral elements of the pen-and-paper game.Overall, the game's campaign will run you around 12 hours, and is a good buy if you can get it on sale, for any enthusiast of turn-based strategy RPGs.
