Posted: March 1, 2014
												The Dragonfall expansion single-handedly did justice to Shadowrun Returns. The Dragonfall campaign build brings a much more involving and intricate storyline, choices, side-missions and memorable NPC companions, resulting in longer gameplay and satisfaction compared to the 12-hour long original. There were certain tweaks to the mechanics of the core game, it seems. For example, there will no longer be extra action points garnered from cybernetics, but this is compensated for via game balancing. There are new portraits to choose from (though still quite limited visual customization) but no changes to the skill trees. Games can be saved at almost every point of the game now, not just at savepoints, so that's another step forward. There are new music scores with this campaign, and they all set the mood satisfactorily for the throughout the gameplay. I still find the beats from the original campaign more to my liking, but that's personal opinion. Some issues inherent in the original was still present in this one. Missing sprites, limitations to allocating picked-up items to teammates outside of combat and the occassional AP bug can still be encountered. However, I would not personally hold this against the expansion as this one is does seem like the developer's turn of churning out an AAA campaign using the same builder tools made available to the community. I grew up playing and loving role-playing games that were akin to reading sci-fi fantasy book sets. After Baldur's Gate, Planescape: Torment, Arcanum and Neverwinter Nights, I am relieved to be able to add Shadowrun Returns into my collection of RPG games worth the ages. To enjoy this one, you'll have to read, children, and dig into your storeroom for that old thing called an 'active imagination'. If Shadowrun Returns left you feeling wanting, then Dragonfall will bring you past dessert.

Posted: February 18, 2014
												Excellent! Loved it!There is no free roaming - this game is on rails.  It's more like an interactive William Gibson novel than Fallout Tactics.But it's the writing that really stands out,  that and the the RPG setting.  After playing this, I think if i ever did pen and paper again I'd like to try Shadowrun.  It reminds me a lot of Traveller (all-time favorite pen and paper RPG) in some respects.The music is good and fits the game well.The art is unique - be sure to zoom in occasionally to check out the details.In some of the levels, you will have a character jacked into the matrix and running alone,  while the rest of the team defends the access point (and the helpless cybernaut).  The game does a good job of creating a genuine feeling of urgency in these situations.Save points:  the game saves for you.  if you screw up a level you have to play it over again.  Did not care for this.I did not find it possible while on a mission to drop out of combat (when no enemies were visible) to move easier -  either i just never figured out how,  or it's not possible.  It should be automatic.  Did not care for this.I found the early game fights weak & easy.  Later scenarios were more difficult.Many reviews I have read lamented that the game is too short.  If you were expecting an open world roamer,  it is -  but if you are expecting a good novel,  it's not.   And ultimately, i think that's what this game is - a good novel.Speaking of good novel,  i found after playing  - being curious about some of the characters -  that i had met a very famous (in the milleu) dragon,  and an immortal - both subtly and (believe it or not) *realistically* portrayed.  another example of good writing.More side quests and missions would have been nice -  but it would have detracted from coherence.If you like cyberpunk novels, or gritty film noir,    you'll probably like this game.   I picked it up on sale for ~7.00$  and it's Definitely worth that.

Posted: December 31, 2013
												A pretty good game and a blast from the past in terms of style. Its got an interesting world and characters. The main campaign feels very much like the one from Neverwinter Nights - a holdover until the community builds content via the editor. The AI is a little weak; the game relies on overwhelming you with bad guys which is a bit annoying but overall combat is really interesting. It's sort of a cross between Advance Wars on the Gameboy and the freeware game Battle of Wesnoth. Improvements for the future could be a party system that allows you to customise a team of 4. That would be a great addition.

Posted: July 27, 2013
												For years now I've considered old-school isometric genres to be 'my' genre. That is to say, the one that strictly caters to my sensibilities as a player. I discovered them well after their golden age, and since this wave of kickstarted CRPGs began I've been eagerly awaiting their results.As the first one out of the gate from this batch, Shadowrun Returns does not disappoint. If you're like me and you've been aching for a deep and immersive roleplaying experience and actual agency when it comes to solving problems, this game is a steal at $20. Excellent writing, beautiful environments, and a fantastic soundtrack all tied together with engaging combat and character progression.The campaign will take you about 15 hours to run through, and there's sadly little in the way of extended diversions, and the game is rather linear in how it progresses. There's not much of a sense of an 'open world' that one would expect from this genre, but even still the world itself is one of the most well-realized and vibrant ones I've seen in a long time.They've got another campaign on the way, and you're going to see plenty of gameplay content coming out of the steam workshop, so I can guarantee you'll have your money's worth in actual meaty game.If you like RPGs at all you owe it to yourself to grab this game and play through it. You'll be really glad you did.

												Well,this game may be little simlistic in game mechanics, thin in side quests and second half of story is yet-another-hero-saves-the-world, but in the way of decriptive an literal writing there are some glimpses of classics like Planetscape Torment (of course PT is much more poetic than Shadowrun). Posted: June 25, 2014
												OK, I've been playing for a couple hours, and I was hesitant to buy this game because of the reviews. But I like Shadowrun lore and ambiance, so I gave it a shot. I played Shadowrun when it came out for SNES.Now: I would cathegorize this game as an "interaction novel". Most of the players wanted a sandbox or at least some freedom, but this is no game for that. This game tells a story where you are involved in. There are some RPG aspects like leveling and building your character, but that is not the core of the game (I think).If you are looking for a short sci-fi story you can play, then go ahead, I recommend this game. If you are a Shadowrun stories fan, then you should give it a try too. If you are looking for an action game, a sandbox or a game where you can choose where to go, then this is not a game for you. It has click adventure parts, it has tactical turn-based parts, but the core is the story. Some player have said the story is sh$%#". For me it is working, so far.CheersEdit: If you are looking for turn based strategy game or you are not into Shadowrun lore, go for XCOM: enemy unknown and within

Posted: June 25, 2014
												Welcome to Seattle.  Whether you are a human, ork, troll, elf or dwarf; gather up your PDA, DataJack and other 90s-future techology.  Emerse yourself in the dystopia world of megacorps and shadowrunners.  Forget about Starbucks.  Put on your Doc Martins, flannel shirt and the dusty old Pearl Jam CD. Posted: June 25, 2014
												Worth buying for the writing alone. Posted: June 28, 2014
												This game is quite the nostalgia trip. They really nailed the look and feel of gritty ol' Seattle of 2054, and the music is just stellar. It's an old view of the future, played in the old ways of RPGs. That means lots of turn-based combat and lots of reading. LOTS of reading. The story is nothing stellar -- what Shadowrun fiction ever is -- but it's a fun return to familiar territory. I haven't dug into the user-generated stuff, but the main campaign is easily worth the asking price if you have any love of cyberpunk.That said, if you buy this, then I highly recommend picking up the Dragonfall expansion as well. It's storyline is much, much better.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												Gameplay is topnotch Tactical RPG stuff. Its fun to make your character however you'd like them, and the skills are laid out in a straightforward way. Spell variety leaves a little bit left to be desired, and I personally wouldve liked greater variety for implants, but is all in all very solid. Storyline for the default game, called "The Deadman's Switch" is boring and linear, and you dont spend a long enough amount of downtime to talk to and connect with your party members. Also playing a decker is a waste of time as theres very few times you actually get to enter the Matrix. Hold your hand too much and feels shallow because of itThe DLC, Dragonfall, fixes the above problems. It starts a bit linear just like before, but theres multiple ways to clear any area, as well as plenty of time between missions to talk with your fellow Shadowrunners. The plot is much more interesting and there are more ways to use your character's skills, both in the field, and in dialogue choices. The game opens up and you get to start taking missions of your own accord, with each having a small storyline within its own mission.Theres also a metric crapton of great workshop content out for the game, which I think will add tremendously to the games longevity.Bottomline, buy this game, and buy it with the DLC.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												It's not particularly elegant, nor is it going to bring in any fans who aren't already down with Shadowrun...but damn if this isn't what all of us fans have been waiting for.  An honest, interesting, and close look at the Shadowrun universe and the tools to tell our own stories and make our own content.  Amazing work from Harebrained.  For the price, I can't see why you wouldn't at least try it.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												The core campaign here, Dead Man's Switch, is awful.  It serves as an introduction to the mechanics and, to a much lesser extent, the setting of Shadowrun.  The DLC/expansion Dragonfall, however, is absolutely fantastic, and is completely unrelated to the core campaign.  It's one of the better written RPGs I've ever played.  The characters are great, the story is interesting, the decisions are difficult, and although the "epilogue" is a little weak, the overall ending was solid.  I heartily recommend Dragonfall to any RPG enthusiast and especially to anyone who has ever been curious to explore the Shadowrun setting.

Posted: March 27, 2014
												I didn't play the original Shadowrun back in the early nineties, so the game gets no retro love in this review. Shadowrun returns is a average cyberpunk and magic theme RPG. The main defect in the game is the vacuity of the gameworld comprised of the different interconnected areas. The game basically gives you only plot items to interact and the city locations are small. True to the "pocket world" RPG approach the plot is your average RPG pipeline stuff. Shadowrun Returns also lacks the intricate background stories for NPCs that most RPGs have, but this aspect of team interaction is added in the Dragonfall DLC. Dragonfall also does everything a little bit better, passing of as a relatively good RPG. It takes maybe 15-18 hours to complete Dragonfall if you're a completionist and about 20h for the main game. Since there's lots of combat, which is not that great, the game in my opinion is somwhat lacking in replay value. Though the end game of Dragonfall does play differently depending on few key choices, you're not inclined to mow through the same combat laden missions again.

Posted: June 23, 2014
												Graphics - 4/5A fantastic pre-rendered world that looks fantastic almost everywhere. There are some flickering issues in some areas and some of the larger creatures aren't high resolution friendly.Sound - 3/5Nothing incredibly memorable, BUT, it is absolutely perfect for the setting and really sets the mood of this bleak futuristic world.Gameplay - 5/5Best tactical RPG I've ever played. You can make whatever kind of character you want. My character used nothing but his fists and knuckle weapons and he ended up being a badass knocking security bots out with a single punch. The combat itself is awesome, fast paced and controls really well. One thing that I noticed though was I feel like the percentages are a little off for the accuracy ratings, I feel like I've rarely hit anything lower than 60 percent.Story - 4.5/5This is a review of the Dragonfall story. You follow a group of shadowrunners led by your character, and the game really makes you familiar with everyone. All species of sentient beings have their own ways of speaking and there are very little stereotypical characters. Strong female leads, strong male leads, and all around strong side characters. Dead Man's Switch overplayed the in world slang a little bit too much, but Dragonfall made it very easy to get what certain words mean.Overall: 4/5

Posted: May 10, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is a game I find hard to give excessive praise, but it's a game that I also find hard to dislike. When it comes down to it, it's a completely solid game, even if it's shallow. Nevertheless, I enjoyed it and feel fully satisfied with the experience, and I didn't have any trouble playing all the way through. There are certainly some notable flaws, however.Let's start with the story, since this game relies heavily on it's writing to motivate the player. The writing and characterization is good, I felt very absorbed in the universe, but the story itself is fairly lacking. It's a shame as well, it starts out great. You got a murder mystery with a lot of interesting faces dying to be talked to, with a few twists and turns here and there. The problem is that it just doesn't developed. It feels extremely rushed. The characters are lovable and relatable to the very end, but I started skipping through dialogue that dealt with the actual plot about 2/3rds through the game. It escalates in a comical direction, with an extremely weak and one-dimensional villian. It's extremely predictable, and just plain boring. The last stretch is so typical and lackluster that I had little to no investment in the actual plight, I just wanted to see if the characters would drop some more interesting backstory about themselves. It gave me closure, but it's not memorable at all. It's just too bad, the beginning was really good, but the plot started going so fast in such a linear direction that it forgot to flesh itself out, leaving some questions unanswered and plot points underdeveloped. It got the job done, but I was hoping for more.Where the game really shines are the characters and their own personal issues. Almost all the staple characters have their own personal motives and vendettas, and I was interested in all their stories. I enjoyed going back to base and talking to every single one of them that were willing to open their mouths. The game does a fantastic job of setting up this belonging feeling, that you're part of this organization of runners. Although, as I stated before, as the game escalates it leaves behind this deep characterization in order to fawn over its own hilariously absurd and out-of-place world-threatening dilemma.The combat is serviceable. It's ultimately shallow and linear, there isn't a lot of variation or depth, and there are some balance issues. But it's still fun, you get to characterize some characters simply by their fighting styles. It's too easy as well, but not game-ruiningly so. It's fun, if you really like X-COM-like turn based combat, you'll probably enjoy it if you can stand it being a tad shallow.The game is overall fun, I would recommend it. It doesn't really have any offending flaws, it just doesn't quite reach the large potential it could've. It's not particularly memorable, but it's enjoyable. I would wait for a sale, but when the price is suitable to you, I'd say to go for it just to get immersed in the world.

												A good old school RPG with tactical battle. True (as much as it can) to the univers of Shadowrun (cyperpunk). Sadly the game is very short - which mean not a lot of different skills & weapons, and it don't take full oportunity of the wonder that is the matrix.To really enjoy the game, you're going to have to use the mods and campaigns created by other players - or create them yourself !In short : good game, worth it's price (especially if you play mods), but the main campaign fail to use the game mechanisms to its fullest.

												The game story and mechanics seems rushed however, the graphics were quite nice and a little too "fluffy" for this style of game.  The music, not a fan, it still lingers in my head after the game crashes or I die and have to go back to that base to redo many lost hours of gameplay.  I HATE HAVING TO DO THINGS TWICE BECASE OF CHEAP DEATHS! Posted: December 24, 2013
												Overall I think this game is a great experience.   There is a lot of potential here.  Lots of user generated content.  I would like to see the studio make a more open ended campaign.  The main story is a bit linear but there is a lot of potential here!Edit: Dragonfall is a huge improvement in terms of storytelling and mechanics.  I recommend it even more and what I said in my original review was true.  The game is now becoming what it set out to be.  Tons of user generated content plus the new campaign makes this a must play if you like Shadowrun, Cyberpunk, or Tactical RPGs in general.  Warning...there is no voice acting, you actually have to...gasp...read!

Posted: March 1, 2014
												The Dragonfall expansion single-handedly did justice to Shadowrun Returns. The Dragonfall campaign build brings a much more involving and intricate storyline, choices, side-missions and memorable NPC companions, resulting in longer gameplay and satisfaction compared to the 12-hour long original. There were certain tweaks to the mechanics of the core game, it seems. For example, there will no longer be extra action points garnered from cybernetics, but this is compensated for via game balancing. There are new portraits to choose from (though still quite limited visual customization) but no changes to the skill trees. Games can be saved at almost every point of the game now, not just at savepoints, so that's another step forward. There are new music scores with this campaign, and they all set the mood satisfactorily for the throughout the gameplay. I still find the beats from the original campaign more to my liking, but that's personal opinion. Some issues inherent in the original was still present in this one. Missing sprites, limitations to allocating picked-up items to teammates outside of combat and the occassional AP bug can still be encountered. However, I would not personally hold this against the expansion as this one is does seem like the developer's turn of churning out an AAA campaign using the same builder tools made available to the community. I grew up playing and loving role-playing games that were akin to reading sci-fi fantasy book sets. After Baldur's Gate, Planescape: Torment, Arcanum and Neverwinter Nights, I am relieved to be able to add Shadowrun Returns into my collection of RPG games worth the ages. To enjoy this one, you'll have to read, children, and dig into your storeroom for that old thing called an 'active imagination'. If Shadowrun Returns left you feeling wanting, then Dragonfall will bring you past dessert.

Posted: March 12, 2014
												Do I recommend it? Here's a better question: is this one of the best cyperbunk pieces of media in the last 10 years? Yes, yes it is. The original Dead Man's Switch campaign is (mostly) well written and fun to play through, even to isometric RPG noobs like me (only other experience is original Fallout).I got the game for $15, but I would've gladly paid $30 for it, and I'm not even halfway through yet! Get the game, you won't regret it.

Posted: March 16, 2014
												Shadowrun. I picked up the Pen and Paper RPG when I was younger. Sadly it took years before finding a group to play it. Luckly around my University years I found a decent group of people and we are gaming since than. I am an hardcore fan so probably my Review could be a bit biased. Frist of all I strongly suggest to read a bit before gaming. Just the "Primer" which is a small guide\introduction to the World of Shadowrun available from the site Shadowrun Universe (official site for all things related to Shadowrun). Once you have the Primer you can have a good idea of what to expect from the Setting. I know that at a frist glance it looks strange maybe even too much but trust me it is awesome. The more you will dig the better it will get, specially if you start to read the various RPG manuals and novels. If you liked the setting buy this game. The basic Campaign included in Shadowrun Returns is a classic. If you never rped or played Shadowrun (I am mostly referring to SNES and GENESIS Games) this is a wonderfull start. The narration is set in 2050s which is a very cool period for Shadowrun (keep in mind that in the current RP Setting the time is around 2075) and it is based on some of the hottest plots of that period. The game is a basic Turn Based Combat with RP elements in the form of dialogues where the various options depends on which skill you have. Back when it was just published the Game lacked few things like save anywhere option. Luckly this was fixed up in the 1st DLC Dragonfall. Dragonfall is even better than the basic game. The Devs listened to us Players and fixed few things and I dare to say even took inspiration from some of UGC - User generated Content (More of this later). Dragonfall can look a bit boring at the start with the logic of "Do a Run, get back and run again" (Run is a work, a mission in Shadowrun) but the Narration, the Plot goes always up till its end. In Dragonfall I was not impressed by the first Runs but nearby the end I could not stop to see how this Story was going to end. The only negative side of both Shadowrun Returns and Dragonfall is that you can not manage your NPCs. You can select who can help you in a Run but you do not have any kind of control on their Skills and how they improve. Probably this will be fixed in future DLCs. If the basic game and the DLC are not enough there are UGCs. Shadowrun Community is very active and Devs select from time to time some UCG to play just to show up how much it is good. There are a lot of good Artist out there who are working on big UCG like remakes of SNES and Genesis Shadowrun Games. I strongly suggest to take a loot at "Shadowrun Unlimited". I hope all of this makes sense. In any case, if you start to play and dig into the Shadows of Shadowrun remember: "Shoot straight, conserve your ammo and never make a deal with a Dragon".

Posted: March 23, 2014
												Ive been fan of the Shadowrun ever since i first played on the Genesis and Snes and was glad to see a new iteration of it come out. The game still follows all of it rules and has a great look and story that fits the Shadowrun world great.While I still do recommend the game to fans of the Shadowrun world, it does have some really bad bugs / glitches still and wouldnt recommend it unless you love the shadowrun series.Fans of the first two fallout games might find some interest in this title as well since the combat sytem is set up very similar,although a  buggy (almost feels incomplete) version of it.Just an example of a few combat bugs to give people an idea of what thier getting into.A bug for shamans where when you summon a spirit which will cause the combat system to break and not be able to use or select any of characters during youre turn and basicly forcing you to forfeit the rest of your turn which will most likely cause a death of one of your runners.Another bug is where and enemy attacking you will shoot you through walls while you not only cannot shoot because of line sight issue and wont be able to even see the enemy untill you run around the wall.A bug where when you try to heal your drone out of combat it will say immune not heal your drone and use a repair kit.So I would say a good game for the price if your a fan of the series but if not I would probaly skip over this one.

Posted: March 18, 2014
												Great game. Real simple to get into. The plot was entertaining, but the end felt abrupt. I am use to turn base RPG's feeling like they last forever, and I was hoping for a little more.If you pick this up on sale, it is totally worth it. I just wish there was a 2nd campaign or a little longer 1st campaign.Cheers.

Posted: March 23, 2014
												Really a big fan of turn-based RPGs since Fallout and Fallout 2 as well as a fan of the pencil and paper, table-top RPG game. The description and reviews are fairly accurate. The thing that really hooked me was when the game was approaching a foreseeable ending and then took a left turn at Crazy Street. Totally surprised me in a good way and extended the gameplay by a couple of hours. Looking forward to replaying as a different spec character to see if there are any other twists that I missed. After that, it's some serious contemplation on whether to buy the DLC or venture off into the user created material that seems to be free of charge. All in all, a fun, solid game with unexplored aspects awaiting.

Posted: April 1, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns by itself is an excellent RPG game that blends the science fiction dystopia of William Gibson's cyberpunk genre and a fantasy world that deliciously warps the traditional roles. I never liked elves, but give one a data-jack smart link shotgun and some chrome wolverine claws and suddenly I think they're worth talking about.As someone who never played Shadowrun tabletop or even really had an idea of what it was, this game has launched me into an entire new realm of games. After finishing the first campaign I immediately went and bought a copy of the Shadowrun 5th edition sourcebook.The first DLC; Dragonfall, is even better than the original campaign both as a new story and a starting point for new players. The writers have only gotten better and they really immerse you in the details of an anarchist Berlin, plagued by crime and the ever present corporate political encroachment. Definitely recommend this game whole heartedly to both Shadowrun veterans and new players alike. Play. This. Game.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												For an old time Shadowrun fan this game feels like going back to a good old friend.On top of all, the Dragonfall expansion improves over several small details in the original, giving you more freedom to choose your path or make small or larger choices.I'd recommend it to any Shadowrun fan out there :)

Posted: June 28, 2014
												This game is quite the nostalgia trip. They really nailed the look and feel of gritty ol' Seattle of 2054, and the music is just stellar. It's an old view of the future, played in the old ways of RPGs. That means lots of turn-based combat and lots of reading. LOTS of reading. The story is nothing stellar -- what Shadowrun fiction ever is -- but it's a fun return to familiar territory. I haven't dug into the user-generated stuff, but the main campaign is easily worth the asking price if you have any love of cyberpunk.That said, if you buy this, then I highly recommend picking up the Dragonfall expansion as well. It's storyline is much, much better.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												Gameplay is topnotch Tactical RPG stuff. Its fun to make your character however you'd like them, and the skills are laid out in a straightforward way. Spell variety leaves a little bit left to be desired, and I personally wouldve liked greater variety for implants, but is all in all very solid. Storyline for the default game, called "The Deadman's Switch" is boring and linear, and you dont spend a long enough amount of downtime to talk to and connect with your party members. Also playing a decker is a waste of time as theres very few times you actually get to enter the Matrix. Hold your hand too much and feels shallow because of itThe DLC, Dragonfall, fixes the above problems. It starts a bit linear just like before, but theres multiple ways to clear any area, as well as plenty of time between missions to talk with your fellow Shadowrunners. The plot is much more interesting and there are more ways to use your character's skills, both in the field, and in dialogue choices. The game opens up and you get to start taking missions of your own accord, with each having a small storyline within its own mission.Theres also a metric crapton of great workshop content out for the game, which I think will add tremendously to the games longevity.Bottomline, buy this game, and buy it with the DLC.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												It's not particularly elegant, nor is it going to bring in any fans who aren't already down with Shadowrun...but damn if this isn't what all of us fans have been waiting for.  An honest, interesting, and close look at the Shadowrun universe and the tools to tell our own stories and make our own content.  Amazing work from Harebrained.  For the price, I can't see why you wouldn't at least try it.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												The core campaign here, Dead Man's Switch, is awful.  It serves as an introduction to the mechanics and, to a much lesser extent, the setting of Shadowrun.  The DLC/expansion Dragonfall, however, is absolutely fantastic, and is completely unrelated to the core campaign.  It's one of the better written RPGs I've ever played.  The characters are great, the story is interesting, the decisions are difficult, and although the "epilogue" is a little weak, the overall ending was solid.  I heartily recommend Dragonfall to any RPG enthusiast and especially to anyone who has ever been curious to explore the Shadowrun setting.

Posted: May 11, 2014
												Funded this game back when the kickstarter campaign was around. Spent $10, and would gladly spend $20+ on it. Granted, I am a long-time shadowrun fan, but it's a great game for rpg fans.While the graphics may not be the greatest, and the original story was pretty good at best (the Dragonfall DLC definitely makes up for it, it's another game in itself), what really makes up for it is all the user generated content that is coming out. A reboot of the snes title was the first project I saw pop up, and have been following since.Shadowrun Unlimited, is more of a non-linear style of game. I'm only a couple of hours into it, but there is so much more to it than the original game (more cyberware, more programs to be used in cyberspace, etc.), and it has much more replayability (random missions) than the original game.That's just a couple of mods that I've been keeping an eye on, and there's plenty more where those came from.If you like turn-based strategy, with both mystical (magic, dwarves, elves, etc.) and futuristic elements, it's most definitely worth picking up.

Posted: May 18, 2014
												Ok so i had never heard of shadowrun, not the Table game, books or the Vid-games, but got intrested when i saw the game show up on the store slider page and reading the description about the sci fi, cyberpunk, fantasy mix and seeing i had the funds sitting in the wallet thought i might aswell give it a go. I loved the setting & story the diffrent ways you can play depending on the characters and abilitys you choose to specilise with to get through the game, the first story 'deadman's swtich' was enjoyable but on replay i did notice what other people mentioned how there wasent much exploreing or side quests branching from the main plot as it throws you down the main story but all the same was enjoyable. the second story thats out however was a massive imrpovement 'Dragonfall' you're responcible for a whole area of people each character has their individual storys, there's many sidequests that branch off the main plot, and the choices you make can effect various details through the later game.In short i thought this game was great! and has replay value though mainly with the 'dragonfall' campaign, the graphics aint the most amazeing thing but i couldent care less!, i preffer games that are enjoyable, have good story & content. I strongly recomend this game to any rpg fans & anyone who enjoys good storylines in sci fi settings. :)

Posted: June 28, 2014
												First, an explaination: When you buy SHADOWRUN RETURNS, you get one campaign - "Deadman's Trigger." It's a solid introduction to the gameplay and story world. There's one additional campaign for sale from the studio - "Dragonfall," which also adds some new items and gameplay functionality. Additionally, the game comes with a campaign editor, allowing you to create your own or download campaigns from others on Steam Workshop.In terms of gameplay, SR is basically a glorified point-and-click adventure, with XCOM-style turn-based combat added in. The combat is just solid enough to feel worthwhile, but otherwise this is the kind of game that lives or dies on the quality of the writing. Thankfully, both campaigns present some of the best character development and story writing I've seen in a videogame. Is it high-literature? No, but it's incredibly solid pulp-fiction and well worth the price of admission.

Posted: June 29, 2014
												This game is absolutely awesome. It takes the rpg elements of the original Fallout 1 and 2 and mixes it with some of the combat mechanics of XCOM: Enemy Unknown/Within. The characters and world are wonderful, giving you that silver lining to a dystopian society. I picked this game up and logged 5 hours nonstop after starting.If you like story driven RPGs or turn-based tactics games, get this game.Edit: I don't mean to sound like I'm advertising it, this mod completes the game. Subscribe to the Shadowrun Unlimited mod in the Steam Workshop for an open world, borderline endless (so far as I can tell) adventure. You pick the contracts, explore an open city as you please, and work your way up the chain (unlock higher tier missions = more money = better apartment & equipment vendors). With this mod, I may never stop playing this game.

Posted: March 9, 2014
												SRR is one of the best RPGs of the generation; between this and the upcoming Wasteland 2, I'm overjoyed to see a resurgence in isometric, turn based RPGS. Everything Harebrained Schemes writes for this game is fantastic. Despite the frustrating brevity of Dead Man's Switch, the writing for it is exceptional. That said, you'll not be getting the real SRR experience unless you buy Dragonfall, which is head and shoulders above the game's first campaign. Lengthy, well written, and challenging, Dragonfall is every bit the excellent RPG adventure I've been missing since the days of Fallout and Fallout 2. If you like old school, you'll love this game. Additionally, SRR has the hands down best lore I've ever seen in a videogame--much, much more so than anything Bioware has released. A low pricetag and a robust User Generated Content scene make Shadowrun Returns the sort of purchase that should be made without any reservations. Just make sure you like reading!

Posted: March 27, 2014
												I didn't play the original Shadowrun back in the early nineties, so the game gets no retro love in this review. Shadowrun returns is a average cyberpunk and magic theme RPG. The main defect in the game is the vacuity of the gameworld comprised of the different interconnected areas. The game basically gives you only plot items to interact and the city locations are small. True to the "pocket world" RPG approach the plot is your average RPG pipeline stuff. Shadowrun Returns also lacks the intricate background stories for NPCs that most RPGs have, but this aspect of team interaction is added in the Dragonfall DLC. Dragonfall also does everything a little bit better, passing of as a relatively good RPG. It takes maybe 15-18 hours to complete Dragonfall if you're a completionist and about 20h for the main game. Since there's lots of combat, which is not that great, the game in my opinion is somwhat lacking in replay value. Though the end game of Dragonfall does play differently depending on few key choices, you're not inclined to mow through the same combat laden missions again.

Posted: March 7, 2014
												Way back in 1989, FASA Corporation, publisher of role-playing games, wargames and board games, released the first version of Shadowrun[en.wikipedia.org], a science fantasy tabletop role-playing game. It was cross-genre, taking elements from both cyberpunk and urban fantasy and putting the player in a world where humans co-exist with elves, dwarfs, trolls and other exotic races, where magic and cyberware are common and the Matrix is accessed by deckers, jacking into the network with cyberdecks connected directly to their brains.I was introduced to Shadowrun while attending middle school by some older friends of mine with long hair and/or glasses who were heavily into tabletop role-playing games. Over the years we tried many different games, like Vampire The Masquerade[en.wikipedia.org] and the GURPS[en.wikipedia.org] system, but Shadowrun was always the one we returned to and the game that gathered most players. Shadowrun has continued to thrive since its release as one of the most popular tabletop role-playing games and in July 2013, Shadowrun Fifth Edition was released.The Shadowrun universe has spawned a massive amount of properties, including action figure games, two magazines, over 50 novels and four more or less successful video games. The latest video game installment, Kickstarter-backed Shadowrun Returns[harebrained-schemes.com], was just recently released and this is my quick and dirty review.I have to admit that I don't remember all the details of the Shadowrun rules, it's been over 15 years since I last sat down to play, but from what I can tell, Shadowrun Returns is true to the core rulebook. The game takes its rules from the second and third edition of the rulebook and everything from character creation to the available items feel familiar. All races and classes, from Street Samurai to Shaman are there, all the different types of magic are available, deckers can enter the Matrix, and riggers can control drones. The only thing I haven't seen is the astral space, so I'm not sure if it's in the game, but players familiar with the Shadowrun universe will immediately feel at home nonetheless.Shadowrun Returns features isometric graphics, and you move your character around and interact with people and objects in real time. But as soon as the drek hits the fan and the weapons come out, the game switches to a turn-based model. Your team can consist of up to four characters, including yourself, and they all have a number of move points determined by each character's attributes. The combat, both in the real world and in the Matrix, is fairly simple, but in my opinion just as complex as it needs to be.The game comes bundled with one campaign set in Seattle, and a single campaign might not seem like much, but it will keep you entertained for 8 to 10 hours. There's also a Berlin campaign in development by the gamer's creators, Harebrained Schemes, but it's not scheduled for release until October. The campaign will be free for Kickstarter backers, but the rest of us have to get it as a paid DLC. That said, Shadowrun Returns comes with a level editor with virtually endless potential. And the game editor is the real strength of Shadowrun Returns: It's a framework that enables game masters to create their own campaigns and share them with the community.One of the great things about the tabletop version of Shadowrun was that it was very social, but if you were hoping for the same experience with Shadowrun Returns you will be disappointed. The game only supports singleplayer at the moment, but multiplayer might be implemented in the future. Multiplayer would be a sweet treat, but I'm not sure how it would be solved in practice. Who is the main character on a multiplayer run? Who will control the NPC team members? Thankfully, I'm not a game designer, so I'll leave these challenges for Harebrained Schemes to solve themselves.Since the game is just released, there are a few bugs here and there, but nothing major. Harebrained Schemes is also working closely with the players to find and remove bugs from the game and very recently released the first game patch. It contains both balancing changes and bug fixes the game needed. If there's one major issue I'd like to point out, it's the design decision to only save the game when the player moves from one area to another as opposed to letting the players save when real life needs their attention. It can be pretty damn tedious to replay parts of the game because you had to abort a run.Despite these few shortcomings Shadowrun Returns is a great game. If you ever played the tabletop version and enjoyed it, you owe it to yourself to buy and play Shadowrun Returns. The base campaign that comes bundled with the game is perhaps a bit linear, but complex and intriguing enough to keep you entertained from start to end. There is also massive potential in the game editor. I'm very excited to see what kind of campaigns the community will create and share.Maybe even my old game master will sit down and re-create his epic campaign from back in the days? That would be downright wiz.This review is also available on https://www.vegard.net/

Posted: July 27, 2013
												A fine game, however...There are many differences between a video game RPG and a tabletop RPG run by a GM. A video game RPG we expect certain conventions: random battles to raise XP, walking around a fixed location until we're ready to proceed with the story, and freedom to explore the entire world to a certain point.In a tabletop RPG, it's almost the opposite: random battles are tedious and most battles are relevant to the plot in some way, you're expected to keep to a timetable to follow the plot, and you probably won't revisit areas you've already visited except for a 'safe house' or two.What we have here is a video game RPG that acts like, plays like, and runs like a tabletop RPG! There are no random battles, and world exploration is very limited. Side quests are (generally) done immediately when you get them or not at all. There are no obvious good/bad dialogue choices that alter an unseen scale that judges your 'morality'. What we instead have is a very intriguing, atmosphere-driven game with a tightly-focused plot and tactical combat which feels very tabletop-ish.I enjoy Shadowrun, but I've also played the tabletop RPG and enjoy the setting. A person who buys this expecting something like a Bioware rpg or Skyrim is going to be very disappointed. But if you're willing to give it a chance, the atmosphere and writing will immerse you easily.And there's a game editor. So you can probably make your own game, if you think you could do better.

Posted: August 3, 2013
												This game *nails* the Shadowrun feel. Writing is solid, class and skill system is reasonably deep. Buy it for the campaign editor -- there's gonna be some great stuff coming out of the community.

Posted: August 10, 2013
												Amazingly high quality game, it does what it has to do perfectly, if you like the genre you will love this game!

Posted: July 27, 2013
												Ah Shadowrun, I'll start off by saying this: If you're into the Shadowrun universe and games like UFO: XCOM, then chances are that you'll really like Shadowrun returns.That said, I do have some issues with the game. First and foremost, the music gets grading and tiresome fast. I've played the game for 9 hours and I had to turn the music off, they were clearly aiming for a dark electronic ambience and they do achieve it, but there are simply not enough tunes and a few of them simply sound too much alike.A second point that I feel must be made, is the fact that the game has cut a lot of corners when making the jump from pen & paper to video game. Shadowrun has always aimed for high realism, but this requires a lot of rules and a lot of depth. I understand that they had to cut a lot of these rules because otherwise nobody would've been able to play the game without 2 hours of tutorial, if not more.Third point, there are some issues when trying to select certain points to move to in the grid, so I suggest activating the double-click feature, which ends the miss clicks.Fourth point, the save system blows balls. The game will auto-save whenever you enter a new scene, but you are unable to manually save, this means that if you fail, you have to start all over from the very beginning of the scene, this can be especially tiresome if the encounter is 30 minutes long or you just leveled up before you died.Fifth point is mostly mechanical, but I still feel  it should be mentioned. There's an issue with scripted events that can ♥♥♥♥ you over; I'll try to explain it: When you move a character through a door and towards cover, the character will stop because and a little dialogue will play. Afterwards your character will be stuck where the dialogue started and if you're out of actions for said character, this can lead to them recieving a lead sandwich. Couple this with the fact that you're unnable to resurrect your main character if his HP hits zero and you can get rather frustrated. This wouldn't be half bad, but when you can resurrect side characters after they hit zero HP it just seems rather silly.And finally always remember:Watch your back. Shoot straight. Conserve ammo. And never, ever, cut a deal with a dragon.

												After much debate, well, not really, but I did wait a decent amount of time to play this title:  Shadow Run – Returns (http://store.steampowered.com/app/234650/), I gave it shot.  It’s about 15 hours’ worth of content and there doesn’t appear to be much in the way of quality DLC atm.   From a cost perspective, a dollar per hour of game play with a great story is money well spent.  It has a Fall Out 1 feel as it is turn-based, there are walls of text to read, and you can be a troll hacker that is more charismatic than an ancient vampire, with a data jack in his head.  In short, if you want a game that doesn’t demand too much of your PC or your time, and gives you a decent story to fall in love with, this game is for you.

Posted: July 1, 2014
												Once I sorted out the crashing issues, (Thanks to this website http://shadowrun-returns.wikispaces.com/Troubleshooting+FAQ, I did the "Audio Problems" fix, and run the game in 1024x768) the game works fine. I will admit I never played any of the older versions, but Shadowrun Online has been on my wish list for a while and when I seen Shadowrun Returns for under $5 (I love you Steam Summer Sale), I snapped it up quick. After playing for only 15 mins, I was sad I never played the older versions, and I was doubly sad I never even heard about the Shadowrun series until this year.As for this iteration of the Shadowrun series, I was blown away, when one of the NPC's feels an urgency to get a mission done, that sense of urgency if felt by the player too. I'm looking your way Paco.The sound effects are really well put together, there is something satisfying about beaning a thug over the head with a baseball bat and that bone on wood sound chimes in......... (Makes note to get more baseball bats in game.)The dreary, miserable, wet, outside world is not only a joy (in the sense it feels real) to walk around in, it is also a joy to explore and talk to the locals and see how downtrodden they are as well.The loading screen DM style scene setting briefs even make the game feel like you could almost be playing the tabletop version with a friend over the weekend.Game play 10/10Graphics 10/10Music 10/10SFX 10/10Atmosphere 15/10All in All 10/10 will spend WAY to many hours playing.

												The base game is decent; the DLC is very good. Base game introduces you to all the game mechanics and is a good if not particularly deep game. The DLC on the other hand has a great plot that lends credibilty to the various runs your crew goes on, some great twists and turns, er, and also has some battles that are (potentially) cruelly unfair, awful, and frustrating.I just had trouble with the one battle, but I read that others had trouble with one or two others. I expect that it depends on play style and the party you bring. The battles often have some sort of interesting twist or surprise that makes them really interesting, but depending on your party and playstyle the same twist can make it very frustrating instead. Maybe the occasional rage quit is the price you pay for the cool surprises. :)In summary:  a) strongly recommended, worth buying just to play the DLC, and b) AUGH. AUGH AUGH AUGH. AUGH MMMWAAAH! AUGH! DIE! DIE! DIE! KILL! WHY AM I DOING THIS TO MYSELF? ISN'T THIS SUPPOSED TO BE FUN??? OK calm down, let's try it again.Four stars. A generally great game and totally worth your money. Expect 1 (and possibly 2  or 3 depending on what party you bring) really unfair battles in the DLC. :)  No, really, it's a little frustrating, but you care because it's good. Just buy it.

Posted: March 1, 2014
												The Dragonfall expansion single-handedly did justice to Shadowrun Returns. The Dragonfall campaign build brings a much more involving and intricate storyline, choices, side-missions and memorable NPC companions, resulting in longer gameplay and satisfaction compared to the 12-hour long original. There were certain tweaks to the mechanics of the core game, it seems. For example, there will no longer be extra action points garnered from cybernetics, but this is compensated for via game balancing. There are new portraits to choose from (though still quite limited visual customization) but no changes to the skill trees. Games can be saved at almost every point of the game now, not just at savepoints, so that's another step forward. There are new music scores with this campaign, and they all set the mood satisfactorily for the throughout the gameplay. I still find the beats from the original campaign more to my liking, but that's personal opinion. Some issues inherent in the original was still present in this one. Missing sprites, limitations to allocating picked-up items to teammates outside of combat and the occassional AP bug can still be encountered. However, I would not personally hold this against the expansion as this one is does seem like the developer's turn of churning out an AAA campaign using the same builder tools made available to the community. I grew up playing and loving role-playing games that were akin to reading sci-fi fantasy book sets. After Baldur's Gate, Planescape: Torment, Arcanum and Neverwinter Nights, I am relieved to be able to add Shadowrun Returns into my collection of RPG games worth the ages. To enjoy this one, you'll have to read, children, and dig into your storeroom for that old thing called an 'active imagination'. If Shadowrun Returns left you feeling wanting, then Dragonfall will bring you past dessert.

Posted: May 25, 2014
												If you're a fan of noir-style stories with twists and turns, tactical turn-based combat, or a fan of the Shadowrun tabletop RPG, this is probably a solid game for you. Played through "Dead Man's Switch" in about 10 hours. Good balance of exploration, dialogue, and combat. There were some things missing, though; the act of hiring teammates was cool, but you never interacted with them, which kind of sucked (some parts in the game led me to believe that it was originally there, but was cut). I also felt like my dialogue choices meant nothing to the outcome of the game, which pretty much goes against how tabletop RPGs work. Also, I think the Dragonfall DLC should be free, but I suppose I'm against paid DLC in general. Should you pay full price for this game? Yeah, I guess so. I'd give it a solid 8/10.

Posted: May 16, 2014
												Shadowrun for me is filled with fond memories of tabletop gaming, and lazy weekends with people too clever by half for their own good. Thankfullly, that core is there, and the story they bundle with it is solid. The problem however, lies with the overall brevity of the content given. There are remarkable storytellers out there who have written, and continue to write stories in the setting, [Do browse the UGC for the game!] but the package as a whole for the average gamer may be a little underwhelming. Mechanically, the pieces are functional, and the experience in terms of actual gameplay is solid enough, but the pace of action and the lack of diversity in its approach may not seem the divine ambrosia to all. X-Com would be a fair parallel to make for the way the gameplay unfolds in action sequences. Character development allows for specilization, and divesification both, but can feel stiflingly slow compared to the glut of typical loot-and-shoot games. For players who like the idea of being able to poke a few buttons thoughtlessly, toss another point into "strength" and move on to the next fight, the system may prove unsatisfying. For players who constantly look at old saves and think "What if I tried it with _____ build?" the depth of variety allowed is a welcome change of pace.Graphically, there is a sense of "days gone by", I personally found myself filled with nostalgia for the classics. The atmosphere is there, in all its dirty, decayed charm, and the experience as a whole is such that no single part of the presentation is a jarring disconnect from the rest. At its core, it holds true to the experiences I remember as a tabletop gamer. I enjoyed and continue to enjoy it and do not regret the purchase.

Posted: July 27, 2013
												A fine game, however...There are many differences between a video game RPG and a tabletop RPG run by a GM. A video game RPG we expect certain conventions: random battles to raise XP, walking around a fixed location until we're ready to proceed with the story, and freedom to explore the entire world to a certain point.In a tabletop RPG, it's almost the opposite: random battles are tedious and most battles are relevant to the plot in some way, you're expected to keep to a timetable to follow the plot, and you probably won't revisit areas you've already visited except for a 'safe house' or two.What we have here is a video game RPG that acts like, plays like, and runs like a tabletop RPG! There are no random battles, and world exploration is very limited. Side quests are (generally) done immediately when you get them or not at all. There are no obvious good/bad dialogue choices that alter an unseen scale that judges your 'morality'. What we instead have is a very intriguing, atmosphere-driven game with a tightly-focused plot and tactical combat which feels very tabletop-ish.I enjoy Shadowrun, but I've also played the tabletop RPG and enjoy the setting. A person who buys this expecting something like a Bioware rpg or Skyrim is going to be very disappointed. But if you're willing to give it a chance, the atmosphere and writing will immerse you easily.And there's a game editor. So you can probably make your own game, if you think you could do better.

Posted: July 27, 2013
												Ah Shadowrun, I'll start off by saying this: If you're into the Shadowrun universe and games like UFO: XCOM, then chances are that you'll really like Shadowrun returns.That said, I do have some issues with the game. First and foremost, the music gets grading and tiresome fast. I've played the game for 9 hours and I had to turn the music off, they were clearly aiming for a dark electronic ambience and they do achieve it, but there are simply not enough tunes and a few of them simply sound too much alike.A second point that I feel must be made, is the fact that the game has cut a lot of corners when making the jump from pen & paper to video game. Shadowrun has always aimed for high realism, but this requires a lot of rules and a lot of depth. I understand that they had to cut a lot of these rules because otherwise nobody would've been able to play the game without 2 hours of tutorial, if not more.Third point, there are some issues when trying to select certain points to move to in the grid, so I suggest activating the double-click feature, which ends the miss clicks.Fourth point, the save system blows balls. The game will auto-save whenever you enter a new scene, but you are unable to manually save, this means that if you fail, you have to start all over from the very beginning of the scene, this can be especially tiresome if the encounter is 30 minutes long or you just leveled up before you died.Fifth point is mostly mechanical, but I still feel  it should be mentioned. There's an issue with scripted events that can ♥♥♥♥ you over; I'll try to explain it: When you move a character through a door and towards cover, the character will stop because and a little dialogue will play. Afterwards your character will be stuck where the dialogue started and if you're out of actions for said character, this can lead to them recieving a lead sandwich. Couple this with the fact that you're unnable to resurrect your main character if his HP hits zero and you can get rather frustrated. This wouldn't be half bad, but when you can resurrect side characters after they hit zero HP it just seems rather silly.And finally always remember:Watch your back. Shoot straight. Conserve ammo. And never, ever, cut a deal with a dragon.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												First, an explaination: When you buy SHADOWRUN RETURNS, you get one campaign - "Deadman's Trigger." It's a solid introduction to the gameplay and story world. There's one additional campaign for sale from the studio - "Dragonfall," which also adds some new items and gameplay functionality. Additionally, the game comes with a campaign editor, allowing you to create your own or download campaigns from others on Steam Workshop.In terms of gameplay, SR is basically a glorified point-and-click adventure, with XCOM-style turn-based combat added in. The combat is just solid enough to feel worthwhile, but otherwise this is the kind of game that lives or dies on the quality of the writing. Thankfully, both campaigns present some of the best character development and story writing I've seen in a videogame. Is it high-literature? No, but it's incredibly solid pulp-fiction and well worth the price of admission.

content:
Posted: March 31, 2014
												Cyberpunk is a genre as much built on the atmosphere as it is on the technology. Everyone has that formative memory of the giant advertisements and smog-belching smokestacks in Blade Runner, Some games make the mistake of keeping the slums out of the cyberpunk, but Shadowrun Returns has the formula down just right: "high tech, low life." The game is a fun return to an earlier era for me, given my experience with the tabletop game - but the experience is fluid and accurate, reminding me of so many times spent around a table being suspicious about your Fixer or the latest contact you made.The gameplay can be somewhat halting and awkward at times - a concession to make in order to accommodate the system itself, of course - but it doesn't diminish the enjoyment of this authentic cyberpunk game. Combat is strategic, if somewhat sparse on detail, and emphasises the differences in roles within the party itself. The decking is sadly quite anaemic compared to the tabletop world, a blue-gridlines re-creation of the combat systems, with Agents standing in for Spirits, and spells replaced with Decker attacks. Nonetheless, it rounds out the flavour of the game well.If you're looking for an engaging Cyberpunk story, with a dash of magic and plenty of political intrigue and conspiracy, I highly recommend Shadowrun Returns.

Posted: May 4, 2014
												If you liked the table top game, or any table top game... then buy this game.  The graphics are...ok... the gameplay is good... but the story is fantastic.  It felt simultaneously home grown and professionally constructed. I felt like I was at a table game, participating in one of the mostl finely constructed stories I had ever played.  It starts small, with a seemingly inocuous event and ends huge.  The story is a work of art.  And speaking of works of art...  The mod tool is one as well.  Included is a single tool with which to build your own stories. It's powerful, easy (enough) to use, the tutorial videos are great, and it includes tons of assets. All in all it's really smart.  Which is going to be my final review for this game.  Shadow Run: Returns... Smart.

Posted: April 30, 2014
												I must admit that I purchased this game with a bit of trepidation.  Shadowrun on the SNES was one of my favorite gaming experiences of my youth.  It was so unique compared to the gaming experiences I had up to that point.  I caught the game on sale and after playing I am absolutely floored by how great this game is.  The storyline had me reeled in.  The combat was a blast, just like back on my old SNES.  Even with 6 character archetypes to choose from, there is still an immense amount of customization that allows you to find your own playstyle.  Hats off to the dev team for a well polished, enjoyable experience with plenty of new features that still pulls off a nice tip of the hat to the old SNES classic.  This game is a must play.

												Awesome artstyle. Awesome theme. Awesome IP. Gameplay leaves a little to be desired. Not a lot of actual choices to be made, which are usually pretty important in heavy dialog RPG's such as this. Interesting class that all have different benefits and styles of play, but the corridor-straightforwardness of the fighting and adventuring doesn't really give you a lot to work with. Posted: May 6, 2014
												The classic 80s-90s vision of the cyberpunk future of the Shadowrun world is done serious justice by this game.  The art style and game mechanics and story all do a great job of pulling you into it even though there is no voice acting (prepare for a lot of reading).The turn based combat is slow paced but satisfying.  The character skill and equipment system is pretty robust.  So, there's definately room for replay variety but it would probably be boring to play through more than a couple times.  If you're a veteran of turn based combat games, I would suggest playing on a high difficulty.  I played the default normal setting and for the most part, combat was way too easy.All in all a pretty lesurely game and a bit nostalgic.  Keeping in mind how SR is setup more as a gaming platfom with systems in place for users to create their own stories and content, the lack of niceties like voice acting, variety of music and so on is forgivable.  This was definately worth the $4.99 I paid for it on Steam sale.

												The core campaign here, Dead Man's Switch, is awful.  It serves as an introduction to the mechanics and, to a much lesser extent, the setting of Shadowrun.  The DLC/expansion Dragonfall, however, is absolutely fantastic, and is completely unrelated to the core campaign.  It's one of the better written RPGs I've ever played.  The characters are great, the story is interesting, the decisions are difficult, and although the "epilogue" is a little weak, the overall ending was solid.  I heartily recommend Dragonfall to any RPG enthusiast and especially to anyone who has ever been curious to explore the Shadowrun setting.

Posted: July 21, 2014
												Best way to describe it would be a mix between a traditional fallout game, and a Dungeons and Dragons title. It's a party based strategy game set in a cyperpunk future where magic has been introduced to the world. The original campaign is well enough, however Dragonfall (DLC) is where the game really shines.

Posted: July 31, 2014
												The Dead Man's Switch(DMS) campaign is forgettable and is only notable for having an annoying enemy that can only be killed with a cumbersome mechanic. There are a handful of interesting interactions during DMS but overall its honestly not worth playing through and can be easily skipped.Dragonfall(DF), on the other hand, is awesome and is filled with characters and scenarios that are as imaginative, well written,  and worth exploring as some of the best RPGs that I have ever played. DF additionally contains a much better structure than DMS, by that I mean rather than having a linear quest with hardly any side branches that you undertake with some flavorless NPCs, DF tasks you with a central goal and allows you to lead a team of fairly unique characters along a questline that has scores of opportunity to explore more of the world of Shadowrun. I enjoyed the vast majority of my time with DF, save for the hacking bits (called decking in this universe), and some later game fights with some annoyingly powerful enemies. Altough, I wholeheartedly recommend DF, Its a shame that you have to buy both to play DF but since thats the case I would advise that you buy the campaigns at a reduced cost and skip DMS.

Posted: July 27, 2013
												A fine game, however...There are many differences between a video game RPG and a tabletop RPG run by a GM. A video game RPG we expect certain conventions: random battles to raise XP, walking around a fixed location until we're ready to proceed with the story, and freedom to explore the entire world to a certain point.In a tabletop RPG, it's almost the opposite: random battles are tedious and most battles are relevant to the plot in some way, you're expected to keep to a timetable to follow the plot, and you probably won't revisit areas you've already visited except for a 'safe house' or two.What we have here is a video game RPG that acts like, plays like, and runs like a tabletop RPG! There are no random battles, and world exploration is very limited. Side quests are (generally) done immediately when you get them or not at all. There are no obvious good/bad dialogue choices that alter an unseen scale that judges your 'morality'. What we instead have is a very intriguing, atmosphere-driven game with a tightly-focused plot and tactical combat which feels very tabletop-ish.I enjoy Shadowrun, but I've also played the tabletop RPG and enjoy the setting. A person who buys this expecting something like a Bioware rpg or Skyrim is going to be very disappointed. But if you're willing to give it a chance, the atmosphere and writing will immerse you easily.And there's a game editor. So you can probably make your own game, if you think you could do better.

Posted: July 27, 2013
												Ah Shadowrun, I'll start off by saying this: If you're into the Shadowrun universe and games like UFO: XCOM, then chances are that you'll really like Shadowrun returns.That said, I do have some issues with the game. First and foremost, the music gets grading and tiresome fast. I've played the game for 9 hours and I had to turn the music off, they were clearly aiming for a dark electronic ambience and they do achieve it, but there are simply not enough tunes and a few of them simply sound too much alike.A second point that I feel must be made, is the fact that the game has cut a lot of corners when making the jump from pen & paper to video game. Shadowrun has always aimed for high realism, but this requires a lot of rules and a lot of depth. I understand that they had to cut a lot of these rules because otherwise nobody would've been able to play the game without 2 hours of tutorial, if not more.Third point, there are some issues when trying to select certain points to move to in the grid, so I suggest activating the double-click feature, which ends the miss clicks.Fourth point, the save system blows balls. The game will auto-save whenever you enter a new scene, but you are unable to manually save, this means that if you fail, you have to start all over from the very beginning of the scene, this can be especially tiresome if the encounter is 30 minutes long or you just leveled up before you died.Fifth point is mostly mechanical, but I still feel  it should be mentioned. There's an issue with scripted events that can ♥♥♥♥ you over; I'll try to explain it: When you move a character through a door and towards cover, the character will stop because and a little dialogue will play. Afterwards your character will be stuck where the dialogue started and if you're out of actions for said character, this can lead to them recieving a lead sandwich. Couple this with the fact that you're unnable to resurrect your main character if his HP hits zero and you can get rather frustrated. This wouldn't be half bad, but when you can resurrect side characters after they hit zero HP it just seems rather silly.And finally always remember:Watch your back. Shoot straight. Conserve ammo. And never, ever, cut a deal with a dragon.

Posted: June 24, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is so damn likable that it's easy to overlook how mediocre it can be. The user interface is cumbersome and frequently doesn't let you do what you'd expect it would. It's janky in the way that you remember crusty old PC games used to be, except it's not charming by today's standards. The default campaign: Dead Man's Switch is unflinchingly linear and the game has some odd hitching issues. But it's ****ing cyberpunk! Despite the fact that the story goes off the rails in a rather magnificent way, Shadowrun Returns stays true to the Gibson-esque tone that you want from a cyberpunk RPG and more to the point, a sequel to the original Shadowrun. The writing is what you want from a Shadowrun game. The combat is ersatz-XCOM Enemy Unknown. I'd have a hard time calling Shadowrun Returns great, but if you're as starved as I am for its specific brand of dystopia, it's a decent fix.

Posted: June 28, 2014
												I'm done with "Dead Man's Switch" and a few missions into "Dragonfall."tl,dr: Don't buy the game unless you buy Dragonfall with it.The combat is a bit simple, though turning up the difficulty helps immensely to provide a more engaging, complicated experience. It certainly doesn't feel like the fluidity one finds in a real tabletop game session, but then, to expect that from a computer game is usually folly.The heart, and meat, of the game is, rather, in its dialogue and world. For clarity, don't expect voice acting and animated cutscenes. It's more in the mein of the aging RPGs like Baldur's Gate, but even less frilly. Characters are rendered convincingly, and with their own authorial voices. The writing never worse than "pretty good."But where Dead Man's Switch (the base campaign) never gets far above pretty good, and maintains a dreary linearity at all times, Dragonfall excels. Dragonfall's characters and story are much more believably written, the world more flavorful, and the story less full of deus ex machina windfalls.Where Dead Man's Switch feels like a saturday morning cartoon, Dragonfall is more like a well-written, high-budget film. I might watch both, but you can be sure I'd much rather watch the latter.

Posted: July 27, 2014
												For some, Shadowrun: Returns was a disappointment; a Kickstarter investment that didn't quite live up to their expectations. To others, it was good enough. For some, like me, the game was a very happy surprise that engaged them more than they had ever expected.Shadowrun: Returns is, as one might gather, a return to the Shadowrun universe, based on the Pen & Paper role-playing game and the previous NES RPG tied in with it. Following its roots, it is of course a role-playing game, played from an isometric perspective not unlike the older Fallout titles. When seeing this perspective, you'll probably note how absolutely striking it is: The first thing that struck me about this game is how absolutely beautiful it is. The artwork is wonderfully designed and it carries a dark, gritty cyberpunk tone that will bring you back to stories such as Neurmancer and Blade Runner.The centerpiece with many worlds is, of course, the story, and again, this is an area where Shadowrun: Returns truly shines. Although the story itself might not be the strongest out there, the overall writing makes up for it: The character and story are written with a high quality, and this breathes life into the story, making it engaging, making you curious as to what might happen next.  The written dialogues contain plenty of wit and intrigue with interesting conversation options, very much making up for the fact that there is no voice-acting present in the game.So, if the story is wonderful and the world equally so, you might begin to see where the detracting factors come in that made this game disappointing for some: The gameplay is where Shadowrun: Returns is lacking. Unlike its late 90's - early 2000's peers Fallout and the Infinity Engine games, Shadowrun isn't very open-ended. It's a linear story that you follow. Sure, there are a few optional sidequests, you can talk to people and you have plenty of freedom when it comes to building your character, there isn't too much free-roaming through the game's world. The world is wonderful, yes, but it could have been utilized way better if there was more freedom.The combat falls a bit short along with it. It's tense enough, and there is a little strategy involved, but very weak animation and sound design deliver a very hard blow to a system that would otherwise be pretty solid; It feels weak and unsatisfying, despite being quite exciting in some of the harder spots of the game.Finally, the RPG mechanics are lacklustre when compared to other titles. Although the progression tree does its job pretty well, there is no proper way to equip yourself during missions, no true 'inventory' besides utility and weapon slots and generally it feels as if there are just a few features missing in this department that would have truly helped the game become better.So, what do we end up with? A very story-oriented game with a wonderful world to play in. The gameplay might not deliver all the time, but it's just strong enough to hold together the rest, and if the combat doesn't provide enough motivation to keep playing, the writing most probably will. If a darker, cyberpunk world to play around in for a bit appeals to you, Shadowrun: Returns is most definitely worth playing.As a final note, it must be said that the game is packed with a reasonably strong modding tool and Steam Workshop compatibility, so when you're done playing you can play user-created content or have a go at making some yourself!

												Solid Turned-Based RPG.I found the overall game to be solid.  Well written, enjoyable storyline wrapped with some great mechanics.  Complaints about a very linear campaign are accurate. Posted: March 4, 2014
												This expansion for Shadowrun Returns (by Hare-Brained Schemes) evokes the old-school grand scope of classic Bioware RPGs.  More than just an expansion campaign, Dragonfall improves on the original engine in many ways, and responds directly to many complaints about the original.  Even better, it translates those improvements (like a new save system) to the original campaign as well, so folks new to the series entirely can enjoy the improved engine from the start.  The result is an improved product all around, and a memorable and enjoyable RPG set in one of the most fun alternate universes ever created.  An excellent set of custom creation tools add to the potential life of the game, as the mod community may well produce some masterpieces of their own, down the line.
