Posted: March 4, 2014
												I never played the original Shadowrun (SNES and Sega Genesis, apparently), but after playing Shadowrun Returns, I'm going to find it.Shadowrun Returns is one of the few games in the "RPG" category that is, in fact, a Role-Playing Game. Unlike Dungeon Siege, Diablo, BioWare Game or Final Fantasy, Shadowrun actually requires you to interact with NPCs and the manner of those interactions actually impacts the game. Imagine that. So many games claim that NPC interactions affect outcomes, but this is the first game I've played in a while (not including the Elder Scrolls/Fallout 3 sub-genre) in which that's actually true.Dead Man's Switch (the original campaign) has a little bit of important dialogue, but Dragonfall (the first DLC campaign) is LOADED with character development and NPCs that actually behave differently depending on how you treat them.But the beauty of Shadowrun Returns isn't the official campaigns. It's the editor, and the integration with Steam Workshop. I've not actually used the editor yet, but judging from the vast range of quality in the user-created content, it must be pretty easy to use. On the one hand, that means a LOT of just pure garbage content. On the other hand, it means that learning how to use the editor isn't a stumbling block for somebody who's got a great story to tell.So while the original campaign is really quite good (I mean really, really good. It's one of the few campaigns of any game that I'm perfectly happy replaying several times in a row), Dragonfall really showcases what the game's engine is capable of.If you've ever played the old Fallout games (Fallout, Fallout 2, Fallout Tactics), this is a lot like those. If you haven't played those, think of it as turn-based, squad-based Diablo, with almost no emphasis on gear. There is an equipment treadmill, but it's not very involved. More along the lines of Mass Effect 2.There are three or four pistols (for example), and you buy the most expensive one you can afford. So while there IS a reason to make more money and get the better stuff, it's not the need that it is in other games (Diablo, for example). Sorry to keep making the comparison to Diablo, but that's the other game I've been playing most recently.Shadowrun Returns is also one of the few games I've played that knows how to use a touchscreen. Most games work "well enough," but SR has a touchscreen mode that makes it function beautifully. And by "beautifully," I mean that the PC version plays just as well on my Dell touchscreen as the Android version plays on my Samsung Note 2.I don't know if anyone but me cares about that, but with the increasing prevalence of Windows 8, I figure it's worth mentioning.I know I'm making a big deal about Dragonfall, and I mean to. It's an excellent campaign, and is actually (in my opinion) worth the price of a full expansion pack, as opposed to the increasingly-common 2-dollar DLC. But I suppose I should really talk more about Dead Man's Switch. It's an engaging mystery with great characters. It doesn't have the meaningful dialogues and character developmnet of Dragonfall, but I was immediately taken with both Dresden and Kluwe. They're not "important" characters, but the fact that placeholder roles are filled with well-fleshed and well-written characters is just indicative of the attention to detail paid by the devs. It's a well-polished introduction to the world of Shadowrun.

Posted: March 4, 2014
												Okay, I finally have to write a little something after playing the Dragonfall DLC.First off, to quickly go over Shadowrun Returns:  Let me preface this by saying I am a kickstarter backer.  Back when SRR popped up on Kickstarter, I immediately jumped on board.  I'd been craving the old-school SR like the ones on Genesis and SNES which I played when I was hardly into my teens, and everything in the KS pitch sold me that this would bring it back to those days.  When SRR finally released and I played through it, I came out satisfied.  It has a solid and deep story, good combat (which has since been balanced and improved), fairly simple puzzles, and yes..it had some flaws like no manual saves (again, resolved since then), but it didn't really bug me that much.  Most of all, they made choice matter.And then along comes Shadowrun: Dragonfall.   Dragonfall absolutely oozes greatness.  There's insane depth of characters and the world, down to the smallest details, even in conversations with side characters like Simmy Kim and reading the Shadowland BBS.  It's a very rare thing where a game captures me so well that I sit and read every single piece of text I come across (and there's so much to read in this series).  I especially appreciated the design in this DLC of having the quest hub, but more importantly, there were so many more rich side quests throughout the campaign than in the base game.  They also upped the design on the puzzle elements a bit which I appreciated (the original campaign's were generally way too straightforward).  But enough of a wall of text, let's break things down:Story: Phenomenal.  Aside from the depth of lore in this world, the story of this campaign alone was so great.  Just when you     think you've got things figured out, something throws you for a loop.  You face lots of decisions that test your morals, many of which mostly seem to test just how close to "the line" you're willing to step, or if it's even a question for you.Characters: Great.  This time around, you've got a dedicated crew.  Sure, you could hire runners to go along with you, but the crew is where it's at.  They've got deep stories and I loved every bit of exploring them.  The SRR Dead Man Switch campaign had people occasionally joining you, like Coyote, but those companions pale in comparison to the attention given to the crew of Dragonfall.  I cared about my crew.  Hell, I felt bad that I always had to leave one member behind on my runs having only room for a team of 4.  I felt like I was neglecting them most of the game and that they were going to confront me about it at some point.Combat: Solid.  I played on hard difficulty, and essentially did the same rifle-focused street samurai build I did in SRR.  I found it much more balanced, and there were several missions with some real tension as the fights raged on.  The Matrix served a good purpose as well; it felt much more key to this campaign than the first.Graphics: Beautiful.  They already established this with SRR, they just painted a whole new world for Dragonfall's Berlin setting, and it's gorgeous.So that's it in a nutshell.Final verdict: Worth buying?  Abso-freakin-lutely.  This is an rpg not to be missed.

												Good News:This game stays extremely close to the feel of the core game of Shadowrun, so much so it feels like it's been released by FASA during the 90's in tone and theme,  It also tries very hard to give you customization of the shadowrunner classes or lets you make your own main character to get through the plot the way you want to. There's also no way to end combat which makes some parts just a little bit of a slog once you kill all of your enemies and have to traverse the map taking turns.   I played a mage and feel like I got a little shafted because you don't get to play in the Matrix unless you want to split your skills, you can't assense, go astral, or summon elementals.  You're just a better, more versatible combat monster.However:The Good outweighs the bad.  If you were a fan of the tabletop RPG or like the theme of technology mixed with magic, it's definitely worth a playthrough.  If you don't like story or you expect more tactics in your combat, skip it.

Posted: August 31, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns (Dead Man's Switch) has some of the best writing of any game I've played this year, but the early going can be somewhat frustrating as SR unfortunately plays its cards close to its chest before opening up the world. After an extended prologue, though, the game blossoms into a story that pulls from classic noir fiction like Raymond Chandler's Marlowe stories and Polanski's Chinatown coupled with the richly detailed background fiction of the Shadowrun universe. "Cyberpunk and magic" is a concept that should, by all accounts, collapse into utter silliness, but somehow SR manages to keep finding interesting (and sometimes amusing) twists on both of these themes.While the art style is clean and the interface generally functional (inventory management is a sore spot), be aware that this is a game that really only gives as much as you're willing to bring to it -- there are no 3D environments, voiced dialog, or cut scenes, but the game manages to be immersive in the same way that dreamily browsing through a gamebook and conjuring adventures can be. Some reviews have faulted the plot for being overly linear, and while I always appreciate more player agency, it really wasn't an issue for me here.My main complaint is the way the game paces itself in doling out the fun skills and cool toys. Early on it's hard to understand why I'd want to invest in particular skill sets when there's little explanation of how they function or game scenarios that take advantage of them. It's not until the midpoint of the game that distinctive SR features like rigs, decks, and chroming really even come into play which makes it frustrating to define your character without knowing what kind of build you're even shooting for. While I have no problem holding back some surprises, I would have rather seen the advanced stuff up on the shelf early on so I had a better idea of what I could aspire to be. In the worst case, you can never go wrong with shooting something with a gun or throwing a fireball at it, though a lot of the fun in SR comes from mixing and matching all the different combinations available.But the story and characters are well drawn, the dialog full of personality, and once events pick up steam I felt compelled to chase down the conclusion. By the end I'd developed a lot of affection for both my character and the friends she'd made along the way; I was sorry to see them go (and that there are currently no plans to continue their story) but based on the strength of this initial foray I'll definitely be checking out the sequel, Dragonfall. Definitely recommended.

												Personally I think the Sega Genesis game tops all of the rest of the shadowrun installments...I didn't play the fps for the pc that was released a few years ago but i heard that was garbage so.... Genesis still wins out, but this version is very close to the Snes version just prettier and better sound. the game revolves around clicking to talk to people, clicking to shoot them, clicking to use inventory and or special moves/spells.sometimes you do this in the matrix (not much different from the ingame rl combat.)you have to do alot of stuff to progress from one area to the next and it can feel clunky, and slow, and if you aren't a SR fan the game then Shadowlingo can be convoluted and seem ...very stuck in what the 80's thought theyd be saying in the future. Posted: March 18, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is set in a fantastic, cyberpunk, distopian earth, where mega-coorporations are running the show, drug dealers roam the streets, and mercenary adventurers, called "shadowrunners" take on dangerous work for the highest bidder. On top of everything else, magic has returned to the world, which puts a novel spin on the whole cyberpunk setup.This game has a brilliant atmosphere, captivating from the start, pulling you into the dirty streets of a blade-runner-ish seattle, and putting you into the skin of a shadow runner. Shadowrun returns features a great story, with lots of twists and reminds me of the Torment due to its emphasis on dialogue, rather than battles. On the downside it's very linear, with only a couple of occasional options for side-quests. But this is not necessarily that bad, because it focuses on the plot and tells the story without infinite distractions and pointless errants.Highly recomended for RPG fans who are not aversed to exploring a futuristic, cyberpunk world, very similar to the worlds of Gibson's "the neuromancer", or Stephenson's "snowcrash" but still very unique in its own right.

Posted: June 24, 2014
												This is a game that could have been so much more. I love the setting and I think that for the most part they did a great job creating the world. However while it looks great it often feels like a set rather than a living city. Every place you go plays out more or less the same. Click the 2 or 3 people with talk symbols over their head, look for the 1 or 2 items that you can click on the map somewhere, fight a few guys, leave area. I like the world, I want to be able to go around and explore it and have a reason to do so. Even if it is just flavor text like "You see a grimy computer terminal, you can tell it has been well used" for example. I want to be able to go around and look at everything and just explore. The world graphics are great for the most part. There are a few things that really take me out of it like the quick loop of papers blowing in the wind over and over. The birds that fly off when you walk by are great though. My biggest gripe with the graphics is that the characters rarely look anything like their super awesome avatar pictures. I see a big orc character and when I walk up to him his avatar picture is of a skinny orc. The avatar picture I made for my guy is very thin but his character model is chunky with a way different head. Just pulls me out of the story. I like the story and I like the characters. It was well written and kept me interested. Even the loading screen text telling me about the place I was heading was great. I do wish that there was less travel here travel there though. I just get interested in an area and nope off to the next place. Maybe if rather than quick traveling everywhere there were inbetween areas with optional side stuff to do then all the traveling around would feel more cohesive. I have not played the official DLC mission yet so maybe they fixed some of my problems with it. Despite the problems, I do recommend the game if for nothing else other than the story and great setting. I really hope we get something more expansive in this universe someday though.

												Right... So where do I begin... The game left me with quite a mixture of feelings...Let's clear the negative bits first. The game is more linear than most linear FPS's this days (and the RPG being more linear than most FPS's says a lot). There is almost no chance to explore or approach the mission in any variety of ways. The game practically forces you from point A to point B in a most direct and unforgiving way. There is simply nothing to do in between of those points. No exploration, no looting, no chatting with random NPC - nothing.Another major let down of this game are dialogs. While generaly well written, multiple choice answers make no sense. As no matter what you reply will be, the conversations take the same course. You can flatter other NPC to high sky or you can tell them to kiss your *** - makes no difference whatsoever in majority of cases. So to cut the long story short - the game is hugely let down by its linearity. Its ultimately linear in every imaginable way - from converasations to how the missions go.But let's "knock it off with those negative waves" and be positive for a bit. First and foremost the game's atmosphere is absolutely marvellous. Considering the simplicity of graphics, sound and setting the game does absolutely fantastic job in recreating a world that, despite its linearity, is still interesting to be in. Many games, while being much more graphically advanced and running on much higher budget have tried and failed to deliver the same.The atmosphere somewhat reminds me of the first Deus Ex, only with magic, elves and orks thrown in. Same dark, run-down, but strangely attractive urban-setting of the near future. You really feel comfy, entering the pub after roaming the slums, you really want to ask bartender for a pint (shame that game won't let you) and chat with the bouncer, while you at it.The plot is fairly strong. Somewhat predictable, but still has a few unexpected twists and provides a good story. Other than that - game has a lot of potential to expand on what it has already achieved, to fix its downfalls and to become a classic in its own right. Developers have already done the most important thing - creating an interesting and immersive world. Now its only a question of expanding on dialogues, exploration, more side quests and making the game-world bigger and more detailed.So I would still recommend this game and "Dragonfall" is already on my wishlist (although not at the top). If you aren't fully convinced - just wait for big sale and buy it then. It probably wouldnt be ultimate purchase of the year, but still - few coins well spent :)

Posted: June 17, 2014
												Shadowrun is a long running series, starting in 1993 as a Nintendo action adventure game, it literally blew minds with its diverse story telling. It had everything; connecting your brain to the internet, street mages, mafia trolls, crazy ex-girlfriends. the game was later adapted into a paperback rpg that has had a relatively strong run. ( its in its 5th edition.)Shadowrun Returns; Deadmans switch and its superior, Dragonfall, takes place in 2070, about 10- 20 years after the events of original. Deadmens switch is an adventure through the city of Seattle, fighting through deadly cultist plots and drek crazy doctors you manage to avenge your old partner’s death. While dragonfall is and intricate story about investigating a mysterious force in berlin while your attempt to battle forces that would appose the flux state. I belive the game play is quite sharp for a turn based game, delivering multple layers of complexty with its various custom class archtypes (rigger, adept, shaman, samurai, mage, decker, ect) you can play a muscle mage, or a shooty hacker, or any combination there of. next there's the multiple layers of customization, from bio mods to specll selection you have a large library to chose from. I've thoroughly enojoyed my adventures in the dark, an impatienly await the coming additions.

Posted: June 21, 2014
												I was introduced to Shadowrun back in the early 90's with the SNES classic.  I fell in love with the setting almost instantly; sci-fi with magic?  It was my dream game.  I then became more enamoured with the Sega Genesis version once I discovered it, since it allowed for even more freedom, and a glimpse into the true mechanics of the game.  In Junior High I was introduced to the actual tabletop RPG, and it sparked my love of that hobby.  All that aside, Shadowrun is very important and dear to me, will always hold a special place in my heart, and will forever be held at the highest standard for me.This game does not dissappoint.  At all.  It is amazing.  The setting harkens back to an earlier time of the Shadowrun universe, when Deckers HAD to go with the group, because wireless connectivity, that wasn't even a thing.Dunkelzahn hadn't become the first Dagon-American President of the UCAS.The Arcology was still a shining beacon of how the future will be.The world is perfect.  It shows how and why people live in the shadows, and doesn't leave anything to mystery as to why the world is in the over all crummy condition it's in.  The gameplay, while not the Shadowrun I know and love, still feels amazing.  Spellcasters are appropriately powerful, while not being the rediculous level of game breaking they can be in the tabeltop (lacking Astral Projection and long-term spirit aid.)  Martial-oriented characters are sufficiently amazing (street samurais and adepts both shine,) and whether you're melee, gun happy, or mixed, you have a lot of cool options.  Where the mechanics really shine?  The Matrix play.  It feels very appropriate for what it's supposed to be.  A little world where you wander around and blast programs.  Where the game lacks over all?  While highly customizable, it still feels as though you are cornered into one or to directions.  Healing is challenging, which isn't bad, just something you aren't really made aware of early on.  It also feels that there's a sharp increase to difficulty if you aren't playing a face (social oreinted) character.  All in all, an amazing game, love it, and suggest it to everyone!

												Shadowrun Returns is a surprisingly addictive isometric cyberpunk RPG. The combat has enough tactical depth to keep you on your toes, but the real strength to this game is the story. Posted: July 31, 2014
												The Dead Man's Switch(DMS) campaign is forgettable and is only notable for having an annoying enemy that can only be killed with a cumbersome mechanic. There are a handful of interesting interactions during DMS but overall its honestly not worth playing through and can be easily skipped.Dragonfall(DF), on the other hand, is awesome and is filled with characters and scenarios that are as imaginative, well written,  and worth exploring as some of the best RPGs that I have ever played. DF additionally contains a much better structure than DMS, by that I mean rather than having a linear quest with hardly any side branches that you undertake with some flavorless NPCs, DF tasks you with a central goal and allows you to lead a team of fairly unique characters along a questline that has scores of opportunity to explore more of the world of Shadowrun. I enjoyed the vast majority of my time with DF, save for the hacking bits (called decking in this universe), and some later game fights with some annoyingly powerful enemies. Altough, I wholeheartedly recommend DF, Its a shame that you have to buy both to play DF but since thats the case I would advise that you buy the campaigns at a reduced cost and skip DMS.

Posted: May 7, 2014
												Highly reccomended, especially if you remember the paper n' pencil, SNES or Genesis games.  Turn based combat, but the use of cover makes for good strategy.  AI tends to target the player, and it's one of those 'if the player goes down you lose, regardless if someone could save said player' which is a stupid bit of design that's been accepted as industry standard.WARNING:  This is NOT a hand-holder, you CAN screw your build, and grinding is NOT an option.  Cash is scarce.  You must build practically, specializing in three areas:  Offence, primary role (this may be the same thing) and Survivability.  Think Fallout 1 & 2:  You can't do everything.  Thankfully, most of the time you can hire the help to do it for you.There's a few bugs here and there, and the system could use a bit of polish.  Firearms specialists feel a bit overpowered compared to mages, but make no mistake:  magic is invaluable and you'll always want at least one magic user of some sort.  Hires in Dead Man's Switch seem to have been built before the system was tested.Note that you won't likely to be able to recreate any characters from the paper and pencil game; the system just isn't the same.  Street Sam's can't have Wired Reflexes AND Dermal Plating for example, and the Wired Reflexes don't give extra AP passively like they did in previous editions.  Drain is replaced with cooldown (although casting from hitpoints remains an option).Once you get the hang of the system however, it's well worth it.  Strong builds are rewarding, and certain builds allow soloing runs on Normal, but you'll never get so powerful you can afford to get cocky.Fans of the console adaptions will be pleased, as there's plenty of shout-outs.  Highly replayable as well, due to the number of ways to solve situations depending on your build.ADDITIONAL EDIT:  I cannot recommend the Dragonfall DLC highly enough!  It includes several improvments in game design and having experience from the first game shows.  While Dead Man's Switch is definitely a love letter to the SNES/Genesis games, Dragonfall adds more depth to the characters and feels more like a true RPG with the ability to talk to a regular set of runners inbetween runs.  It is also a vastly more satisfying experience and well worth its price because it's basically a separate game entirely.

Posted: May 11, 2014
												Right... So where do I begin... The game left me with quite a mixture of feelings...Let's clear the negative bits first. The game is more linear than most linear FPS's this days (and the RPG being more linear than most FPS's says a lot). There is almost no chance to explore or approach the mission in any variety of ways. The game practically forces you from point A to point B in a most direct and unforgiving way. There is simply nothing to do in between of those points. No exploration, no looting, no chatting with random NPC - nothing.Another major let down of this game are dialogs. While generaly well written, multiple choice answers make no sense. As no matter what you reply will be, the conversations take the same course. You can flatter other NPC to high sky or you can tell them to kiss your *** - makes no difference whatsoever in majority of cases. So to cut the long story short - the game is hugely let down by its linearity. Its ultimately linear in every imaginable way - from converasations to how the missions go.But let's "knock it off with those negative waves" and be positive for a bit. First and foremost the game's atmosphere is absolutely marvellous. Considering the simplicity of graphics, sound and setting the game does absolutely fantastic job in recreating a world that, despite its linearity, is still interesting to be in. Many games, while being much more graphically advanced and running on much higher budget have tried and failed to deliver the same.The atmosphere somewhat reminds me of the first Deus Ex, only with magic, elves and orks thrown in. Same dark, run-down, but strangely attractive urban-setting of the near future. You really feel comfy, entering the pub after roaming the slums, you really want to ask bartender for a pint (shame that game won't let you) and chat with the bouncer, while you at it.The plot is fairly strong. Somewhat predictable, but still has a few unexpected twists and provides a good story. Other than that - game has a lot of potential to expand on what it has already achieved, to fix its downfalls and to become a classic in its own right. Developers have already done the most important thing - creating an interesting and immersive world. Now its only a question of expanding on dialogues, exploration, more side quests and making the game-world bigger and more detailed.So I would still recommend this game and "Dragonfall" is already on my wishlist (although not at the top). If you aren't fully convinced - just wait for big sale and buy it then. It probably wouldnt be ultimate purchase of the year, but still - few coins well spent :)

Posted: July 25, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is a great game.Think Lord of the Rings meets the Matrix for the setting : orks, elves, trolls, dwarves and regular humans dwell in the shadow of mega-corps, facing the many perils of a cyber-punk low-life. They fight, charm or oustsmart their way around the many dangers of this world with guns, cybertech and magic. The general setting is vibrant and offers a great potential for many stories.The official first campaign is good, but the excellency comes from the User Generated Contents, some of which are better than the original game. Shadowrun's online community offers a lot of different storylines that make this game virtually immortal : play as an elf shaman, a troll bruiser, a dwarven mage, an ork street samurai or a human cyber pirate (or any combination of them, or a character of your own design), assemble your team of runners and advance through the myriad of high-quality mods. Each character has its advantages and drawbacks, so a balanced team is often the best option, though sometimes brute force, magic or technological capacity can make the difference.On the gameplay, it is rather intuitive : 50% RPG, 50% turn-by-turn tactical fighting (à la X-Com) with varyinng proportions depending on the mod.Some "classes" are better suited to some roles than others but the progression system allows you to create your own build : do you want your shaman to have proficiency in firearms ?  Do you prefer him to be a pure spellcaster and go mage/shaman ? Do you want him to be extra-tough ? Do prefer to concentrate on invocations and shamanic support spells ? Do you want to sacrifice some of your spellcasting capabilities in favour of cyberware ? All builds are possible and all of them work, with various advantages and drawbacks !The different races help for the feel of the game but have ultimately little impact gameplay-wise apart at the very begining or at the very end of a campaign. Choosing to be a tough troll or a gracefull elf will give you some minor changes in starting stats and a different ultimate potential, but for most of the game the different races don't really matter.Overall, this great game is made awesome thanks to the online community (most of which is here on Steam).

Posted: November 25, 2013
												Like every game, this isn't for everyone. The default campaign is short (took me slightly north of 10 hours without skipping sidequests), it has a check point system instead of save anywhere (getting changed in Berlin DLC, unsure if being ptached in to cover default game too), lack of lootable corpses, and no voice acting. If none of that bothers you, it's worth a look. The story isn't bad, and there's a lot of dialog.My main complaints are as an RPG, it's kind of lacking content. The campaign is very linear, not a lot of tactical depth to combat, no ability to customize anything except a handful of consumables on party members, nearly all hired runners lack any personality, and reactivity is pretty sparse (i.e. special dialog for race/gender is rare). However, where this game will really shine is future content. It shipped with an ugly but powerful editor that allows modders to fix certain things (more open world questing and lootable bodies for starters). The Berlin DLC is also planned to be more open ended.Overall, a shallow but solid default campaign. The best of this game will come to the surface in the coming months.

Posted: March 1, 2014
												This is one of those games I went "must have it!" over and then, for some reason, it took me a while before I actually tried it (typical me). So now that I have I'm really happy I did!The atmosphere in the game is really something extra and I'm surprised there aren't more of this type of games instead of all those fantasy inspired ones who are basically flooding the market. Blending cybertech with magic and then puting it in a dark, corporate run society where bribes, conspiracies and espionage is a way of life really speaks to me.So, what will you get then? You'll get a linear game where you get to create your own character and specialize it the way you want it while compensating your weaknesses by hiring mercs whom you'll fight turn-based tactical battles with while following an intriguing storyline that kept me hooked from start to finish (alright, I slept in between, once!). Well constructed dialogues with lots of options that feel real and adds a lot to the feeling of the game. I  liked the music quite a bit and for those of you who also liked the first game won't go wrong with this one ;)Ohhhh! The game has a few difficulties as well to choose from, ranging from "I just want to know the story" to "I love to see my character dying".I love playing for achievements and usually don't buy games who lack them but this is one of those rare titles I make an exception for and so I give it a 4!Cons: 1 - Crap, don't buy2 - Fun for an evening3 - It's an alright game but not my taste4 - Great game5 - One of the best I've ever played

Posted: March 1, 2014
												The game was really good. I like how the story escalated from a simple investigation to taking down a whole cult organization by the end. You can tell that the story, chracters, and the whole lore have been thought through. Gameplay was fun. It's a tactical, grid-based, turn-by-turn actions. You can customize your gear and skills. And even your team. The game doesn't really hold your hand when it comes to exploring features, so take time in digging info about everything like what different skills and items can do. "I didn't know I can do that!" I said this so many times. By the time I started getting to know what everything does, the game was almost over. There is one thing that really irked me about this game: my shots just kept missing! The probability says 85%, and yet all my shots missed, like all the time! This happened so many time that I felt like that probability the game is showing is the probability of you missing. Overall, the game was great and I'm looking forward to more titles!

Posted: March 2, 2014
												Having just finished the Shadowrun: Dragonfall DLC, I would say it is a better game than the original overall, but I enjoyed both stories very much. The inclusion of the 'save anywhere' system was a great addition. It means the designers are able to make larger maps and encourage exploration. I found Dragonfall's maps were more interesting to roam around. The story is less linear which is fantastic.Choice and dialogue feel a bit better in the DLC as there are some large fights you can avoid completely if you have high charisma or the appropriate character background. I played a rifle-toting character, which just like the previous game, feels rather overpowered on normal mode. Starting ranged weapons skills at 4-5 and increasing this steadily throughout the campaign will get you through many battles faster and quicker on normal mode.

Posted: March 3, 2014
												I never played the table top or the MMO shooter no one else seems to have played either, but Shadowrun Returns hits all the important bits for a western RPG: flexible charecter progression, a plot that raises the stakes as you progress, comrades of drinking age, and a fun enviroment that doesn't need hundreds of codex entries to explain what the hell all is going on. Its good tactical fun for a reasonable price: beating the game won't make you sad to leave the charecters, but it will feel like you came from somewhere and did something. If that's not you cup of tea, go find a game where the protagonist has three love intrests he doesn't even notice in between beating up spiders and panther bear robots in his quest to slay god. 												Not a very complicated game.  While many other games have exciting engines and flashy graphics, this game harkens back to the '90s style of turn based action. Posted: July 1, 2014
												Personally I think the Sega Genesis game tops all of the rest of the shadowrun installments...I didn't play the fps for the pc that was released a few years ago but i heard that was garbage so.... Genesis still wins out, but this version is very close to the Snes version just prettier and better sound. the game revolves around clicking to talk to people, clicking to shoot them, clicking to use inventory and or special moves/spells.sometimes you do this in the matrix (not much different from the ingame rl combat.)you have to do alot of stuff to progress from one area to the next and it can feel clunky, and slow, and if you aren't a SR fan the game then Shadowlingo can be convoluted and seem ...very stuck in what the 80's thought theyd be saying in the future.    So for nostalgia's sake I like this game, the story is ok, Chery still pops into my dreams wearing that ripped shirt , familiar characters from the first game, very true to SR story line, tons of workshop content and the abillity to create your own story (true to the pen and paper SR). And you can use your initial character in a lot of the user generated content items,deck and all.So people looking for a casual rpg with a merc-noir story and lots of add ons this game is for you.Fans of the snes and sega versions will like this.none of the above? you got 30/70 chance of liking it.I give it a solid 70 out of 100. it would have scored higher with more playable options and a revamped combat system but i think we may see that with future content from the workshop.

												Shadowrun Returns original campaign:This is a very nice Shadowrun based game, with a good story and gameplay. Note that it is not a continuation of the original campaing - you cannot bring your old character into this new campaign - altough some small references can be seem during the game. It is worth mentioning that this campaign is a little longer than Shadowrun Returns original campaign, but still a very linear game. Moreover, the dificulty level is higher than in the original campaign.

Posted: July 2, 2014
												If you've ever played 2nd Edition Shadowrun this is a huge nostalgia trip - if you haven't it's still damn fun.The majority of the game plays out like an old-school text-based RPG like Fallout (no voice actors required) and will have you investigating the death of an old friend through a variety of standard 2050s Seattle backdrops.Combat, when it happens, is very similar to XCOM: Enemy Unknown. Each character has a set number of action points that they can use each turn to move, shoot, cast spells, control drones, etc. Normal difficulty shouldn't pose much of a threat (I think I've been killed twice) so once you have the mechanics of it down I'd suggest playing through on Hard or better.Slight spoiler for the main story: make sure you put some points into Shotguns.

Posted: June 5, 2014
												Shadowrun is cyberpunk meets fantasy, all mashed together with the kitchen sink thrown in. Character classes include shamans (clerics), street samurai (fighters, melee or gun-based), mages, adepts (magical martial arts fighters), deckers (computer hackers) and riggers (who control drone robots). Player character races include humans, orcs, trolls (extra large orcs), elves and dwarves.The world includes lots of fantasy monsters from spirits and giant scorpions to great dragons, and also plenty of security personnel itching to die at your hands.Decking (computer hacking), and the way computers and the Internet work in general, doesn't make any sense at all. But this is totally consistent with the Cyberpunk genre, which was generally written by people with no real computer knowledge. Inside Cyberspace, you battle ICE (Intrusion Countermeasures) and even Black ICE (ICE that can kill you in real life).I've played through the original plot of Shadowrun Returns (Deadman's Switch) and also Dragonfall. I thought that both games had really engaging stories, and were generally well-paced, had good dialogue and interesting characters. The scenes and themes fit well with a cyberpunk "high tech, low life" motif.Dead Man's Switch was very linear, with little more than dialog choices (nice answer, neutral answer, mean answer). Playing it is a lot like reading a good book that has interactive fight scenes and some inventory management.Dragonfall was less linear, with some limited ability for the player to make world-changing choices. The important decisions are all made more toward the end of the game, though. This may annoy you, or you may like it because it gives you the chance to load your game and try a different ending with only 5 minutes more investment. Also, Dragonfall has much more lively NPCs, which makes for a game that feels a bit more social and less isolating.That having been said, it's great that the stories are good, but 90% of your time in the game will be spent in fights. Almost all of the skills that you increase with experience (which Shadowrun calls "karma") are combat skills, although they have some limited utility in conversation (especially Charisma). All the equipment is combat or quest related.In Shadowrun, the fighting is turn-based, with each character on a side getting a turn (with 2 or 3 Action Points) before the next side gets to act. The huge array of options can be overwhelming, especially at first. Fighting takes place in a large variety of locales and against a wide variety of foes. Sometimes your opponents get a surprise turn against you, which can be very annoying if your main character is squishy (has few HPs), as you see the entire enemy team attack your character (who is not under cover) before you get to act. I was once killed outright this way without even having a chance to react. Fortunately, I had an item that automatically resuscitated me.The fighting in Shadowrun Returns can get pretty repetitive fairly quickly, though. Once I figured out the ideal strategy (see next paragraph), it was just a question of repeating the same operations every fight. The same strategy works every fight. The only variation is a bit of difference in tactical positioning depending on how the enemy is approaching you and the layout of cover. Take cover, buff your main damage dealers, and kill your opponents. If your opponents bunch up use grenades and area effect spells against them. Rince and repeat.SPOILER WARNING the best strategy is to take a mage and buy spells that do area effect damage or reduce AP. In a 1v1 duel you can easily steal all of your opponent's AP and just damage them every turn without ever being hurt. Other viable options include a rifle/shotgun specialist or a high-Intelligence decker/rigger. The melee characters are particularly underpowered. Use shamans as support to boost your main damage dealers with AP, HP and accuracy. SPOILER WARNING ENDThe game is a bit buggy. I frequently have trouble with character equipment, where items will switch in or out of my backpack spontaneously, or I'll see different items when in combat or out of combat. I've had rare situations where I click on a HUD button and my character moves on the map instead--wasting a turn. I encountered no critical bugs that crashed the game or prevented story completion, however.There are some usability issues. There doesn't seem to be any way to manage drone equipment. It can be awkward to manage objects found in the world, since only the character accessing the container can pick up the item, and outside of combat you only have control over your main character. The game often requires extra unecessary clicks, like when using abilities that can only be used on yourself, you're still forced to click on your sprite to self-select.Overall, I consider this game worth buying and playing, especially if you're a fan of computer role-playing games.

Posted: June 24, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is so damn likable that it's easy to overlook how mediocre it can be. The user interface is cumbersome and frequently doesn't let you do what you'd expect it would. It's janky in the way that you remember crusty old PC games used to be, except it's not charming by today's standards. The default campaign: Dead Man's Switch is unflinchingly linear and the game has some odd hitching issues. But it's ****ing cyberpunk! Despite the fact that the story goes off the rails in a rather magnificent way, Shadowrun Returns stays true to the Gibson-esque tone that you want from a cyberpunk RPG and more to the point, a sequel to the original Shadowrun. The writing is what you want from a Shadowrun game. The combat is ersatz-XCOM Enemy Unknown. I'd have a hard time calling Shadowrun Returns great, but if you're as starved as I am for its specific brand of dystopia, it's a decent fix.

This new DLC/Campaign is a great place to start because it's a bigger, fuller, better realized game.  As far as RPGs go, this is a modern classic. The characters and environment have that Baldur's Gate feel, not visually but in that they seem like people/places worth interracting with and even saving. I'm only about 6-7 hours in but it's worth recommending already.

Posted: March 15, 2014
												The original shadowrun for Sega was one of my favorate games of all time, and certainly my favorate cyberpunk game.  The amount of detail in world creation, plotline, and character development made the original game playable multiple times.Over a decade later, I was thrilled to see a sequel.  I found that the writing and plotlines were as original and immersive as the previous original.  Some things had changed, the graphics were slightly more detailed, the combat system different, and the world much smaller and more linear.  But the essence of the game, the style, and much more was enough to make the game a great experience.I was slightly disappointed at the small size of the game compared to the original, but have since discovered there will be additional content added.  Shadowrun Returns is certainly a great start, and I look forward to new content.

Posted: March 16, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns offers an enjoyable walk through a cyberpunk story, which grows larger than is really sensible.  This is a linear tale, presented in the form of the original Baulder's Gate games.  Players of games in this style may be left wanting from the gameplay.  Although the player has control over team mates in combat the player has no control over their skill point allocation and may only manage their own player in this way.  Further, there is not much variety to speak of in the combat.  I'm also warned by friends to not bother chosing to play a Decker (hacker class) one's self, as there is little opprotunity for the player to make use of this class's specialities.  Likewise, there are some conversational bonues in the Charisma attribute that can ignored altogether (I think I only saw "Academic" as a possible response category once).  I'd recommend this one for anyone itching for a Shadowrun experience, but with reservations.  I am hoping that Shadowrun: Dragonfall offers more depth in the gameplay.  I also just remembered that this was a Kickstarter project.  Great work from that perspective.  Here's hoping future installments keep up with the excellent story-telling and also satisfy more in the gameplay.

Posted: March 24, 2014
												Now, to start off, I feel the need to tell you that I have been playing RPGs since the late 1970's. About 4 years ago, I was introduced to the tabletop miniature game, "Necromunda". It's a fastpaced cyberpunk-style game with various gangs. I liked it and yet, found it missing a few things.I love Adv. D&D too. Now.. combining Necromunda with AD&D.. hmmm... I love the movie,"Blade Runner"... With all that, throwing them all in a pot and stirring... Amazement!!! The result,Shadowrun!!!  This game has it all for me! Posted: March 24, 2014
												Played the main campaign awhile ago and liked it well enough.  About 10 hours of gameplay.  I never played the tabletop version and so I'm no expert as to how closely the game remained tied to the specifics of that world, but the environment felt genuine and created a very interesting and captivating setting for the story.Main campaign is alright.  Game's not retail price and it shows.  UI and movement/cover systems are a little wonky.  Tactical combat system is a bit simplistic, as are the items and inventory management.  Everything feels just a bit... insubstantial.  Still, as I said before, the environment is interesting.  Decent music reminiscent of the old top-down Fallout games.  Game suffers from some bugs, primarily related to transition triggers (I.E. When something becomes searchable, or when an NPC shifts from neutral to enemy due to an event, things tend to go a bit off-kilter at times).  Also the original campaign suffers from a lack of a save system in favor of an uncontrollable checkpoint system that can result in some frustrating losses of progress.  You can see why they went this route -- trying to get you to just roll with the punches and accept imperfect outcomes -- but for perfectionists like me, that tends to be more irritating than provocative.Regarding the Dragonfall DLC, there are some significant improvements.  NPC characters are developed with greater depth and are generally more interesting and likeable.  Story feels more complex as well, and all of the little nuggets of Shadowrun lore strewn about are a welcome help to the immersion factor.  It is DLC though, meaning that most of the fundamental annoyances (transition trigger bugs, lag when controlling friendly NPCs not originally part of the party, Slightly sticky UI design, simplistic combat/inventory management and tactical combat system) are all still present.  Still, neither the main game nor the DLC are full retail price, so one gets what one pays for.  They did put in a quicksave function which, while not perfectly implemented, does get the job done.  Being able to save at will reduces the amount of progress you lose on the occasional progress-ending bug you may encounter.DLC is about 18-20 hours gameplay (granted I did a few things over for better outcomes).  The niggling complaints above aside, I really enjoyed it.  Good story, good NPC characters, good immersion level, and decent length for the cost.I guess my biggest complaint is that this isn't a AAA full retail title.  I would have liked to see a cleaner UI, a more complex tactical combat system, and a longer campaign.  The story was so well-written and the base environment so rich and interesting that I would have happily paid more for the opportunity to spend more time there.  Looking forward to any future DLC they may release.

Posted: June 17, 2014
												Shadowrun is a long running series, starting in 1993 as a Nintendo action adventure game, it literally blew minds with its diverse story telling. It had everything; connecting your brain to the internet, street mages, mafia trolls, crazy ex-girlfriends. the game was later adapted into a paperback rpg that has had a relatively strong run. ( its in its 5th edition.)Shadowrun Returns; Deadmans switch and its superior, Dragonfall, takes place in 2070, about 10- 20 years after the events of original. Deadmens switch is an adventure through the city of Seattle, fighting through deadly cultist plots and drek crazy doctors you manage to avenge your old partner’s death. While dragonfall is and intricate story about investigating a mysterious force in berlin while your attempt to battle forces that would appose the flux state. I belive the game play is quite sharp for a turn based game, delivering multple layers of complexty with its various custom class archtypes (rigger, adept, shaman, samurai, mage, decker, ect) you can play a muscle mage, or a shooty hacker, or any combination there of. next there's the multiple layers of customization, from bio mods to specll selection you have a large library to chose from. I've thoroughly enojoyed my adventures in the dark, an impatienly await the coming additions.

Posted: March 18, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is set in a fantastic, cyberpunk, distopian earth, where mega-coorporations are running the show, drug dealers roam the streets, and mercenary adventurers, called "shadowrunners" take on dangerous work for the highest bidder. On top of everything else, magic has returned to the world, which puts a novel spin on the whole cyberpunk setup.This game has a brilliant atmosphere, captivating from the start, pulling you into the dirty streets of a blade-runner-ish seattle, and putting you into the skin of a shadow runner. Shadowrun returns features a great story, with lots of twists and reminds me of the Torment due to its emphasis on dialogue, rather than battles. On the downside it's very linear, with only a couple of occasional options for side-quests. But this is not necessarily that bad, because it focuses on the plot and tells the story without infinite distractions and pointless errants.Highly recomended for RPG fans who are not aversed to exploring a futuristic, cyberpunk world, very similar to the worlds of Gibson's "the neuromancer", or Stephenson's "snowcrash" but still very unique in its own right.

Posted: May 21, 2014
												To clarify, what this is not, is a sprawling open-world RPG with endless space to explore and fight and level up with the same character until you become and unstoppable behemoth that Blizzard is targeting premium content at on a daily basis. If you want that, look elsewhere.Yes the graphics are a little retro, personally it works for me, it may not for everyone, if it doesn’t for you - since there are a huge number of videos and photos available to see before purchasing the game, I find whining about it a little childish, no?What this is, is a fun and engaging storyline and an amazing opportunity for user generated content to provide a huge wealth of different experiences. To challenge yourself to find different solutions and to challenge yourself to myriad different play styles.The user generated content will get there, and when it does, there will be so much to this game (that the studio could never have afforded to produce) that I foresee loosing many many hours blissfully jacked in.If you doubt any of this look at the amount of user generated content for the dungeon crawler Legend of Gimrock, what you buy is a single campaign that takes a day or so to complete, what you get access to is a vast wealth of user generated dungeons created by people who, with the intricacy of their level design and fiendishness of their traps and puzzles, make the guy in the Saw films look like he really wasn't trying. If that can happen with this game (which I’m sure it will so long as the level creation and modding tools are there) it will be awesome.

Posted: July 1, 2014
												I just finished "Dead Man's Switch" of Shadowrun Returns and I really enjoyed it. Just a heads up before my review, the main reason I purchased this game is because I used to play the table top version of Shadowrun back in highschool. Just the product's name brings back great memories and my review (and enjoyment of the game) of course is partially biased due to this background. Here is a quick review for those interested in the title:What is "Dead Man's Switch"?Think of Shadowrun Returns as the client, and DMS as the story you plug into it. There is also a DLC that I've purchased but not started yet that is another story for Shadowrun Returns. I'm hoping they will continue to support this product! Game Mechanics:Smooth, easy to learn, and well done. The game plays like the first Fallouts or the Baldur's Gate series as an overhead tactical turn-based gameplay. With that said you do not need any prior experience with this type of game to enjoy Shadowrun Returns. The menu, UI, and rpg elements are all straight forward. The only thing that bothered me about the combat UI was reloading my rifle, however I'm sure there was a hotkey I could've used. Story vs. Action:The biggest compliant I saw on my own research of this game prior to purchase was the amount of dialog. The team that created this game obviously aimed to reproduce a table-top setting that focused primarily on storytelling, not combat. There are plently of short engagements throughout this product and I felt the combat was very satisifying. However, if you are the type that clicks quickly though dialog in other games you won't be impressed with this title. The best part of this game is the story and for those don't care about that and just want an action / adventure title should look elsewhere. If you have any direct questions please comment below! I just wanted to hit those two points since they I felt they were not communicated well in other reviews.

Posted: June 25, 2014
												I was a huge fan of the SNES Shadowrun game.  This new game not only is a worthy follow-up, but a true sequel!  Shadowrun Returns improves on all the shortcomings SNES players had to tolerate, as well as bringing the game into the modern age.  For a budget game especially, everything about this game is well balanced.  The hand-drawn graphics are slick and the lighting is pretty and immersive.  Character development is satisfying and the story is truly interesting and perfect for the world of Shadowrun.The only aspects of this game that reveal its price tag are the limited sound effects, character art and voice dialogue.  But let's be honest - how much more often do voice-overs ruin a game?  Besides, the core of the game is true and enjoyable, the limited art is beautiul and detailed, and the action is as polished as the latest X-Com game (which is also a treat.) 												This is a really nice game that is similar to the old style of adventure games like Baldur's Gate and Fallout, the dialogue and narritive writing is detailed and very fun to read becausr the author spends time on describing intricate details of a scene and ties it together into a readable flow which you don't normally find nowadays in games for storytelling.I'm only 5 hours in and I'm enjoying the writing as much as I do the gameplay itself, it is an RPG with turn-based combat, a feature which the game has taken from the old styled RPGs is the one where your custom designed character has a set of attribute points which are used for calculating results in combat as well as being useful when exploring or dialogue situations  (my character is good at hacking computers so I can open doors and access areas which would otherwise be inaccessible to me if I didn't have the correct skill points). Posted: November 30, 2013
												GRAPHICS:  The difference between the 3D character models and the 2D backdrops and portraits really couldn't be greater.  The backgrounds of this game really help set the ambiance, being very dreary, weathered, and overall unpleasant.  The game occasionally contrasts this with very nice areas, but only to emphasize the feel of how dirty and unkempt the rest of the game world is.  All the praise and honors I give the 2D artists I would take from the 3D designers.  The characters are incredibly low-poly.  Think somewhere around Goldeneye for the Nintendo 64.  There definitely could have been improvements in the quality of the models.  That being said, you walk into this game knowing it isn't exactly Crysis.  The game's focus is in getting you into the story.  And it does that exceedingly well.REVIEW: Overall, I am having a lot of fun playing this.  The game has a really good story and a fantastic environment that really holds itself together, even with new plot points and characters introducing themselves.  It's very reminiscent of Deus Ex in it's view of the not-quite-near future, and I found myself wandering all around the game, talking to the people because I wanted to, not because I had to.  Conversations options are plentiful, not just a "Yes, I will do the mission" or "Not now".  You can be an♥♥♥♥♥to people, or you can kiss it.  Conversation options unlock if you have a certain amount of skill points in that specific area, much like the Fallout series.  If you are able to say the unlocked option, it usually helps you out with better prices or more specific information.One of my favorite aspects of the game was the fact that not all of the game was accessible because of the class I chose.  I am a hacker class, but I poured too many stat-points into combat.  This locked me out of rooms I could have gained access to if I had more hacking skill.  It enhances replayability by quite a bit.  Another element was the different fighting styles and the enhancements you can unlock.  The game seems designed to cater to specializing in one or two unique skill paths, or else you don't really get many fun abilities in combat and conversation.  This is not a bad thing by any means, but there is that feeling of regret when you see a skill you really want in a skill tree you haven't invested in.The combat is tile and turn-based.  It found quite a bit like the new X-COM combat, but without permadeath, and more weapon options.  It also resembles Fallout combat in some ways.I have always found point-and-click games tedious and fetch-questy.  Many of these games say to the developer "Hey, we have a game that you could reasonably complete in a couple hours.  Milk three more hours out of it." Shadowrun Returns respects the player's time.  I never noticed myself retracing my steps or stopping playing because I didn't want to "go all the way back there" in-game. It's much more movie-esque, where the next big scene/event is at the destination, not right where you are after you collect the three Orbs of Annoyance and Plot Forgetting from three obnoxiously far-apart places in game.  I'd really recommend this game, and for people who really enjoy a good story, you can't miss it.  Personally I enjoy taking my time and soaking in the game.  The story is great, and I really enjoy the conversations as well as combat.  This may not be your cup of tea, though.  If you power through the game, you'll miss all the good stuff and find it lacking polish.  But the fun of this game does not give itself away, you have to lose yourself in it to find it.For me, 9/10.

Posted: May 18, 2014
												Let's get one important thing out of the way: Shadowrun Returns *needs* the Dragonfall DLC. [EDIT: Now that Dragonfall can be purchased standalone, this game has no real reason to exist] Without it, you're doomed to a story-on-rails campaign built to satisfy gun-monkeys and leave less combat-oriented classes in the dust, to say nothing of an inferior save system.Basically, Dead Man's Switch should be considered bonus content. Dragonfall is the real game.And what a game it is. Characters feel real, like they've been lived in for a while, not just plopped all one-dimensional and tabula rasa into the story. They have motivations, interesting origins, disagreements, and so on. They feel like actual people. And those people breathe life into the story -- a conspiracy yarn full of magic, intrigue, and high-tech low-lives. Choices are difficult. There's often a clear division between the morally right and wrong choices, but the consequences muddy it up. Is it better to spare some schlub for the sake of conscience if missing a payday means you can't stop far greater evil down the line?Combat is kind of a stripped-down X-Com affair with turnbased isometric squad stuff. It's serviceable, but the real treat is the writing.

												To clarify, what this is not, is a sprawling open-world RPG with endless space to explore and fight and level up with the same character until you become and unstoppable behemoth that Blizzard is targeting premium content at on a daily basis. If you want that, look elsewhere.Yes the graphics are a little retro, personally it works for me, it may not for everyone, if it doesn’t for you - since there are a huge number of videos and photos available to see before purchasing the game, I find whining about it a little childish, no?What this is, is a fun and engaging storyline and an amazing opportunity for user generated content to provide a huge wealth of different experiences. Posted: July 1, 2014
												I just finished "Dead Man's Switch" of Shadowrun Returns and I really enjoyed it. Just a heads up before my review, the main reason I purchased this game is because I used to play the table top version of Shadowrun back in highschool. Just the product's name brings back great memories and my review (and enjoyment of the game) of course is partially biased due to this background. Here is a quick review for those interested in the title:What is "Dead Man's Switch"?Think of Shadowrun Returns as the client, and DMS as the story you plug into it. There is also a DLC that I've purchased but not started yet that is another story for Shadowrun Returns. I'm hoping they will continue to support this product! Game Mechanics:Smooth, easy to learn, and well done. The game plays like the first Fallouts or the Baldur's Gate series as an overhead tactical turn-based gameplay. With that said you do not need any prior experience with this type of game to enjoy Shadowrun Returns. The menu, UI, and rpg elements are all straight forward. The only thing that bothered me about the combat UI was reloading my rifle, however I'm sure there was a hotkey I could've used. Story vs. Action:The biggest compliant I saw on my own research of this game prior to purchase was the amount of dialog. The team that created this game obviously aimed to reproduce a table-top setting that focused primarily on storytelling, not combat. There are plently of short engagements throughout this product and I felt the combat was very satisifying. However, if you are the type that clicks quickly though dialog in other games you won't be impressed with this title. The best part of this game is the story and for those don't care about that and just want an action / adventure title should look elsewhere. If you have any direct questions please comment below! I just wanted to hit those two points since they I felt they were not communicated well in other reviews.

Posted: July 1, 2014
												This has been an interesting experience! Isometric RPGs have been rapidly winning my heart back even since ME 3 and this one was a fresh change from the normal recipe.The skill system is nicely portrayed, gameplay is fun and with a lot of choices and the story brilliant enough to keep you invested ( don't expect crazy or unexpected plot twists here ) My two major cons here are the general linearity of the game , which doesn't allow much on the exploration department and the lack of plentiful side quests (which probably goes side by side with my first complain) This game CRIES for side questing and the characters it introduces are SO WELL portrayed that it's arguably a crime that there is no further development with them or some involving quests to further enjoy them in action (Coyote's quest for example should have been done for more characters!) There is your occasional side quest , but they are SOOO few that it makes you feel sad moving on to the next chapter like this. Finally i was REALLY bummed by the length of the main campaign .. I mean okay i understand that you guys were betting on the UGC (user generated content) to maximize replayability but really that short ??? You could have made an at least +20 hours on the Dead man's switch . Oh well..Pros:+ Beautiful Skill system+ Fun Gameplay+ Enjoyable storyCons:- Too Linear (for an RPG)- Very few side quests - Main campaign TOO BLOODY SHORT!All in all did i fully enjoy this game? Yes Could i have enjoyed it EVEN more ? DEFINITELY YES Do i recommend it? well yes if you are an RPG fan you will enjoy this for what it offers. But maybe try and get it on a Sale as i did

Posted: July 1, 2014
												I just finished "Dead Man's Switch" of Shadowrun Returns and I really enjoyed it. Just a heads up before my review, the main reason I purchased this game is because I used to play the table top version of Shadowrun back in highschool. Just the product's name brings back great memories and my review (and enjoyment of the game) of course is partially biased due to this background. Here is a quick review for those interested in the title:What is "Dead Man's Switch"?Think of Shadowrun Returns as the client, and DMS as the story you plug into it. There is also a DLC that I've purchased but not started yet that is another story for Shadowrun Returns. I'm hoping they will continue to support this product! Game Mechanics:Smooth, easy to learn, and well done. The game plays like the first Fallouts or the Baldur's Gate series as an overhead tactical turn-based gameplay. With that said you do not need any prior experience with this type of game to enjoy Shadowrun Returns. The menu, UI, and rpg elements are all straight forward. The only thing that bothered me about the combat UI was reloading my rifle, however I'm sure there was a hotkey I could've used. Story vs. Action:The biggest compliant I saw on my own research of this game prior to purchase was the amount of dialog. The team that created this game obviously aimed to reproduce a table-top setting that focused primarily on storytelling, not combat. There are plently of short engagements throughout this product and I felt the combat was very satisifying. However, if you are the type that clicks quickly though dialog in other games you won't be impressed with this title. The best part of this game is the story and for those don't care about that and just want an action / adventure title should look elsewhere. If you have any direct questions please comment below! I just wanted to hit those two points since they I felt they were not communicated well in other reviews.

Posted: May 2, 2014
												This ain't your nephew's Dragon Age 2 or Witcher. Instead of going for needless voice-overs and cheesy cutscenes, this game aims purely for great dialogue - in written form. For the uninformed, dialogue in written form is a tradition which had been going on for many, many centuries.What you're getting here is an Old School western RPG, very reminiscent of the first two Fallout games. It shares two of their biggest strengths - great writing and interesting setting. The biggest detriment is that the gameplay here follows an extremely linear plot. That wouldn't be so bad, if the game also didn't feel so short. It's absolutely adequate for the price you're paying, but you can't help but feel like there's something missing when you arrive at the end. However, that may just be, again, because of the very, very good writing.Despite the fact that barely any dialogue choices and actions has a greater impact on the story, this game inspires one to play through it again with different characters and mindsets - just to read all the NPCs' reactions to all the dialogue choices. I can't stress that point enough. Some people notice the difference between 'okay' writing and great writing, and some think of AAA titles as high art.DRAGONFALL DLC:Dragonfall, in two words: Pretty amazing. For me, what really makes Dragonfall stand out in comparison with the original campaign, is the difference in plot structure.For one thing, the game is much less linear. There are several missions to do in the middle section of the game; these can be done in any order you want, and it's entirely possible to skip one (maybe even two) of those missions.Another major improvement is the fact that companions stick with you and are there to talk to after every mission. There are more than enough of these permanent companions hanging around that you never have the need fore hired companions. The original campaign had a great variety of interesting characters who would accompany you for a mission or two; here, they stick around and have new dialogue after every major mission. There's character development, and in the end, there's even closure.Which brings me to the ending. Bluntly put, it's really, really good - enough to be a major point in this review. While the original campaign left you no choice in the end and the feeling of closure was kinda missing, Dragonfall delivers both in the end, and it does so very, very excellently, too. You are not only given a very meaningful choice which has the potency to shape the future of the setting, but the consequences of that choice are also portrayed adequately. After the end of the game, you are given one more chance to talk to every NPC of the main hub, every one of your companions and even new NPCs, depending on your choice. There's closure for every character and your choice is possibly being questioned in some of the best dialogue of the game. But, lastly, the best thing about this DLC is that it delivers more of the old. Shadowrun shines when you get to interact with strong characters and are given absolutely free reign - the first Harlequin dialogue from the original campaign comes to mind - and there is much of that, here.

												Shadowrun Returns original campaign:This is a very nice Shadowrun based game, with a good story and gameplay. However, it is a short game and as soon as you learn how to optimize the character skills (and the enemies AI failures...) it is an easy game, even in the very hard mode. Note that it is not a continuation of the original campaing - you cannot bring your old character into this new campaign - altough some small references can be seem during the game. It is worth mentioning that this campaign is a little longer than Shadowrun Returns original campaign, but still a very linear game. Moreover, the dificulty level is higher than in the original campaign.

Posted: March 15, 2014
												The original shadowrun for Sega was one of my favorate games of all time, and certainly my favorate cyberpunk game.  The amount of detail in world creation, plotline, and character development made the original game playable multiple times.Over a decade later, I was thrilled to see a sequel.  I found that the writing and plotlines were as original and immersive as the previous original.  Some things had changed, the graphics were slightly more detailed, the combat system different, and the world much smaller and more linear.  But the essence of the game, the style, and much more was enough to make the game a great experience.I was slightly disappointed at the small size of the game compared to the original, but have since discovered there will be additional content added.  Shadowrun Returns is certainly a great start, and I look forward to new content.

Posted: March 16, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns offers an enjoyable walk through a cyberpunk story, which grows larger than is really sensible.  This is a linear tale, presented in the form of the original Baulder's Gate games.  Players of games in this style may be left wanting from the gameplay.  Although the player has control over team mates in combat the player has no control over their skill point allocation and may only manage their own player in this way.  Further, there is not much variety to speak of in the combat.  I'm also warned by friends to not bother chosing to play a Decker (hacker class) one's self, as there is little opprotunity for the player to make use of this class's specialities.  Likewise, there are some conversational bonues in the Charisma attribute that can ignored altogether (I think I only saw "Academic" as a possible response category once).  I'd recommend this one for anyone itching for a Shadowrun experience, but with reservations.  I am hoping that Shadowrun: Dragonfall offers more depth in the gameplay.  I also just remembered that this was a Kickstarter project.  Great work from that perspective.  Here's hoping future installments keep up with the excellent story-telling and also satisfy more in the gameplay.

Posted: March 24, 2014
												Played the main campaign awhile ago and liked it well enough.  About 10 hours of gameplay.  I never played the tabletop version and so I'm no expert as to how closely the game remained tied to the specifics of that world, but the environment felt genuine and created a very interesting and captivating setting for the story.Main campaign is alright.  Game's not retail price and it shows.  UI and movement/cover systems are a little wonky.  Tactical combat system is a bit simplistic, as are the items and inventory management.  Everything feels just a bit... insubstantial.  Still, as I said before, the environment is interesting.  Decent music reminiscent of the old top-down Fallout games.  Game suffers from some bugs, primarily related to transition triggers (I.E. When something becomes searchable, or when an NPC shifts from neutral to enemy due to an event, things tend to go a bit off-kilter at times).  Also the original campaign suffers from a lack of a save system in favor of an uncontrollable checkpoint system that can result in some frustrating losses of progress.  You can see why they went this route -- trying to get you to just roll with the punches and accept imperfect outcomes -- but for perfectionists like me, that tends to be more irritating than provocative.Regarding the Dragonfall DLC, there are some significant improvements.  NPC characters are developed with greater depth and are generally more interesting and likeable.  Story feels more complex as well, and all of the little nuggets of Shadowrun lore strewn about are a welcome help to the immersion factor.  It is DLC though, meaning that most of the fundamental annoyances (transition trigger bugs, lag when controlling friendly NPCs not originally part of the party, Slightly sticky UI design, simplistic combat/inventory management and tactical combat system) are all still present.  Still, neither the main game nor the DLC are full retail price, so one gets what one pays for.  They did put in a quicksave function which, while not perfectly implemented, does get the job done.  Being able to save at will reduces the amount of progress you lose on the occasional progress-ending bug you may encounter.DLC is about 18-20 hours gameplay (granted I did a few things over for better outcomes).  The niggling complaints above aside, I really enjoyed it.  Good story, good NPC characters, good immersion level, and decent length for the cost.I guess my biggest complaint is that this isn't a AAA full retail title.  I would have liked to see a cleaner UI, a more complex tactical combat system, and a longer campaign.  The story was so well-written and the base environment so rich and interesting that I would have happily paid more for the opportunity to spend more time there.  Looking forward to any future DLC they may release.

Posted: March 27, 2014
												The original game is an excellent RPG with exceptional storytelling. The first DLC expansion, "Dragonfall," is a work of art. I found myself worrying about my companions emotional lives during a run, and I looked forward to coming home to our safehouse and wandering the neighborhood to chat with the locals as much or more than speculating on what our next action-packed job might entail. I actually teared up at the terrible beauty of the entirely unexpected conclusion, and unlike most of my favorite games, Dragonfall didn't leave wanting more, because the ending fit--perfectly. I am, however, eagerly awaiting any future Shadowrun installments from Harebrained Schemes. After this, their RPG work is on my buy-on-release list.
