Posted: September 17, 2014
												You! Yes, you.  You like fantasy RPGs? You like strategy games? You like Sci-Fi? Ever wanted to mash 'em together into a delicous nerd smoothie?  Then do we have a product for you.If you're an XCOM fan, the mechanics are pretty straightforward to you.  Honestly, Shadowrun Returns as simply a game is good, but not great.  The Karma system for leveling allows you to customize your character however you like with no limitations on class, though you'll want to specialize as you approach endgame.However, Shadowrun Returns -- Shadowrun as a whole -- is so much more than a game.  It's a living, breathing world; a technologically heightened and magic-infused setting for stories of any kind.  Plots might hinge on the epic and esoteric (dangerous research into blood magic by a ruthless, profit-hungry megacorp) or the throwback noir with a twist (being hired by a dead man to find his murderer).  Sure, most of the RP of this RPG happens via old-school plain text, but you know what they call plain text in most places? Books. It ain't broke, so don't fix it!Character creation remains fun to me, even after a few playthroughs.  It's pretty neat to tell your friends about your human shaman/street samurai who packs enough heat to take on a militia even before summoning his elemental spirits.  Or about your pink-haired elvish techno-wiz equally at home jacking into corporate Matrix blocks or rigging into her homemade combat drones with her very mind.  Moreover, the skills your character chooses will assist them outside of combat, unlocking alternate routes, hidden passages with loot, chances to solve a problem diplomatically (with added EXP!), and more.The campaign that ships with the game, Dead Man's Switch, is a bit short but satisfying nonetheless.  It's an excellent introduction to the Shadowrun world, and veterans of the series will even see a few familiar faces.  Dragonfall, the DLC whose remastered version will drop tomorrow, is just plain phenomenal.  And that's not even touching the free Steamworks fan-made campaigns, some of which are truly brilliant.  Harebrained Schemes, the devs of Shadowrun Returns, have reminded us that a great game doesn't need 60 fps or 360-noscopes. You just need solid mechanics, a fascinating setting, and some hardcore writing chops.Be sure to check out the pen-and-paper Shadowrun RPG, too!

Posted: December 3, 2013
												I've played this game for ten hours before I eventually got too frustrated and uninstalled.What I thought when I first encountered it was a misstep, (the lack of any save/load game feature), turned into a death knell -- you WILL reach moments in the game, where despite your best planning you are left in the worst condition you could be and are unable to continue.In a typical RPG, you would restore to an autosave or a quicksave or otherwise from somewhere earlier on and roll the dice again, presumably to try and get a better result from a combat sequence -- you'd be free to because a regular game recognises the mutability of each instance of combat and provides you that opportunity. That is NOT the case in this game: if you get to the penultimate area of a mission with no health, dead team members, or no supplies, you must either run through the situation over and over from their awkwardly placed checkpoints, or start the entire mission over again from BEFORE you initiated it. This includes talking to all the NPCs, watching unskippable cinematics, recruting new team members, purchasing supplies, levelling up, and travelling to the mission area. Depending on how much preparation you require, you may spend more time in preliminary prepping than actually playing the game, going over the same (admittedly clever and consistent) dialogue, losing its significance each time.This surely seems like an issue that one shouldn't harp on, but consider how elemental even a rudimentary save system is to any RPG you've ever played, and then remove it. How many opportunities are there to say that it was a universally good choice? In this game, the absence is so notable that it almost renders the game worthless.As for the positives, the game is set in the legendary Shadowrun universe, fully realised in video game form! The writing is quite often witty and on point. There is a potential for infinite content with the open authoring tools.It's worth buying if you think you can deal with the big drawback, but it is a big one.

Posted: October 17, 2014
												As a first time experience, this game had me really enjoying the whole concept of shadowrun. I must say as someone who wasn't a fan before, this game had really opened up my experience and mind to the world of shadowrun.Gritty, dark and futuristic environment really appeals to me as I was not a fan of cyberpunk before, however this game has really helped introduce this genre as its environment was well designed enough to keep me interested.However, some gameplay elements can be rather repetitive and the base storyline is rather bland, however the additional campaigns online makes up for it, thank goodness for indie campaign creators (do mind me if i used the wrong terms, am new at this)Overall, a 7/10, good game, and great way to introduce people to the cyberpunk genre.

Posted: November 25, 2013
												Like every game, this isn't for everyone. The default campaign is short (took me slightly north of 10 hours without skipping sidequests), it has a check point system instead of save anywhere (getting changed in Berlin DLC, unsure if being ptached in to cover default game too), lack of lootable corpses, and no voice acting. If none of that bothers you, it's worth a look. The story isn't bad, and there's a lot of dialog.My main complaints are as an RPG, it's kind of lacking content. The campaign is very linear, not a lot of tactical depth to combat, no ability to customize anything except a handful of consumables on party members, nearly all hired runners lack any personality, and reactivity is pretty sparse (i.e. special dialog for race/gender is rare). However, where this game will really shine is future content. It shipped with an ugly but powerful editor that allows modders to fix certain things (more open world questing and lootable bodies for starters). The Berlin DLC is also planned to be more open ended.Overall, a shallow but solid default campaign. The best of this game will come to the surface in the coming months.

Posted: December 3, 2013
												Back in my SNES days, Shadowrun was by far my favourite game.  These days, that's the only game that really sticks in my mind when I think back to playing that console.  Over the years I have tracked where the game was going.  Horrified that Microsoft bought the rights, but thought maybe they'll do something good with it.  Nope.  2007, I saw it was just another first-person shooter, not tied to the Shadowrun universe, I sadly concluded there was no chance of ever seeing another Shadowrun game like the one on SNES.  Guess I'll have to install a SNES emulator and play the original (never got around to it).Then I was cruising around Google Play last week, when Shadowrun Returns showed up on my recommended list.  OHHHH.... darn.  No tablet.  Yet.  But tis on Steam, and it works on Linux.  REJOICE!  I tried it for a few hours and so far it's looking great.  I played both the Dead Man's Switch campaign provided by Harebrained Schemes, and a story someone is putting together to replicate the SNES version.Thanks Microsoft for giving the game's rights back to Jordan Weisman!  Thanks Jordan and HBS for bringing back the world of Shadowrun to our screens!  Thanks  Kickstarter for the campaign to fund HBS' development.  Thanks all who provided funding!  Had I known the campaign existed last year, I would've contributed for sure.

Posted: July 23, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is a tactical strategy rpg which functions similar to the X-Com or UFO series games, set in the Shadowrun universe. Pros: *Nice Artstyle*Simple yet effective combat and skill system, allows you to more or less build your "class" by picking which stats and skills you want to learn.*Lands the Shadowrun Universe pretty wellCons:*Very short playthrough (core game, not the Shadowrun: Dragonfall expansion)*This game is very easy on "normal". I recommend to anyone that has played the genre before to play on the hardest difficulties.*Could use more weapons/armor/configuration. I kept feeling like there should be another drop or weapon coming soon... and it never does.Overall: 7/10Fun game, looks nice, but it's very short and could use more content and story. I am about 5-6 hours in (2 did not get recorded by Steam), and I would say according to the chapter list on most websites I'm about 75% through the game. I am looking forward to trying the expansion however, and I will update my review when I get the chance. Many reviews for the expansion title seem to point out that it's a bit more complete and a touch longer than the core campaign.I would purchase this game again, since I bought it on sale... but I don't think I would pay full price for it. This is a good pickup if you catch it on sale, and if so I would grab the expansion to go with it, otherwise the game may feel a bit incomplete.

Posted: August 22, 2014
												A great game, lovingly recreated to resemble the old super nintendo game I used to love.  The turn based gameplay works really well and the karma system for levelling up gives limited scope so decisions must be made carefully, rather than having a fully levelled up character before too long.  Dead Mans Switch felt linear and the responses felt as though they didn't really change the game outcome much, however the expansion, Dragonfall, addresses many issues including the ability to save anywhere.  Dragonfall is a much more honed Shadowrun campaign in my opinion and deserves an applause for the production team who clearly thought hard about the game story and characters.  A triumph.

Posted: August 22, 2014
												Overall, I would give this game a 9/10. Everything is fantastic, and I cannot wait to play Dragonfall someday and also play player-created campaigns. I am also inspired to pick up the paper and pen version of Shadowrun, as well as Shadowrun Online. It's just that Dead Man's Switch became quite disappointing. Just take it out, or give the players more freedom, and everything here would be stellar.*****Now for ***SPOILERS*** Kind of.*****I have not played Dragonfall, so this review is of the main campaign, Dead Man's Switch. I really enjoy pretty much every aspect of this game--the environment, combat, characters, atmosphere, etc.--except for the main story. Despite getting very interested in the storyline after the first few lines were presented to me, almost all of my excitement was lost when the Ripper was revealed. I was having fun treating DMS as a murder mystery; I was carefully examining everything and trying to figure out who the Ripper could be--I even had some evidence to support who I thought could be the Ripper--but the game pretty much points a huge sign at the real suspect from the moment they are introduced, and this is overwhelmingly disappointing. The other side of the story after the reveal doesn't even make much sense.

Posted: June 15, 2015
												My playthough was about 15 hours total. I went with a Troll who specialized in unarmed combat, and I really enjoyed the powerful hits that would sometimes one-shot enemies. It was a little annoying not being able to get all the little secrets that require decking skills, but I managed just fine without the extra stuff.Pro:  Lots of community contentLots of class/race options and tons of ways to build a character, and lots of spells/skillsWell-executed turn-based combat with a cover system akin to X-COMGreat story that pulls you into the world of Shadowrun (very text-heavy, enjoyable for those who like to read)Con:The RNG seems off sometimes (e.g. a 90% chance to hit might fail three times in a row)The story is very linear, and there isn't a new-game+ option

Posted: March 3, 2014
												Solid Turned-Based RPG.I found the overall game to be solid.  Well written, enjoyable storyline wrapped with some great mechanics.  Complaints about a very linear campaign are accurate.  However, considering the price and solid execution, I feel that is more than forgiveable.  This isn't an RPG with lots of side content or derivative bits to distract you from the main story.  As mentioned, at $15 or even $20, I think that the offering is more than fair.  My only complaints are that while polished, the story and gameplay are forgettable.  The game is entertaining enough to pull you through the campaign but not memorable enough to bring you back for nostalgic purposes.  On the contrary, it will probably give you a craving for some older classics such as Baldur's Gate, Planescape Torment or Fallout.

Posted: March 4, 2014
												This expansion for Shadowrun Returns (by Hare-Brained Schemes) evokes the old-school grand scope of classic Bioware RPGs.  More than just an expansion campaign, Dragonfall improves on the original engine in many ways, and responds directly to many complaints about the original.  Even better, it translates those improvements (like a new save system) to the original campaign as well, so folks new to the series entirely can enjoy the improved engine from the start.  The result is an improved product all around, and a memorable and enjoyable RPG set in one of the most fun alternate universes ever created.  An excellent set of custom creation tools add to the potential life of the game, as the mod community may well produce some masterpieces of their own, down the line.

Posted: March 4, 2014
												I never played the original Shadowrun (SNES and Sega Genesis, apparently), but after playing Shadowrun Returns, I'm going to find it.Shadowrun Returns is one of the few games in the "RPG" category that is, in fact, a Role-Playing Game. Unlike Dungeon Siege, Diablo, BioWare Game or Final Fantasy, Shadowrun actually requires you to interact with NPCs and the manner of those interactions actually impacts the game. Imagine that. So many games claim that NPC interactions affect outcomes, but this is the first game I've played in a while (not including the Elder Scrolls/Fallout 3 sub-genre) in which that's actually true.Dead Man's Switch (the original campaign) has a little bit of important dialogue, but Dragonfall (the first DLC campaign) is LOADED with character development and NPCs that actually behave differently depending on how you treat them.But the beauty of Shadowrun Returns isn't the official campaigns. It's the editor, and the integration with Steam Workshop. I've not actually used the editor yet, but judging from the vast range of quality in the user-created content, it must be pretty easy to use. On the one hand, that means a LOT of just pure garbage content. On the other hand, it means that learning how to use the editor isn't a stumbling block for somebody who's got a great story to tell.So while the original campaign is really quite good (I mean really, really good. It's one of the few campaigns of any game that I'm perfectly happy replaying several times in a row), Dragonfall really showcases what the game's engine is capable of.If you've ever played the old Fallout games (Fallout, Fallout 2, Fallout Tactics), this is a lot like those. If you haven't played those, think of it as turn-based, squad-based Diablo, with almost no emphasis on gear. There is an equipment treadmill, but it's not very involved. More along the lines of Mass Effect 2.There are three or four pistols (for example), and you buy the most expensive one you can afford. So while there IS a reason to make more money and get the better stuff, it's not the need that it is in other games (Diablo, for example). Sorry to keep making the comparison to Diablo, but that's the other game I've been playing most recently.Shadowrun Returns is also one of the few games I've played that knows how to use a touchscreen. Most games work "well enough," but SR has a touchscreen mode that makes it function beautifully. And by "beautifully," I mean that the PC version plays just as well on my Dell touchscreen as the Android version plays on my Samsung Note 2.I don't know if anyone but me cares about that, but with the increasing prevalence of Windows 8, I figure it's worth mentioning.I know I'm making a big deal about Dragonfall, and I mean to. It's an excellent campaign, and is actually (in my opinion) worth the price of a full expansion pack, as opposed to the increasingly-common 2-dollar DLC. But I suppose I should really talk more about Dead Man's Switch. It's an engaging mystery with great characters. It doesn't have the meaningful dialogues and character developmnet of Dragonfall, but I was immediately taken with both Dresden and Kluwe. They're not "important" characters, but the fact that placeholder roles are filled with well-fleshed and well-written characters is just indicative of the attention to detail paid by the devs. It's a well-polished introduction to the world of Shadowrun.

Posted: March 4, 2014
												Okay, I finally have to write a little something after playing the Dragonfall DLC.First off, to quickly go over Shadowrun Returns:  Let me preface this by saying I am a kickstarter backer.  Back when SRR popped up on Kickstarter, I immediately jumped on board.  I'd been craving the old-school SR like the ones on Genesis and SNES which I played when I was hardly into my teens, and everything in the KS pitch sold me that this would bring it back to those days.  When SRR finally released and I played through it, I came out satisfied.  It has a solid and deep story, good combat (which has since been balanced and improved), fairly simple puzzles, and yes..it had some flaws like no manual saves (again, resolved since then), but it didn't really bug me that much.  Most of all, they made choice matter.And then along comes Shadowrun: Dragonfall.   Dragonfall absolutely oozes greatness.  There's insane depth of characters and the world, down to the smallest details, even in conversations with side characters like Simmy Kim and reading the Shadowland BBS.  It's a very rare thing where a game captures me so well that I sit and read every single piece of text I come across (and there's so much to read in this series).  I especially appreciated the design in this DLC of having the quest hub, but more importantly, there were so many more rich side quests throughout the campaign than in the base game.  They also upped the design on the puzzle elements a bit which I appreciated (the original campaign's were generally way too straightforward).  But enough of a wall of text, let's break things down:Story: Phenomenal.  Aside from the depth of lore in this world, the story of this campaign alone was so great.  Just when you     think you've got things figured out, something throws you for a loop.  You face lots of decisions that test your morals, many of which mostly seem to test just how close to "the line" you're willing to step, or if it's even a question for you.Characters: Great.  This time around, you've got a dedicated crew.  Sure, you could hire runners to go along with you, but the crew is where it's at.  They've got deep stories and I loved every bit of exploring them.  The SRR Dead Man Switch campaign had people occasionally joining you, like Coyote, but those companions pale in comparison to the attention given to the crew of Dragonfall.  I cared about my crew.  Hell, I felt bad that I always had to leave one member behind on my runs having only room for a team of 4.  I felt like I was neglecting them most of the game and that they were going to confront me about it at some point.Combat: Solid.  I played on hard difficulty, and essentially did the same rifle-focused street samurai build I did in SRR.  I found it much more balanced, and there were several missions with some real tension as the fights raged on.  The Matrix served a good purpose as well; it felt much more key to this campaign than the first.Graphics: Beautiful.  They already established this with SRR, they just painted a whole new world for Dragonfall's Berlin setting, and it's gorgeous.So that's it in a nutshell.Final verdict: Worth buying?  Abso-freakin-lutely.  This is an rpg not to be missed.

Posted: June 26, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns and its DLC's are a great way to immerse oneself in this excellent RPG and novel setting. The game is really easy to master and anyone who has played X-COMM, for instance, will find Shadowrun easy. A word of advice though, be very thorough in searching for clues and other hidden objects, especially at the beginning. Going straight into fights without these is missing most of the fun. My only criticism about this game is that it lost one of the coolest elements in the RPG: the planning part. Although, there is a recruitment and resupplying phase before missions, the actual planning is limited to a bare minimum (no possibility to get any map of the area beforehand, for instance). That's a bit too bad, especially since it makes the choice of team members before each run a random game. Apart from this, great fun game.

Posted: June 23, 2014
												My review is of both "Shadowrun Returns" as a game engine, and the included "Dead Man's Switch" story. Overall, I give it a massive yes. If you enjoy tabletop RPGs, cyberpunk, or science-fantasy... get this. It's not without it's flaws however. Shadowrun Returns - The game engine is a powerful story creation tool, and it's simple to use as far as these things go. However, there are some interface issues during gameplay, as I made accidental moves on more than one occasion. But overall, it's a solid game engine that will provide many dozens of hours of fun with custom stories and the steam workshop.Dead Man's Switch - Let me start by saying that it's not very interactive. The world is well built through text and visuals, but you can't really do much with it. Any actual role playing comes in with your dialog options, rather than your behaviour in the world or choices in the story progression. If you don't mind a very scripted RPG experience then this story is really good. In fact, it's better than good, the writing is just amazing. It was like an interactive novel in some ways, with well written dialog, a "page turner" of a story, and great world building. I knew little about the Shadowrun universe before this game, and now I feel like I've just paid a visit to it.As a whole, Shadowrun Returns is an excellent bargain purchase for the price that will please tabletop, Shadowrun, and story rich RPG fans.What the frag are you waiting for!? Buy it, drek-head!

Posted: July 1, 2014
												This has been an interesting experience! Isometric RPGs have been rapidly winning my heart back even since ME 3 and this one was a fresh change from the normal recipe.The skill system is nicely portrayed, gameplay is fun and with a lot of choices and the story brilliant enough to keep you invested ( don't expect crazy or unexpected plot twists here ) My two major cons here are the general linearity of the game , which doesn't allow much on the exploration department and the lack of plentiful side quests (which probably goes side by side with my first complain) This game CRIES for side questing and the characters it introduces are SO WELL portrayed that it's arguably a crime that there is no further development with them or some involving quests to further enjoy them in action (Coyote's quest for example should have been done for more characters!) You could have made an at least +20 hours on the Dead man's switch . Oh well..Pros:+ Beautiful Skill system+ Fun Gameplay+ Enjoyable storyCons:- Too Linear (for an RPG)- Very few side quests - Main campaign TOO BLOODY SHORT!All in all did i fully enjoy this game? Posted: July 1, 2014
												I just finished "Dead Man's Switch" of Shadowrun Returns and I really enjoyed it. Just a heads up before my review, the main reason I purchased this game is because I used to play the table top version of Shadowrun back in highschool. Just the product's name brings back great memories and my review (and enjoyment of the game) of course is partially biased due to this background. Here is a quick review for those interested in the title:What is "Dead Man's Switch"?Think of Shadowrun Returns as the client, and DMS as the story you plug into it. There is also a DLC that I've purchased but not started yet that is another story for Shadowrun Returns. I'm hoping they will continue to support this product! Game Mechanics:Smooth, easy to learn, and well done. The game plays like the first Fallouts or the Baldur's Gate series as an overhead tactical turn-based gameplay. With that said you do not need any prior experience with this type of game to enjoy Shadowrun Returns. The menu, UI, and rpg elements are all straight forward. The only thing that bothered me about the combat UI was reloading my rifle, however I'm sure there was a hotkey I could've used. Story vs. Action:The biggest compliant I saw on my own research of this game prior to purchase was the amount of dialog. The team that created this game obviously aimed to reproduce a table-top setting that focused primarily on storytelling, not combat. There are plently of short engagements throughout this product and I felt the combat was very satisifying. However, if you are the type that clicks quickly though dialog in other games you won't be impressed with this title. The best part of this game is the story and for those don't care about that and just want an action / adventure title should look elsewhere. If you have any direct questions please comment below! I just wanted to hit those two points since they I felt they were not communicated well in other reviews.

Posted: October 17, 2015
												As someone who's never played Shadowrun previously, I'm pretty happy with the system mechanics and how the story folds out. I played it on Very Hard difficulty, which didn't actually seem all too difficult (if anything, I felt like my team missed their attacks more often than they should have). This is also based on the Dead Man's Switch campaign, which comes with the game.I customized my character originally as a Rigger, focusing on Drone Control, with a few levels in Pistols. I later added Decking to my skills, keeping its levels even with my Drones, and it seemed to work out very successfully, in that I never felt that my character was over-reliant on my companions other than for additional damage output.The game does have a couple of bugs in some places: the first major one I noticed was when I bought level 2 Decker abilities, where they did not show up in my inventory/stash at all after I bought them. I had to trust the game actually did register that I possessed them, as they were also absent from the store (which is normal if you already had it), and later on in the game, when level 3 Decker abilities were made available, the behavior seemed to correct itself.The other major bug I found was in the room for the final battle (I'll try not to be spoilery). There are pieces in the room which are either active or inactive, and to keep the battle more manageable, you want to keep all of them inactive as much as possible. However, there were a few instances where I couldn't actually target an active piece (quicksave/loading fixed this), and a few times where a piece appeared inactive, but I knew based on enemy behavior in the battle that it was actually active.

Posted: November 13, 2015
												While I like this game a lot, others may not, depending on what they're expecting.If you are expecting any edition of the tabletop role-playing game, or the Genesis or SNES console games, you will be disappointed.  Shadowrun: Returns plays something like a simplified version of tabletop rules that never actually existed.I liked the plot, combat, and music.Opinions on the plot vary widely.  If you have an aversion to reading, this game is not for you.  Almost all of the plot is delivered via screens of text upon entering an area, or text dialogs.  There is no voiceover.  Some people complain of purple prose, or that it seems to have been written by someone that is immature, but the writing is superior to that in most video games, including most other RPGs.  I personally do not perceive any of these problems, and have never seen examples cited.Screenshots do not do the combat system justice.  Some of the interface is only displayed when it is relevant.  For example, the action point cost of movement, and the effectiveness of cover, only appear when you prepare to move, and when cover exists in the area you mouseover.  The combat system is relatively simple (which is reflected in the user interface), but like Chess, can be quite difficult.  The difficulty is selectable at character creation, so if you find the game too easy or hard you can adjust it.  Since almost all RPGs are combat-heavy, it's important that it not be mindless and repetitive.The music is hard to describe.  It is not ambient.  You will notice it.  I especially like the theme on the title screen.I didn't like some things about Shadowrun: Returns.It is very linear, and most decisions will not affect the ending.The gameplay in the matrix is very similar to meatspace.  It's not so much that the gameplay in the matrix is bad as it doesn't feel different enough.The game only saves on area transition.  If you have to stop playing, or die, unexpectedly, you can lose quite a bit of progress.

Posted: June 22, 2015
Pros:+ Solid storyline+ Various builds that change how you play+ Rewarding, challenging combat+ Clever puzzles+ Bug-free+ The game ends on exactly the right noteCons:- Game is a bit short; campaign lasts roughly 20 hours if you do everything- Relatively low replay value- Straightforward campaign; for the most part, you stay on a single track through the main campaign, with only a couple chances for sidequests- Charisma/Etiquettes*- Specializing is required.  Jack of All Trades type characters don't do well.Overall: Shadowrun Returns is fun.  You get to hire a crew and go do odd jobs as a mercenary in a futuristic dystopia.  The tone and music fits, the game gives you just enough money to get by and forces you to spend wisely, and the storyline is fast paced and fun.  The game is short, and there's not many chances for optional sidequests, but in spite of that the overall experience is still great.  If you're a fan of tactical isometric roleplaying games, this is a solid choice.Bottom Line: A wild ride from start to finish, with fun characters, rewarding combat, and enjoyable gameplay.  A little short and straightforward, but well done in spite of this.  Worth the price.* The charisma system in game works by giving you various "etiquettes" which will open up conversation options if you know them.  Some etiquettes are extremely useful, others are entirely pointless.  Consult a guide when choosing which etiquettes to learn.

												Besides Mass Effect, its been a very long time since I've found a roleplaying game that I've really enjoyed.Honestly, Shadowrun Returns blew away my expectations, especially since I didn't really have any going into it. I knew that it was based off a classic sci-fi tabletop RPG, but that was about it.The first campaign, The Deadman's Switch, draws you into the world of Shadowrun very well, introduces you to some characters, and generally how the game works and feels. It's a nice introduction to the game, but it does have a few things that annoyed and irked me. Especially the linearity of it all. It was one story the whole way through, with not many different ways to approach things, or side quests to take up your time.That's why I recommend getting the Dragonfall expansion with it. I've played the expansion for three or four hours at this point, and all of my problems with the original game have been taken care of, as far as I can tell. There are a lot more things put in place to sidetrack you, and I really like that.But, there's also the horde of player created content that the game allows access to, and that could provide a lot more gameplay than the original campaign allows for, therefore not necessarily making the Dragonfall expansion worth it, but I recommend it none-the-less.

Posted: July 2, 2014
												Shadowrun Returns is an adaptation of the classic cyberpunk tabletop pen and paper RPG. Set in an alternative history future where magic has returned to the world, elves, dwarves, trolls, and orks live side by side with humans in dense urban cities, and corporations are a law unto themselves; the game centers around the segment of humanity who makes their living in the shadows, the runners. Hacker, mercenary, detective, sorcerer, where there is a job that needs doing, there will be someone willing to get paid to do it.The game itself is a single player, turn-based strategy RPG, utilizing 3/4 isometric perspective with 3D character models set against sprite based backgrounds. The sprite backgrounds are static and well done, while the character designs are somewhat poorly textured with resolution below that which the majority of modern systems could easily handle; belying the limited budget the company had to work with. Gameplay takes the form of point and click interaction with the world map and carries over directly into combat, utilizing the same environments. Combat is somewhat klunky, as there are problems with the interaction of the courser and corners of the movement field.The game itself is, however, merely a platform. It is in reality intended for players to build and share their own Shadowrun campaigns, and the full game editor comes included with the base game as well as a professionally developed campaign. Thanks to Steam Works, player campaigns are free, though professionally developed campaigns will be sold as DLC as they become available. Sadly there is no multiplayer option what-so-ever, crippling one of the intregral elements of the pen-and-paper game.Overall, the game's campaign will run you around 12 hours, and is a good buy if you can get it on sale, for any enthusiast of turn-based strategy RPGs.

												A diamond in the rough.Some people have problems with the engine and it's true, it is far from perfect. The Checkpoint system bugged many, and I thought it would get on my nerves when I first read of it but in the end it didnt bother me at all. The game has a variety of bugs but after I beat it last week they've already patched many of them.The music was made by the guy that made the music for the SNES game aswell as the guy that made the music for the Genesis/Megadrive game set in the Shadowrun world so they know their stuff.The graphics are Both beautiful but in terms of animations on the characters, sort of stiff.So the battles tend to look abit worse than when youre just walking around the world in awe of the neon glory that is the Shadowrun world.The battle system is very close to the one in the 2012 Xcom remake so all is good there.Where the game really shines is it's storytelling and characters. Posted: November 29, 2013
												Shadowrun Returns' turn-based, old style XCOM-esque gameplay is solid and set in the fascinating mix of cyberpunk and high fantasy that is the Shadowrun world. The vanilla storyline is compelling the first time around, but loses much of its appeal on replays due to the lack of meaningful choices or varying narrative paths. Ultimately, no matter what you do or say, you always end up at the same place and talk to the same characters. However, the diversity in the character building/class system does much to keep the game interesting across multiple playthroughs, with Deckers, for example, playing much differently from Mages or Street Samurai. Overall, a good indie title that is well worth the price if you're a fan of the turn-based tactics genre or the Shadowrun lore.

Posted: July 28, 2013
												This game is absolutely great from top to bottom. The main game is a well written and well paced piece of murder mystery cyberpunk action, made with great writing and interesting characters. The writing is so good, in fact, that even characters that show up just once or twice feel really memorable. The graphic style and musical design are top notch and really help make the experience into a cohesive whole. The gameplay is a solid tactical RPG experience that's fun to play, if a bit on the easy side more often than not. The few downsides to the game start with the lack of manual saving. The game automatically saves at checkpoints (probably to prevent save scumming like some other tactical games) which can sometimes be frustrating. The locked angle camera usually is okay, but there are times where it's a problem. Some people will call a 12 hour, very linear main campaign a problem too, but I personally think that it's better to have 12 high-quality hours than 20-25 with lots of filler. So it's not perfect, but it's damned well done. And the inclusion of an editor means that in the end we'll hopefully see a lot more great content from the community.

Posted: February 7, 2016
												Being new to the PC/Steam community, I was astoniished and a little overwhelmed when I began browsing the Steam store for the first time. Something I am sure many people have experienced.I kept at it and as I searched through the  of numerous titles available along came Shadowrun Returns.....Now, I have been gaming for many years and one of the highlights was playing Shadowrun on the SNES (Super Nintendo). This game was such fun and the world so diverce, it is one of those gaming experiences you never forget!To find this gem among so many other great titles on Steam made my day, a chance to return to the Shadowrun world.The setting is a future Cyber Punk world, centred around a strong story driven experience with RPG/Turn based action elements. It is a game you can play when you want to lose yourself for an hour or often more. It is not as complex as other turn based stratergy/RPG titles, but still as rewarding due to an excellent murder mystery story line. It is above all an excellent place to start for people wanting to give this type of game a go. I have not played the other subsequent titles that have been released, but fully intend to as they each in turn expand the game and it's complexity with new functionality. Just check out the reviews/videos for the rest of the series available! For the price it's a steal for any gamer and will open up a new exciting experiences. Just like the SNES game did for me many years ago.Give it a go, you won't be dissapointed.

Posted: December 25, 2013
												I marathoned this game. It is fantastic. It reminds me of Infinity Engine games like Neverwinter Nights and Baldur's Gate, only the combat is much easier to wrap your head around. The setting is cyberpunk (William Gibson and Neal Stephenson specifically) mixxed with high fantasy. The module that is included in the game is a fun story, but don't be surprised if you call out plot points well before they happen. I've only played through it once, but my class choice (decker) seemed pretty useless in most situations. I am hoping Harebrained Scheme puts out a few more modules of their own.There is a module creator and it looks like the community has put out quite a bit of content on their own. I'm looking forward to sinking a few hours investigating that over the weekend.

Posted: November 30, 2013
												Shadowrun has always been a great universe. It is a real shame that it doesn't get as much attention as tradition D&D universe. So this game is much needed break from you're typical RPG. The storyline in the main campaign is pretty good but not super orginal or great. It  did kept my attention enough that I played it for over 8 on the first day I got it. It has some flaws though that may take away from the enjoy of the game. First it is a very linear game, you don't get much chance to roam around. Even more sad then that is you never really use some the advanced skills like Decking at all really. The second issue is it lack of a save anywhere feature. Even though I played the whole in nearly one sitting it was a difficult to play it through only  been able to set checkpoints. This limits the replay value because most of us, myself included normally cannot play a game without being dragged back into the real world at random times. Doing some parts of the game more then once because of fairly spaced out checkpoints wasn't so bad. It did however give the game a limited time to play or to replay without having a large amount to play it. The promise of new updates on the way and the steam workshop makeup for some of the flaws so I would recemmmend this for any RPG fan looking for a new take on the typical RPG.

Posted: January 8, 2014
												This game had an excellent sense of immersion in to the world of Shadowrun. I have enjoyed playing both the released main content of Shadowrun Returns as well as many of the player workshop campaigns. One of the biggest selling points was in shipping a very useful editor that put the power of creating these campaigns in the hands of the player community.That being said there are a few rough spots. The current save system (which appears to be replaced in the next DLC Dragonfall) only provided save points at the start of a map, which means in order to save ones progress you would have to complete the section you were on and move to the next load in area for it to record your progress. The replayability was also argueable. While I enjoyed some of the subtle changes each class could bring to the different dialogs and oppertunities that would arise, the game is unfortuantely very linear. Even with those subtle changes the overall story will progress the same way. The linear story did, however, showcase many different aspects of the Shadowrun world and in my opinion was successful in introducing players to different creative aspects they could explore while making their own content for the game. You have sections of story running through the matrix, attacking a corporation and even fighting through zombies. For 20$ I found the game to be worth my expectations and have played a total of 58 hours so far between main story and workshop content. I have no regrets with my purchase.

Posted: September 15, 2015
												EDIT: After reading some other reviews, I figured I'd add that this is based off of the Dragonfall campaign. After reading them, I am horrified of the idea of playing the original campaign.Excellent story. Great idea. Utter rubbish gameplay.Originally I enjoyed this game. Then I started realizing how hard it was, even maxing out skill lines for each character, to do...anything.There is no actual tactical combat in this; your team blindly follows your character until they blunder into an enemy group, who immediately gets to react and take cover and shoot you up. You can only take cover once you've already entered combat, and you cannot manually start combat; the enemy starts combat for you EVERY TIME.Not only that, but there are either really bad bugs relating to gunshots to enemies or - and this is pure hypothesis I've come up with because there's no documentation beyond the description of Body - the Body attribute makes it so there's a chance for every single attack to only deal half damage...meaning every single attack roll has three rolls: whether you hit, whether you crit, and whether it's weak, and enemies have a higher Body score than you seem able to achieve and have a decent chance of hitting at anything but point blank range, meaning while they may not hit as often, it will hurt more. It got to the point I started quick-saving before ever shot, and my own experiences suggest that you need to take about 30% off of the shown percentages for attacks (even on the easiest difficulty level), because 99% misses about 1 out of every three attacks, and I've only occasionally landed hits with percentages below 55% (call it 1 in 20 or more).Want a definite bug that's gone through every patch thus far? When firing an assault rifle on full-auto, once one of your five shots misses, every other shot misses. Always. It doesn't matter if you've got a 99% chance to hit; if your first attack roll is that 1%, you won't hit anything at all.Oh, and you can't carry more than one weapon of a particular class, which means you can't carry both a sniper rifle and an assault rifle, because they're both RIFLES. If you want to have both long- and close-range options you have to split your karma points (XP/skills) on two SEPARATE weapons.And my personal favorite screwed-up design option? Every conversation pretends you are by yourself. You can have (or be) one of the most skilled deckers ever on your team, but you don't have an option to ask him to hack a terminal except in very rare circumstances. You can have a troll on your team with tremendous strength, but it's YOUR strength that matters for bashing things down in conversations. YOU have to know things, rather than being able to delegate or actually ask your freaking teammate who's standing RIGHT NEXT TO YOU. I totally get some of this in games like Pillars of Eternity, because some of what you do is in the spirit world and only you can interact with it, but even there some of it irks me (because I should be able to have someone else light a fire with their face if they're the right race), but at least they let you use teammates for a lot of stuff. Here, though? We're seriously talking about maybe three times in the entire game where you get to use the skills of someone else on your team, out of hundreds of times skills and attributes are checked.I wanted to like this game. I wanted to want the Hong Kong game that came out after. But after repeatedly coming across the stuff above, as well as the most recent problem I've had where there is endless combat heading into the final battle even when there are no enemies around, and my game is corrupting save games made during combat, which means I can either run the entire last level with nothing but autosaves, or run the (high) risk of having to start over from the beginning......I cannot like it, and I cannot recommend it to anyone unless they're incredibly masochistic. Finishing this game has become a task I have to force myself to do, and even then the game is preventing me from doing it with this corrupt savegame issue.

Posted: January 5, 2014
												Pay attention, everyone. THIS is how you adapt a tabletop system to a videogame. Shadowrun Returns is what that looks like.The game is mechanically sound and tactically interesting. The combat is straightforward enough to pick up easily, but as you upgrade your character and progress through the game, your options and strategies become more complex. Character progression is also quite well-handled; although you have tremendous freedom in choosing how to spend your "Karma," the game seems to do an excellent job of keeping all your choices balanced and avoiding game-breaker builds.All of this is backed up by a lovely, slick interface (with just the occasional hiccup or quirk), an excellent soundtrack, and a content editor so that users may make their own campaigns. I have not tried the editor, but there is no shortage of custom content in the Steam workshop right now, so I presume it works.The default campaign is quite solid, itself. It acts as a perfect introduction to this universe, and features exceptionally strong writing- something I can't say about nearly as many games as I'd like. A good portion of my enjoyment of Shadowrun Returns came directly from the strength of the setting and story. (The final twist is a bit of a letdown, but in the context of everything that has already happened, it feels alright and is easy enough to overlook.)Make no mistake, if setting and story aren't your thing and you'd rather play something more strictly gameplay-oriented, this is really not that game. I say that not because the gameplay is lacking, but because the story is given such high priority. You will spend a lot of time talking to people. Interesting, well-written people, but not everyone cares for that.If that doesn't sound like a problem to you, then I would absolutely recommend this game.

												Yeah i funded the kickstarter, im so cool ~ ^.^This game is pretty fun, if you like very good story, better than actual gameplay

Posted: August 2, 2016
												As a fan of the Shadowrun tabletop RPG setting since way before playing the videogames, I can say this game is a dream.Shadowrun Returns is based on a setting that I know and love for a long time. The main campaign has great writing and it feels like it was made for old time fans. But the best idea is the editor. This tool was a dream for people like me, that spent hours creating shadowrun adventures that where never played to the end.The world of Shadowrun takes some time to understand. It is a cyberpunk future where magic has returned, elves, dwarfs, orcs and trolls, dragons and magical swords get along with high-tech cyberware modifications, virtual realities that you access directly in your brain and self-conscious AIs. The gameplay of Shadowrun Returns is turn-based combat and text dialogues, no voice-acting. Still, the story is worth reading.Great game, offers a lot, but it is just a first step. The sequels are now a much better option.Positive points* Very faithful adaptation of a tabletop RPG* Easy to play, also on AndroidNegative points* Limited combat and character options* The editor engine is not optimized, you have to buy the sequels to have access to better options.

Posted: January 3, 2014
												As mentioned in other reviews, character modeling could be better, and the music could have more variety, but I've greatly enjoyed playing it. It's not a long campaign, but it's not so short. It took me 15 hours to finish it, and I loved every one of them. The best points, imo, were the background (as I've been roleplaying since the 80's and I used to love the original paper rpg), and the story. I think this campaign had a lot of what Shadowrun players used to love, with a strong storytelling, beautiful sets and 2D artwork, and enough of the cyberpunk world to fit a story of this length (not too much, not too few).And for the weakest points, I've missed looting bodies after a shooting, and that kind of stuff, but I guess it's just a balance factor to get rid of and simplify the system. But as I started the game with a pistol, and my oponents had shotguns, I could have used one of those, and sell the others! xDAnyway, I highly recommed playing it, it was great fun and made me want to play the paper rpg again! :)

Posted: February 3, 2016
												I am not sure how to review this game because it has clear faults, and there are things that I wish were done better, yet I really enjoy it to the point that I know own the next 2 versions as well.That says a lot and anyone who enjoys turn based xcom style games probably will enjoy this one as well, albeit it is closer to Terror From The Deep than the most recent 3D offerings graphically.I didn't know anything about the setting for this game and it is as good as any I guess, not really my cup of tea but the game makes it worthwhile. Generally everyone is downtrodden and you are one of the few fighting against the injustice / being a thief because those you are fighting against are legally in power. If you want your character to be pure (Thing DnD Lawful Good) then you are in the wrong setting as a result, but I got over it (And all my DnD characters ARE Lawful Good).Character classes seem diverse, though it looks like melee probably has a hefty 'being shot in the face on the way' penalty but there is little in the way of nuance. You have 1 'stat' and then health, anything put into other areas just diversivies your abilities and weakens you. No spreading points around for a smooth talking gunsmith for example, or at least not if you want to be good at either.In fact as far as smooth talking goes there isn't really such a thing, all skills are combat related.Combat is good though, animations are ok, story is good and I imagine gives a very good introduction to the setting so it feels like you are being introduced to a franchise but done very well rather than forced onto you. By the end of the game I expect you will also be looking for more. Thankfully there already are more!

Posted: February 9, 2016
												Love this game.  I originally got dragonfall thinking it included the first one (Shadowrun Returns) and having not played any of them before and not touching any turn based games in years it was, very hard to me.  After reading that SRR is a bit slower and better to learn from I got it and have been learning a lot more about playing.  Even as I'm not that great at it and still get killed a lot and have to redo parts, it's still an amazing game. I am hard pressed to want to read dialog in most games.  This one is interesting enough that even though it is very heavy on the dialog, I find that the writing is well done, enough that you don't wan to miss anything.  It's not a lot of empty writing like filler or fluff but it drives the story and most times there are details you don't want to miss, or you might not be able to get to the next part.  The characters have personality even without the fancy voice acting and 3d character animations and cutscenes.  I'm so impressed I plan to return to Dragonfall after this, and Hong Kong is already in my library too.  (those reviews to come later) Tip for new players in this game - pay attention to your builds, learn how to use the Karma points, search for tips and tutorials if you have to or it is indeed a frustrating game to the newb.  Stick with it, it is well worth playing through - even though i'm sure I have quite a ways to go, I'm enjoying every minute.  Highly recommended!

Posted: January 2, 2016
												Shadowrun Returns is a story-driven RPG with something akin to XCOM's combat system (albeit a few tweaks and more customization per character).  There isn't any choice that drives the plot in a different direction but there are multiple ways to deal with the smaller scenarios you're presented with, such as how to get into a blocked off area.  These ultimately do not affect the larger story but it's nice to have these smaller interactions in lieu of that.Also, some dialog options are locked behind choices you make during character creation, and occasionally others are behind skill checks.  So that plus the multiple routes in each level makes up for what I imagine were budgetary constraints that prevented a multi-path narrative.  It was a Kickstarter after all.  I don't know if this is the case for the future titles in the series, so don't judge those based on this.  I'm only talking about the base game.The skill system in this game is satisfying, using a steady stream of points instead of levels.  I like all the different ways I can customize my character.  The classes all feel varied and interesting, and they fit the world really well.Shadowrun is well written, even if the story is not revolutionary.  It has fast paced dialog and isn't overly wordy, like the aforementioned Pillars of Eternity, or most games which people claim are "well written."  It doesn't bog you down in detail, yet it also provides quite sufficient descriptions to give you a good understanding of everything.  Sometimes the world's "slang" feels a bit cheesy (like using 'frag' instead of ♥♥♥♥).  I love a world that has its own slang, like in Clockwork Orange, but that slang was far more believable.  I don't believe for a second that people would say frag and stop saying ♥♥♥♥.Even with a bad story, I'd still be interested because the world that this is set in is fantastic.  It's a cross of D&D, Blade Runner, and Deus Ex.  I've not played any of the other games/tabletop games in this ruleset before so the whole thing is new to me, and I really found myself drawn into it immediately.  The only critique is that it's too bleak to be plausible.  No society with the technological capability of this one could crumble to the place that this one does.  Still, it is a work of fiction, and it's established well enough to overlook the unlikeliness of it.  The story deals with serious subjects like drug addiction, racism, torture, etc. but it also manages to keep a lot of levity in there as well.  It takes itself seriously enough, but not to a point where it's brooding or depressing at all.Overall it's a nice little game which I've enjoyed far more than many other releases.  I avoided the game for its middling reviews, but I am upset that I did in retrospect.  I'd have liked to play these games earlier when I was searching for something to play.  I really love the XCOM type combat, the classes are all interesting, the story is sufficient, and the world is really great.And this is gonna seem strange, but there's some real oomph to when characters get shot, and that has made me want to play the game almost more than anything else about it.  There's something about when games make something feel right that I just love.  I played Spiderman 2 on PS2 for dozens and dozens of hours just because of how web slinging felt correct.  I remember playing San Andreas and thinking about how differently each of the cars felt from one another, and how they all felt right in their own way.  This game, the way it feels when you shoot someone and it makes impact, it just feels correctly made.  I realize that there's probably nothing more subjective than to say that I enjoy the way it feels to shoot enemies in this game, but it's my review, so whatever.  Get the game.

Posted: March 19, 2015
												I know who Jordan Weissman is and am aware of many things he's done, but I had no idea Shadowrun was anything more than a video game, much less something of his; all I've ever known it as was, until this version, a Super Nintendo game.  But then I went looking for a wiki for this game, and holy crap at the decades of history.How have none of the tabletop-playing, hard-RPG grocking people on my friend list showed me this?  Damn Magic: The Gathering ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥s, keeping the cool stuff all to yourselves <.< It hits like 20 of my sweet spots....its a cyberpunk Blade Runner-esq style (does anyone else remember Johnny Mnemonic? it smells a lot like that, only good.), its an isometric turn-based RPG like those of old (FALLOUT!!), etc. Now I gotta buy Dragonfall when it goes on sale, until then I'm gonna toy with some of the user-created campaigns on the Workshop to see what people can do with the tools available to them.I'd give an actual, proper review/recommendation, but honestly considering its age and history, if you care about Shadowrun (or anything else bearing Jordan Weissman's name) at all, you probably already know more about it than I do, I have to google certain words they use to understand what they're saying xD but I really dig the atmosphere and the gameplay is...well, Blade Runner-style isometric turn-based (AP system, not one move per turn, think Fallout rather than Final Fantasy) RPG, that about covers it. The thing you picture after reading that sentence is very close to being accurate.

Posted: February 8, 2016
												Rating: 7/10Budget: Worth it. Replayability: Low - The story doesn't change enough to warrant an additional playthrough. Length: Good - Custom missions too. Shadowrun Returns is actually a really great game. I have a few issues with it. You have to pick a playstyle extremely early in the game, and it's very difficult to know what is the right choice for you - Especially seeing as you have no way of controlling what classes your companions in the game will have. This is actually a much bigger problem than one might initially think. I tried going for a non-combat build, actually. I wanted to be the "face" of my party, but have my goons fight for me. Didn't work out - impossible to play this way. You HAVE to be able to fight SOMEHOW, so this was a letdown for me. Especially considering how much of the game you can actually ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥t your way through later on. It's also fairly easy to make a character who is simply so good at fighitng that you can kill everything the game ever sends your direction. The games combat system is a bit rough and while a good translation from actual shadowrun, there's a reason that system is a bit of a cult novelty - It's just very rough in general. Over-all good game, but read a guide or something to save some frustrations.

Posted: February 3, 2016
												I am not sure how to review this game because it has clear faults, and there are things that I wish were done better, yet I really enjoy it to the point that I know own the next 2 versions as well.That says a lot and anyone who enjoys turn based xcom style games probably will enjoy this one as well, albeit it is closer to Terror From The Deep than the most recent 3D offerings graphically.I didn't know anything about the setting for this game and it is as good as any I guess, not really my cup of tea but the game makes it worthwhile. Generally everyone is downtrodden and you are one of the few fighting against the injustice / being a thief because those you are fighting against are legally in power. If you want your character to be pure (Thing DnD Lawful Good) then you are in the wrong setting as a result, but I got over it (And all my DnD characters ARE Lawful Good).Character classes seem diverse, though it looks like melee probably has a hefty 'being shot in the face on the way' penalty but there is little in the way of nuance. You have 1 'stat' and then health, anything put into other areas just diversivies your abilities and weakens you. No spreading points around for a smooth talking gunsmith for example, or at least not if you want to be good at either.In fact as far as smooth talking goes there isn't really such a thing, all skills are combat related.Combat is good though, animations are ok, story is good and I imagine gives a very good introduction to the setting so it feels like you are being introduced to a franchise but done very well rather than forced onto you. By the end of the game I expect you will also be looking for more. Thankfully there already are more!

Posted: January 5, 2014
												Pay attention, everyone. THIS is how you adapt a tabletop system to a videogame. Shadowrun Returns is what that looks like.The game is mechanically sound and tactically interesting. The combat is straightforward enough to pick up easily, but as you upgrade your character and progress through the game, your options and strategies become more complex. Character progression is also quite well-handled; although you have tremendous freedom in choosing how to spend your "Karma," the game seems to do an excellent job of keeping all your choices balanced and avoiding game-breaker builds.All of this is backed up by a lovely, slick interface (with just the occasional hiccup or quirk), an excellent soundtrack, and a content editor so that users may make their own campaigns. I have not tried the editor, but there is no shortage of custom content in the Steam workshop right now, so I presume it works.The default campaign is quite solid, itself. It acts as a perfect introduction to this universe, and features exceptionally strong writing- something I can't say about nearly as many games as I'd like. A good portion of my enjoyment of Shadowrun Returns came directly from the strength of the setting and story. (The final twist is a bit of a letdown, but in the context of everything that has already happened, it feels alright and is easy enough to overlook.)Make no mistake, if setting and story aren't your thing and you'd rather play something more strictly gameplay-oriented, this is really not that game. I say that not because the gameplay is lacking, but because the story is given such high priority. You will spend a lot of time talking to people. Interesting, well-written people, but not everyone cares for that.If that doesn't sound like a problem to you, then I would absolutely recommend this game.

Posted: November 27, 2015
												TL;DR - Great story/setting, great character customisation, levels/gameplay is fairly linear which restricts the RPG elements of the game, overall a really fun game, worth the money, just have to take it as it is. Before I give my thoughts on this game, I'd like to make it clear that this is the first Shadowrun game I have played, although I am aware of the franchise and it's history. (Tabletop, PC/Console games etc.)Story/Setting: The game overall is pretty solid and good fun. It has a decent story with twists and turns and an amusing ending. You encounter likeable characters and the world is a great representation of Cyberpunk, with it's own take on things with the addition of magic.  Character Customisation:You get to make your own runner at the start of the game and there is a lot to work with from melee characters, armed characters, Deckers (hackers), Riggers (drones), Mages (spells, traps, heal), Shamans (Similar to mages, can also raise spirits, creatures and demons). However where this game shines is you really have the power to go all out with one type of class or mix any of them and make a unique build of your own. (I think I got all the classes correct there. Or near enough!) I'd say this game has great potential for replay value as you could try out all the different classes avaliable, however it wouldn't be something you'd jump straight back into after compleing in my opion, as the story and levels are fairly linear.Mechanics/Gameplay:Everything works as it should in this game and I encountered no issues at all. However I would say the game is a little lacking in RPG elements in my opinion. Let's call it CRPG-Lite! (That was terrible)A couple of areas that came to mind; In conversations you do have the ability to convice, bribe and use etiquettes to persuade and win people over to your side which you would expect with an RPG, but, what I feel was lacking was that you can't really♥♥♥♥♥♥someone off in dialogue or make them hate you and never talk to you again like you can in some RPGs, ultimately conversations (It would appear) all have the same conclusion, you just have little things you can do here and there if you spec'd in charisma, you bribe them or have the correct etiquette.I think this is because the levels and story are fairly linear for an RPG that it can't really give you that freedom. There are oppourtunities that you can miss out on if you give the wrong responses, but in an RPG I want it to be truly diverse in the sense that I can ♥♥♥♥ up an oppurtunity and then I have to go out of my way find another way to achieve my goal/quest. This game ultimately always seems to come to the same conclusion regardless. The other major area that felt a little lacking was the combat, it has the average top down, turn based combat mechanics but I wish it was more like Wasteland 2's. You can get behind cover, but some you can't shoot around, your character literally can't step out with one foot and shoot around a doorway or down a corridor. Just a bit more control over combat and the ability to make better stratergies would have made the combat near-perfect!Other little issues I had were things like not being able to examine the environments other than what the devs wanted you to see. Lack of dialogue/text box like in most RPGs, that displays examine text, Character thoughts and NPC dialogue etc.Overall:Overall this is a really fun game, I played it through in a few days and was pretty glued to it. At first I was a little disappointed with the lack of RPG elements I'm used to, but I quickly accepted that Shadowrun is it's own thing and does it a little differently. I'm really impressed with Harebrained Schemes and that they've successfully brought back Shadowrun. Now I have Dragonfall and Hong Kong to play, and from what I hear they've been improved a lot from this game!

Posted: September 11, 2015
												So, finally completed this and although I liked the story, and it has the potential to contain a lot more depth than the newly released Chronicles (multiplayer support) I was a bit dissappointed that the story is quite linear, unless I am missing something here.I played through as a custom class Human, using Shotgun, Assault Rifle (both upto 6) with the maximum amount of charisma unlocked (to enable dialogue options) and some minor spirit control - for use on summon points.A lot of the extra etiquette options are null and void, each only being used once as far as I can see, and there are not many side missions, only encountered a single side mission, and one that was suggested as optional inbetween a major mission arc. (involving coyote)Combat is nice, tactical settings and options all very good - cover, scenery, summon points and ley lines adding to strategy level.The way you build your team can totally alter the playstyle you adopt, but overall you can ham fist your way through the majority of the missions with good combat skills. (with a solid main character at least)This was a real shame because although some levels were a challenge it was mainly because of a poor choice in a combat round (don't summon 3 spirits then have them go rogue woops) not because I struggled to overcome the enemies.This carried on right up until the end, again the only difficulty coming from the choice of enemy used to progress difficulty (spirits).Totally worth the time invested but I was expecting a lot more conversational choices (2 of the etiquette lines are not even used) and a LOT more side material in line with the none combat skills I only encountered 3 places in the game where I couldn't personally unlock, influence or action something because it was based on - decking, strength, or intelligence.Even race choice and stereotype seems to have little impact.I get that this is a showcase for the engine, and the ability to mod in more content is nice, but overall the vanilla campaign had a lot more potential than a basic manhunt combat run. imo

Posted: November 6, 2015
ShadowRun is the game you wish you had instead of playing DnDTL;DRRating: A soild 8/10Pros:  - Hours of playtime - Different play styles  - Many classes that suit all different kinds of play styles - A DnD feel to the game that all DnD players have to try - The story line is not narrow and you have choices on how to solve puzzels or kill enemies.  - Turn base combat system that is actually worth waiting for.  - Tons of ways to complete missions. - Complete charcter customization - Well priced for the contentCons: To begin with the game is not for people looking for a shootem up and kick everyones asses as soon as they get into the room. It's turn based. - Can get borning in some areas, but the game makes up for it with combat and great story telling. - Lacking some content, wish there was a bit more.Conclusion: The game is worth paying the $15. If you're into a DnD play style then this game is for you. Hours of fun and so many ways to complete the game. I'd pick it up if it was on sale if you want to save some money.

Posted: January 27, 2016
												Pros:- Nice visuals, awesome portraits, the art style is very fitting and immersive.- The combat system is enjoyable but could use some polish.- Dialogues and NPCs in general are very well written.- The story is part dumb, part engaging. It fits into the setting, altough it somewhat turns downhill towards the second half. The writing is good for the most part though.- The setting, I personally love the setting. Cons:- The combat, despite its solid foundation feels cheap and too easy. - The decking sections are super boring.- The game is waaay too linear for an RPG. It takes away from the awesome dialogues when you know you can't change a drek no matter what you say/do.- The music is rather forgettable. - The spell effects are down right ugly.- The game world is gated behind loading screens and comes in small chunks. In this regard it's similar to Deus Ex - you're being teleported from location to location, thus the world seems small and contained.They did an awesome job of bringing Shadowrun to PC, but sadly it's just isn't that good of a game. Feels more like an interactive novel, an introduction into the world of Shadowrun. The dialogues, the NPCs, the visuals and the cyberpunk distopia, the immersion of being a runner... it's all there and it's a pleasant journey for the fan of the setting. It's just it doesn't feel like you're DOING anything, other than watch the game play itself.  It's like this GM friend who's got this really awesome story he wants to tell you... but you can't alter a thing, your PC is but a pawn in his hands and you can only sit, listen and bask in the ambience. And if the story was indeed as good as he promised I would have enjoyed the ride way better.Either way, if the story was better or the gameplay was more polished the score would have been higher. As is the final score sits somewhere around 6-7/10. Still, the game is so cheap these days, and the setting is so awesome you should buy it anyway.

content:
Posted: May 4, 2014
												I'm not sure why this game has had so many bad reviews; I really enjoyed it.Shadowrun Returns is based on the old pen and paper role playing game Shadowrun. Set in a world where magic has "returned" to the Earth along with races that we are all familiar with in Fantasy stories. Magic and technology, spells and hacking all blend into this mishmash of Cyberpunk and Fantasy, and for the most part it works pretty well.The mechanics of the game will be familiar with anyone who has enjoyed games such as Fallout 1 & 2 or any X-Com games. The game has turn based combat and a deep class system, wherein you level, spend points (known as Karma) and find more powerful weapons, clothing and spells.The campaign that comes with the game: "Dead man's switch" is quite enjoyable, if a little short, however this game has steam workshop and plenty of mods to try out once you are done.A few negative things do crop up in this game, however. First and most obvious from the get-go, the graphics are horrendous; they are actually not that far beyond the Super Nintendo game and that was made in 1993... but graphics aren't everything right? What about the fact that you cannot export your character that you so lovingly built up in the campaign into other mods? Unless you basically hack the game, that is. And just like any game with "dice rolls" this game is seriously suspect when it comes to calculating chance.All in all good game. It needs to have more accessibility so that you can export characters into different adventures, but you will still get alot out of it.

number of helpful: 2 of 3 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 26, 2014
												A return to to Shadowrun is like coming back to an old friend. I used to play and love "Shadowrun" for the SNES - never played the P&P RPG - but I was too young to fully understand the world and lore. Getting back into it now, the memories have come flooding back to me, along with the old enjoyment I felt of exploring a cyberpunk world full of corporate elves and shadowrunning orks.This is a game without voice actors, without an advanced 3D engine, and without amazing particle effects. It is, however, a game with some fantastic and moody writing (and benefits from no voice actors because of this, IMO), a memorable story, and an ending with great closure. Before I get into pointing out a few things I liked and disliked, if you're a fan of RPGs with a focus on story and setting, this game is for you.I played once through the Dead Man's Switch campaign, and I'm still a little undecided on how I feel about the leveling system. It seems, to me, a little bit simple. It could definitely benefit from some type of "perks" system that you could put points into that allow the gameplay to vary some. As it stands, it's all a bit too straight-forward for my liking, without any real hard decisions to make. if you want to use SMGs and be a decker, you just put karma points into those two stat lines, and that's about it. It's not bad, just not great.The story, however, is wonderful, along with the characters. Coyote is memorable, and I hope to see her appear in the next expansion as well, and it was nice to see Jake Armitage make an appearance early. It really helped ground the game in the Shadowrun lore. There was a bit of a running red herring throughout the story (at least, I'm pretty sure it was), and I was genuinely happy to see the villain turn out a bit differently than I thought.The actual combat is a bit like a simplified version of X-COM. It's turn-based, it utilizes a rudimentary cover system, and it includes magic along with gunplay. It's fun enough, but, along with the leveling system, seems a bit on the simple side, without much variation. This could be alleviated some, I feel, by using scripting to make the combat encounters more interesting. The shoot-out in the cemetery, for example, was easily, IMO, the best encounter of the game as it added variety and surprise in the middle of the fight.And, of course, the editor! I dabbled in this for a number of hours, and it seems perfectly robust and easy to use if you've ever modded games in the past to any extent. I have experience creating modules for Neverwinter Nights, and the Shadowrun Returns editor is mercifully easier to use when scripting, as it gives you the language to select from, instead of you having to discover it yourself.All in all, I definitely recommend this game to those who are either Shadowrun fans, RPG fans that love a good story (and aren't afraid to read as it seems a lot of gamers are these days), or want to create your own stories using the editor. I would give Shadowrun Returns a 7.5/10.

												Shadowrun Returns is a digital translation of the pen and paper game. The Shadowrun rulebook contained a short adventure/module/run/gig that served to demonstrate the game's mechanics. In those days it was expected that the GM would make their own runs. In that same way Shadowrun Returns was released with a short run. Soon thereafter the workshop filled with community crafted runs.Please do not look at this game based solely on the released run, look at the community crafted runs as well.Full disclosure: I play this for nostalgic reasons and the low metascore bums me out.
